description: The Continual Service Improvement module focuses on how organizations and individuals can strategically review the products and services they have produced following the strategy, design, transition and operation stages of the IT Service Lifecycle and offers guidance on how this process should be organized and executed. It also includes guidance on the tools and technology that can be used to support CSI activities as well as how to evaluate risks and critical success factors.

episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Intermediate
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.717
[SOUND] Hi and welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:05.717 --> 00:00:07.431
My name is Jo Peacock and

3
00:00:07.431 --> 00:00:13.190
I'm going to be taking you through
an introduction to your ITIL intermediate.

4
00:00:14.320 --> 00:00:18.520
So let's take a look then at
our first slide here coming up.

5
00:00:18.520 --> 00:00:23.840
And we have our introduction
to our intermediate class and

6
00:00:23.840 --> 00:00:27.730
exactly what content is going to be found
in this upcoming intermediate class.

7
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:32.745
You will see what we will cover is
an introduction to the class followed

8
00:00:32.745 --> 00:00:37.112
by the principles and
the processes of the lifecycle phase.

9
00:00:37.112 --> 00:00:40.907
Then we'll take a look at organizing for
that lifecycle phase and

10
00:00:40.907 --> 00:00:43.500
also the technology considerations.

11
00:00:43.500 --> 00:00:48.270
Especially those that we need when
we're implementing the phase itself.

12
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:51.880
Then we'll take a look at the challenges
and the critical success factors and

13
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:57.110
all of the risks that are associated
with that particular lifecycle phase.

14
00:00:57.110 --> 00:01:00.692
And most importantly, of course,
for you, is that preparation for

15
00:01:00.692 --> 00:01:04.543
the exam that's going to be coming up
when you have completed your class.

16
00:01:04.543 --> 00:01:07.142
Okay, so let me take a look now then and

17
00:01:07.142 --> 00:01:11.790
how we're going to approach this
particular intermediate class.

18
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:17.230
We're going to be doing
some presentation work,

19
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:22.550
obviously you're going to be watching us
on-screen both myself and my colleagues,

20
00:01:22.550 --> 00:01:27.110
and we're going to be taking you through
the course materials for the class.

21
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:31.450
And then there are going to be some
discussions and some exercises that

22
00:01:31.450 --> 00:01:38.140
are going to be based primarily in our
chat rooms and also in our forums as well.

23
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.530
And we're also available if you want
to undertake any of the assessments,

24
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:45.960
then please feel free to come
back to us via the forums and

25
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:49.270
we will be able to help
you out in any way we can.

26
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:51.950
Also provided in the course material,
which is available for

27
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:57.390
you to download, are mock tests or
exams if you prefer to use that word.

28
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:02.720
And we will be conducting a run
through of that mock exam for you.

29
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.675
So, where are we then at
ITIL intermediate level?

30
00:02:08.675 --> 00:02:15.090
Well, you'll see in using Bloomâ€™s Taxonomy
that we are actually at Level 4 Analyzing.

31
00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:19.931
In other words, we've done foundation
level, we've done the remembering and

32
00:02:19.931 --> 00:02:23.007
the understanding of those
concepts within ITIL.

33
00:02:23.007 --> 00:02:26.361
And we're actually moving
through applying those

34
00:02:26.361 --> 00:02:29.020
concepts to analyzing those concepts.

35
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:32.809
And being able to apply
the ITIL processes, and

36
00:02:32.809 --> 00:02:38.787
also the concepts at a real world level,
in a real world situation, okay?

37
00:02:38.787 --> 00:02:42.171
So where does ITIL come from then?

38
00:02:42.171 --> 00:02:45.080
Well let me give you a little
bit of a background.

39
00:02:45.080 --> 00:02:48.812
It's actually owned by
a company called Axelos and

40
00:02:48.812 --> 00:02:53.771
it was first published in the mid 1980s,
by the UK government.

41
00:02:53.771 --> 00:03:00.665
And the Office of Government Commerce
owned ITIL for a very, very long time.

42
00:03:00.665 --> 00:03:04.915
And we developed ITIL right
the way back from the 1980s,

43
00:03:04.915 --> 00:03:08.999
through its version 2 in the 1990s,
mid 1990s,

44
00:03:08.999 --> 00:03:12.271
to version 3 which was released in 2007.

45
00:03:12.271 --> 00:03:17.620
And then there was an update
to version 3 in 2011,

46
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:22.450
which is exactly where we are right now.

47
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:26.660
It is copyright, it is trademark
protected, it's a framework for

48
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:28.670
managing services.

49
00:03:28.670 --> 00:03:31.928
And as such, it is a flexible framework,

50
00:03:31.928 --> 00:03:37.796
a framework that we would expect any
organization to adopt as a framework,

51
00:03:37.796 --> 00:03:41.443
but then to adapt it to suit your needs,
okay?

52
00:03:41.443 --> 00:03:45.117
ITIL was born right
the way back in the 1980s,

53
00:03:45.117 --> 00:03:49.405
out of a desire to be able to
demonstrate value for money and

54
00:03:49.405 --> 00:03:54.340
efficiency for
the use of taxpayer's money within the UK.

55
00:03:54.340 --> 00:03:58.860
Way back in the 1980s these things
started appearing on desks and

56
00:03:58.860 --> 00:04:03.880
quite frankly, we didn't know how
to manage these in an unbiased,

57
00:04:03.880 --> 00:04:07.883
in an impartial and
in an efficient and effective way.

58
00:04:07.883 --> 00:04:13.009
And thus ITIL was born, and ITIL was
born from a group of industry experts

59
00:04:13.009 --> 00:04:18.305
that went out into the big wide world and
analysed various organizations,

60
00:04:18.305 --> 00:04:23.098
from various different industry sectors,
not just government but

61
00:04:23.098 --> 00:04:26.990
we're talking finance,
we're talking retail etc.

62
00:04:26.990 --> 00:04:31.040
And they came back with
a set of best practices,

63
00:04:31.040 --> 00:04:38.045
best practices that they observed in the
real world for managing our IT services.

64
00:04:38.045 --> 00:04:42.654
And thus, we have ITIL and
as I've already said we've had

65
00:04:42.654 --> 00:04:47.940
subsequent revisions and
now we're up to version 3, 2011.

66
00:04:47.940 --> 00:04:52.724
So we work on the understanding that we

67
00:04:52.724 --> 00:04:57.361
have a life to every single service.

68
00:04:57.361 --> 00:05:01.715
And we start off with a concept
in service strategy and

69
00:05:01.715 --> 00:05:07.600
then we take that concept and
we design it and then we develop it.

70
00:05:07.600 --> 00:05:12.791
And we deploy it as a service into a live
environment which is where we operate and

71
00:05:12.791 --> 00:05:14.273
where we maintain it.

72
00:05:14.273 --> 00:05:19.040
And we continually seek to
ensure that we are aligned with

73
00:05:19.040 --> 00:05:22.230
the needs of the organization in CSI.

74
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:29.320
So you're attending this class
because you probably want to

75
00:05:29.320 --> 00:05:33.031
achieve an ITIL
Intermediate Qualification.

76
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.920
So you can that,
if we were to start off right at the very,

77
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:40.280
very top, you'll see where I am.

78
00:05:40.280 --> 00:05:46.560
I am an accredited ITIL trainer, working
with an accredited training organization.

79
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:52.830
I'm also an accredited examiner, and
proctor, or invigilator for these exams.

80
00:05:52.830 --> 00:05:57.020
And work very, very closely with
the official ITIL accreditor and

81
00:05:57.020 --> 00:06:00.560
also Axelos who owns the ITIL copyright.

82
00:06:02.100 --> 00:06:07.080
Now in terms of ITIL, where can you
go with your qualification level?

83
00:06:07.080 --> 00:06:09.058
Well, we start off with ITIL Foundation.

84
00:06:09.058 --> 00:06:14.103
And ITIL Foundation would
traditionally be a three day

85
00:06:14.103 --> 00:06:19.927
classroom experience where we
learn the foundations of ITIL.

86
00:06:19.927 --> 00:06:23.542
And we learn all the terminology, and all
of the definitions to that terminology.

87
00:06:23.542 --> 00:06:28.900
There's roughly around about 75 that we
learn within the ITIL Foundation class.

88
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:31.560
And then, as we move through we can

89
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:36.710
either take an ITIL practitioner class
which can be taken at any point in time,

90
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:40.820
throughout the progression
of your career within ITIL.

91
00:06:40.820 --> 00:06:46.220
Because ITIL practitioner focuses on
the implementation of ITIL, okay?

92
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:50.210
Whereas if we take a look at the more
advanced intermediate classes,

93
00:06:50.210 --> 00:06:55.048
you are at this moment
in a Lifecycle Modules.

94
00:06:55.048 --> 00:06:59.720
And those Lifecycle Modules consist
of service strategy, service design,

95
00:06:59.720 --> 00:07:04.470
service transition, service operation and
continual service improvement.

96
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:08.557
And that's where we focus on those
lifecycles that we've just looked at

97
00:07:08.557 --> 00:07:09.367
previously.

98
00:07:09.367 --> 00:07:14.776
Okay, and on the right hand side
then we have our capability modules,

99
00:07:14.776 --> 00:07:20.590
and these capability modules really
focus on specific areas within ITIL.

100
00:07:20.590 --> 00:07:27.109
Such as, RCV which focuses on
release control and validation.

101
00:07:27.109 --> 00:07:30.504
And these classes,
you will notice that every single

102
00:07:30.504 --> 00:07:34.430
one of these classes has got
a score right beside each one.

103
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:39.271
So we've got a number 2 for
ITIL Foundation and we've got a 3 for

104
00:07:39.271 --> 00:07:44.213
Lifecycle Modules and we've got a 4 for
our Capability Modules.

105
00:07:44.213 --> 00:07:49.383
Now what we need to do is
ensure that we have achieved

106
00:07:49.383 --> 00:07:54.674
a minimum of 15 credits at
both either lifecycle or

107
00:07:54.674 --> 00:07:57.460
capability module level.

108
00:07:57.460 --> 00:08:03.252
In order to be able to qualify to sit the
Managing Across the Lifecycle class and

109
00:08:03.252 --> 00:08:08.665
therefore subsequently the test
that goes along with that class.

110
00:08:08.665 --> 00:08:13.065
So we need to take two from the ITIL
Foundation, that's a prerequisite,

111
00:08:13.065 --> 00:08:14.905
we have to do the foundation.

112
00:08:14.905 --> 00:08:19.756
And then we need to add in another
15 scores from either, as I've said,

113
00:08:19.756 --> 00:08:22.511
the lifecycle or the capability stream.

114
00:08:22.511 --> 00:08:25.549
Now you can interchange,
you can mix and match,

115
00:08:25.549 --> 00:08:29.100
you do not have to stick to one stream or
the other.

116
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:33.215
Once you've got that 17 in total scores

117
00:08:33.215 --> 00:08:37.165
that are needed to be able to sit
Managing across The Lifecycle.

118
00:08:37.165 --> 00:08:40.805
You're perfectly able to sit
that lifecycle class and

119
00:08:40.805 --> 00:08:43.503
to be able to take that test afterwards.

120
00:08:43.503 --> 00:08:48.542
And as soon as you've take that test,
you will be awarded those 5 credits,

121
00:08:48.542 --> 00:08:52.535
which will mean that you
have achieved ITIL Expert.

122
00:08:52.535 --> 00:08:57.073
Now, ITIL Expert is allocated
as soon as you have passed

123
00:08:57.073 --> 00:09:02.510
the Managing Across the Lifecycle test and
have achieved 22 credits.

124
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:05.770
Both of those must happen in order for
you to achieve ITIL Expert.

125
00:09:07.380 --> 00:09:10.090
Now, we have the ITIL Master
qualification,

126
00:09:10.090 --> 00:09:14.630
and the ITIL Master is
a completely different beast.

127
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:19.410
The ITIL Master is a two-year
qualification, and

128
00:09:19.410 --> 00:09:25.750
during that two years you will be
expected to submit various white papers

129
00:09:25.750 --> 00:09:31.500
on specific topics within
the ITIL qualification scheme.

130
00:09:31.500 --> 00:09:35.870
So these could be topics
on activities within ITIL,

131
00:09:35.870 --> 00:09:38.830
these could be topics on
processes within ITIL,

132
00:09:38.830 --> 00:09:43.810
these could be topics on implementation
of various aspects of ITIL.

133
00:09:43.810 --> 00:09:46.860
But you will be required to sit
a number of white papers or

134
00:09:46.860 --> 00:09:51.410
submit a number of white papers
over the period of two years.

135
00:09:51.410 --> 00:09:56.520
At the end of those two years,
once you have submitted the prerequisite

136
00:09:56.520 --> 00:10:01.260
white papers then you will be
asked to attend a panel interview.

137
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:06.760
And during that panel interview, you will
be assessed not only on your white papers,

138
00:10:06.760 --> 00:10:11.880
but also on your experience within
the IT service management arena.

139
00:10:11.880 --> 00:10:13.890
And at the end of that panel interview,

140
00:10:13.890 --> 00:10:18.630
then if successful, you will be
awarded the status of ITIL Master.

141
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:24.735
So the qualification scheme, I'm going to
take this back now to Bloom's Taxonomy

142
00:10:24.735 --> 00:10:28.969
then and just very, very quickly look
at the fact that in ITIL Foundation.

143
00:10:28.969 --> 00:10:32.661
And I know that I've already
covered this on a previous slide,

144
00:10:32.661 --> 00:10:36.774
we just looked at understanding,
understanding the terminology and

145
00:10:36.774 --> 00:10:39.150
the concepts of ITIL Foundation.

146
00:10:39.150 --> 00:10:43.954
And then in the Lifecycle Modules we're
looking at implementing those processes

147
00:10:43.954 --> 00:10:45.423
contained within ITIL.

148
00:10:45.423 --> 00:10:50.148
And in Capability we're looking at
actually undertaking those process and

149
00:10:50.148 --> 00:10:51.928
managing those processes.

150
00:10:51.928 --> 00:10:57.446
Whereas Managing Across the Lifecycle,
this is for senior management,

151
00:10:57.446 --> 00:11:01.639
this is at CIO level, and
its senior management level.

152
00:11:01.639 --> 00:11:05.179
And in MALC,
as we like to abbreviate it to,

153
00:11:05.179 --> 00:11:10.475
you're concerned with leading
IT service management.

154
00:11:10.475 --> 00:11:15.262
So I mentioned right at the very
beginning of all of this that we had

155
00:11:15.262 --> 00:11:20.240
a test to go along with every single
lifecycle phase, and there is.

156
00:11:20.240 --> 00:11:25.176
And we will be conducting a session
to go over this particular test or

157
00:11:25.176 --> 00:11:27.600
at least a sample of these tests,

158
00:11:27.600 --> 00:11:32.960
just to give you some preparation for
the actual test itself.

159
00:11:32.960 --> 00:11:38.678
So your test is conducted online,
it's conducted virtually.

160
00:11:38.678 --> 00:11:46.390
It is an 8 multiple choice question test,
it's complex multiple choice.

161
00:11:46.390 --> 00:11:48.829
You get an hour and a half for
this particular test.

162
00:11:48.829 --> 00:11:54.054
And with every single question,
you will be given a scenario and

163
00:11:54.054 --> 00:11:59.958
then you will be given four possible
options, four possible answers for

164
00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:04.331
the question that is posed
along with that scenario.

165
00:12:04.331 --> 00:12:10.410
You get 5 points for the best fit answer,
now it mentions up there the most correct.

166
00:12:10.410 --> 00:12:13.910
I always call it the best fit,
because every single question asks

167
00:12:13.910 --> 00:12:19.300
what is the best answer given
the scenario and given the question?

168
00:12:19.300 --> 00:12:24.860
Don't be alarmed if you don't see
an answer that you think is 100% correct,

169
00:12:24.860 --> 00:12:28.480
because the question is asking you for
the best fit.

170
00:12:28.480 --> 00:12:32.800
And for that best fit you're
gonna get 5 points, for

171
00:12:32.800 --> 00:12:37.696
the next best fit you're gonna get 3,
for the next one which

172
00:12:37.696 --> 00:12:42.897
we've considered to be the least
correct you're gonna get 1.

173
00:12:42.897 --> 00:12:47.890
And for the next one you're gonna get a 0,
now it mentions up on that

174
00:12:47.890 --> 00:12:52.021
slide there that the next one
is 0 marks for incorrect.

175
00:12:52.021 --> 00:12:56.490
We like to call that in the industry, us
in the know, we call that the distractor.

176
00:12:56.490 --> 00:13:00.600
And we call it the distractor for
a reason, cuz it distracts.

177
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:04.130
And quite often what you will find is,
with your distractor,

178
00:13:04.130 --> 00:13:08.440
a lot of the words in the terminology that
are taken straight out of the ITIL books,

179
00:13:08.440 --> 00:13:10.790
straight out of the publications, and

180
00:13:10.790 --> 00:13:15.490
are input into that 0 pointer
because it's there to distract.

181
00:13:15.490 --> 00:13:21.250
And it sounds great, but more often
than not, that distractor has absolutely

182
00:13:21.250 --> 00:13:26.600
no relevance to the scenario or
to the question.

183
00:13:26.600 --> 00:13:31.480
So you have to be incredibly careful with
that, it's so easy to be distracted.

184
00:13:32.800 --> 00:13:38.370
You have to get 28 out of a possible
40 in order to be able to pass and

185
00:13:38.370 --> 00:13:44.540
achieve accreditation at
any lifecycle test, okay?

186
00:13:44.540 --> 00:13:48.960
If English is not your first language you
are allowed a paper dictionary, but you

187
00:13:48.960 --> 00:13:55.650
will be asked to show that to the proctor
at the time that you take your test.

188
00:13:55.650 --> 00:14:01.648
And as I've already said, you have to
have an ITIL Foundation in version 3 or

189
00:14:01.648 --> 00:14:08.225
version 3 2011, or an ITIL version 2
Foundation Bridge to version 3, okay?

190
00:14:08.225 --> 00:14:13.287
I will be very, very honest with you,
there are not that many

191
00:14:13.287 --> 00:14:18.580
people that have attained
the version 2 to version 3 Bridge.

192
00:14:18.580 --> 00:14:23.350
And most people will have the version 3 or

193
00:14:23.350 --> 00:14:27.540
2011, sorry, ITIL Foundation certificate.

194
00:14:27.540 --> 00:14:31.730
You will be required to
upload that certificate to

195
00:14:31.730 --> 00:14:36.510
the examining board prior to
sitting your lifecycle test.

196
00:14:36.510 --> 00:14:40.680
So be prepared with that,
you will need to have it to hand and

197
00:14:40.680 --> 00:14:42.590
saved as a PDF as well.

198
00:14:44.250 --> 00:14:51.880
So when we come to the end of every single
lifecycle class, we will be going over and

199
00:14:51.880 --> 00:14:56.410
this one's no exception,
we'll be going over a sample test for you.

200
00:14:56.410 --> 00:14:59.670
And during that sample test I'll
be giving you lots of hints and

201
00:14:59.670 --> 00:15:04.150
tips on how to select that
best fit possible answer.

202
00:15:04.150 --> 00:15:08.300
And also how to ensure that you read
the full question, how to relax and

203
00:15:08.300 --> 00:15:13.200
to make sure that you approach
it with an open mind, but

204
00:15:13.200 --> 00:15:16.100
you consider relevance
in every single answer.

205
00:15:17.590 --> 00:15:21.610
Ultimately, we wanna get you
past the test just as much as

206
00:15:21.610 --> 00:15:23.760
you want to achieve that accreditation.

207
00:15:24.970 --> 00:15:30.608
So just to sum up, what we will
be doing over the next few shows

208
00:15:30.608 --> 00:15:37.255
is encouraging you to take your ITIL
lifecycle intermediate classes.

209
00:15:37.255 --> 00:15:41.289
And feel free to join us in the forums for
any questions that you may have.

210
00:15:41.289 --> 00:15:41.789
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews the key aspects of ITIL foundation by describing the 5 core volume service lifecycles: service strategy, service design, service transition, service operation, and continual service improvement.  She also defines what ITIL means by a Service and Service Management.  Also the key terms that define value: Utility and Warranty by Jo.

the definitions that we
learned in foundation class.

459
00:26:18.970 --> 00:26:22.190
Here's another term and definition
that we learned in foundation class

460
00:26:22.190 --> 00:26:25.750
is the concept of both internal and
external services.

461
00:26:26.850 --> 00:26:34.180
And an internal service is a service that
we provide internally to our organization.

462
00:26:34.180 --> 00:26:37.610
And an external service is a service
that we provide externally

463
00:26:37.610 --> 00:26:39.520
to external customers.

464
00:26:39.520 --> 00:26:43.820
So an internal service would be something,
and I use examples like SAP or

465
00:26:43.820 --> 00:26:49.020
like our email services,
something internal to our organization.

466
00:26:49.020 --> 00:26:52.862
But then an external service is
something that our customers use,

467
00:26:52.862 --> 00:26:54.927
such as the websites for instance.

468
00:26:54.927 --> 00:26:56.977
Or external service catalogues,

469
00:26:56.977 --> 00:27:02.280
if we're in an industry where we are
selling goods externally to our customers.

470
00:27:02.280 --> 00:27:07.543
So you will see here from this particular
slide that over on the left hand side,

471
00:27:07.543 --> 00:27:11.156
internal services are delivered
to business units.

472
00:27:11.156 --> 00:27:17.140
And then in turn, use those to deliver
a service to external customers.

473
00:27:17.140 --> 00:27:22.160
And then on the right hand side,
we have services like our Internet that

474
00:27:22.160 --> 00:27:28.460
are delivered directly through
our external customers, okay?

475
00:27:28.460 --> 00:27:32.910
On the next slide, there's just
really a little bit of an example of

476
00:27:34.260 --> 00:27:40.110
core services, enabling services,
and enhancing services, okay?

477
00:27:40.110 --> 00:27:43.320
Which is just further classification
of our services to be honest.

478
00:27:43.320 --> 00:27:47.431
We split our services down, believe it or
not, into those that are core.

479
00:27:47.431 --> 00:27:51.877
Those that are enabling services and
those that are enhancing services.

480
00:27:51.877 --> 00:27:56.374
Now we've got pizza delivery example
up there on the screen in front of you.

481
00:27:56.374 --> 00:27:59.520
I wanna give you an IT example for
instance.

482
00:27:59.520 --> 00:28:04.780
So let's think about our email service.

483
00:28:04.780 --> 00:28:09.508
So the core service in an email
service is that ability to send and

484
00:28:09.508 --> 00:28:12.760
receive email, that's our core service.

485
00:28:12.760 --> 00:28:17.395
Now, the enabling service is a service
that's a service in its own right.

486
00:28:17.395 --> 00:28:21.640
But that underpins the core service,
and that would be our infrastructure.

487
00:28:21.640 --> 00:28:23.400
It's a service in its own right, but

488
00:28:23.400 --> 00:28:28.580
without it, email is not going to
be able to be sent or received.

489
00:28:28.580 --> 00:28:32.960
And then an enhancing
service is an optional extra.

490
00:28:32.960 --> 00:28:37.222
Something that we can do that maybe
sets up apart from our competitors or

491
00:28:37.222 --> 00:28:39.433
something that we just choose to do.

492
00:28:39.433 --> 00:28:41.463
It's optional for our business, and

493
00:28:41.463 --> 00:28:45.160
that would be something like
a shared calendar for instance.

494
00:28:45.160 --> 00:28:47.694
Okay, so
something that is an optional extra.

495
00:28:47.694 --> 00:28:55.172
That's our shared directory, shared
calendar is the word I'm looking for.

496
00:28:55.172 --> 00:28:59.279
Okay, so these are our core and
our enabling and our enhancing services.

497
00:29:01.300 --> 00:29:06.310
Now I asked you about value
a little earlier on and

498
00:29:06.310 --> 00:29:09.460
about what we perceive as value.

499
00:29:09.460 --> 00:29:13.897
So I'm just gonna wrap up this
section by going over a couple

500
00:29:13.897 --> 00:29:17.641
of slides that look over
the definition of value.

501
00:29:17.641 --> 00:29:22.191
Now, you will see that in the bottom
of this particular slide right

502
00:29:22.191 --> 00:29:23.960
in front of you now.

503
00:29:23.960 --> 00:29:30.089
You will see that the diagram that you
saw in your ITIL Foundation class.

504
00:29:30.089 --> 00:29:33.344
And that is that diagram that always
looks very, very complicated.

505
00:29:33.344 --> 00:29:36.914
And everybody always says to me,
how am I supposed to remember this?

506
00:29:36.914 --> 00:29:39.945
Well, it's really easy
because you just need

507
00:29:39.945 --> 00:29:43.450
to remember the concept of the utility and
warranty.

508
00:29:44.530 --> 00:29:47.944
So the concept of utility is very,
very simply,

509
00:29:47.944 --> 00:29:50.539
does it do what it's supposed to do?

510
00:29:50.539 --> 00:29:52.478
That's its fitness for purpose.

511
00:29:52.478 --> 00:29:55.081
Does that service send and receive email?

512
00:29:55.081 --> 00:29:56.001
Yes, it does.

513
00:29:56.001 --> 00:29:57.807
Okay, then it has utility.

514
00:29:57.807 --> 00:30:02.215
And you can have a web based email
service that will do exactly that for

515
00:30:02.215 --> 00:30:04.422
you, it will deliver that email.

516
00:30:04.422 --> 00:30:08.498
But can I ask you in a business
perspective then Ronnie,

517
00:30:08.498 --> 00:30:13.444
would a web based email deliver you
levels of security that you would

518
00:30:13.444 --> 00:30:16.327
feel comfortable with, do you think?

519
00:30:16.327 --> 00:30:18.509
>> Yeah, not necessarily,

520
00:30:18.509 --> 00:30:24.171
especially if I'm actually using
a public provider and not my own.

521
00:30:24.171 --> 00:30:28.259
As far as a portal that allows me
access just inside of my own network.

522
00:30:28.259 --> 00:30:33.449
>> Yeah, right, so what you're saying
is then, in effect, is that that

523
00:30:33.449 --> 00:30:39.690
service provides utility, which it doe,
but it doesn't provide warranty aspect.

524
00:30:39.690 --> 00:30:42.380
And if we look at the warranty aspect,

525
00:30:42.380 --> 00:30:46.668
you will see that those warranty
aspects are availability,

526
00:30:46.668 --> 00:30:51.642
capacity, security, which is one
that I mentioned and continuity.

527
00:30:51.642 --> 00:30:57.926
And so both utility and warranty have to
exist in order for us to perceive value.

528
00:30:57.926 --> 00:31:01.292
So let's go through
those warranty aspects.

529
00:31:01.292 --> 00:31:03.943
Is there service available enough?

530
00:31:03.943 --> 00:31:10.793
Well okay, an Internet based webmail
service might be available enough.

531
00:31:10.793 --> 00:31:12.590
But does it have it enough capacity?

532
00:31:13.890 --> 00:31:18.260
Guarantee when you try and some files,
it'll tell you that they're too big.

533
00:31:18.260 --> 00:31:19.622
Does it have continuity?

534
00:31:19.622 --> 00:31:23.410
Well it might do, but
we don't have any assurance of that.

535
00:31:23.410 --> 00:31:27.490
And that's the key thing about warranty,
is that we have assurance.

536
00:31:27.490 --> 00:31:31.217
And we certainly don't have
any assurance for security.

537
00:31:31.217 --> 00:31:36.430
So you see both utility and warranty
need to exist for us to perceive value.

538
00:31:36.430 --> 00:31:38.356
It's not just good enough for

539
00:31:38.356 --> 00:31:41.833
us to have a service that does
what it says on the card.

540
00:31:41.833 --> 00:31:44.819
We've got to be able to use it as well.

541
00:31:44.819 --> 00:31:46.187
And this next slide,

542
00:31:46.187 --> 00:31:51.090
which is something that I'm going
to use to wrap up this session.

543
00:31:51.090 --> 00:31:56.230
If you look, the utility effect
in that bottom left hand corner

544
00:31:56.230 --> 00:32:01.030
is all about increasing
the probability and

545
00:32:01.030 --> 00:32:05.440
maintaining that probability
of that service working.

546
00:32:05.440 --> 00:32:06.736
In other words,

547
00:32:06.736 --> 00:32:12.487
that service will do what it says on
the card without a shadow of the doubt.

548
00:32:12.487 --> 00:32:18.129
But the warranty effect has to
actually decrease varriances and

549
00:32:18.129 --> 00:32:23.891
availability and in capacity and
in continuity and in security.

550
00:32:23.891 --> 00:32:29.387
Because what we actually want to do is we
want to ensure that we have all of those.

551
00:32:29.387 --> 00:32:33.479
So we want to decrease,
we want to decrease

552
00:32:33.479 --> 00:32:37.924
the uncertainty of
providing those aspects.

553
00:32:37.924 --> 00:32:41.761
As we've said,
we have got to have both utility and

554
00:32:41.761 --> 00:32:45.428
warranty in order for
anyone to perceive value.

555
00:32:45.428 --> 00:32:49.991
So for now, we're going to wrap
up this particular session,

556
00:32:49.991 --> 00:32:53.869
which is part one of our
recap over ITIL Foundation.

557
00:32:53.869 --> 00:32:57.924
And in our next section, we're going
to look further into our assets and

558
00:32:57.924 --> 00:33:00.461
into our resources and capabilities, etc.

559
00:33:00.461 --> 00:33:06.766
And we're also going to look at processes
and we're going to look at rolls and

560
00:33:06.766 --> 00:33:11.720
we're going to look at all of
our responsibilities etc too.

561
00:33:11.720 --> 00:33:13.682
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for

562
00:33:13.682 --> 00:33:16.006
helping us out with this
part of the refresher.

563
00:33:16.006 --> 00:33:20.191
There's a lot more for us to cover, but
that means we're gonna go ahead and

564
00:33:20.191 --> 00:33:21.533
end this episode then.

565
00:33:21.533 --> 00:33:25.822
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

566
00:33:25.822 --> 00:33:27.130
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

567
00:33:27.130 --> 00:33:31.896
>> Stay tuned right here, for
another ITIL Foundation Refresher.

568
00:33:31.896 --> 00:33:37.977
[MUSIC]

569
00:33:37.977 --> 00:33:44.819
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews asset, resource, capabilities and processes from the ITIL perspective.  She emphasizes the process model and roles associated with processes.  Lastly, she describes the accountability that belongs to the service owner as well.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher Part 2

WEBVTT

1

00:00:24.560 --> 00:00:29.320

00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:40.659

>> Yeah, I mean it's, this foundation

00:00:56.865 --> 00:00:58.610
there's so much information-

00:00:58.610 --> 00:01:01.170
>> To absorb, so much information.

And it really is, and the unfortunate

And so
what we're learning here is concepts.

30

And I will admit that

31
00:01:41.935 --> 00:01:44.040
[LAUGH]
>> All right, Jo, so

just take us a little bit through
what we reviewed last time and

00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:50.750

be heading from there.

34
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:51.480
>> Okay.
So in part one,

35
00:01:51.480 --> 00:01:54.510
we actually looked at
the concept of a service.

36
00:01:54.510 --> 00:01:56.220
And the concept of a service is,

37
00:01:56.220 --> 00:02:01.080
a service is a means of delivering value
by facilitating the outcomes that our

38
00:02:01.080 --> 00:02:05.730
customers want to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

39
00:02:05.730 --> 00:02:08.440
Now, you know value is perceived.

40
00:02:08.440 --> 00:02:11.880
As I mentioned, we all have
a different perception of value and

41
00:02:11.880 --> 00:02:16.460
even in a business environment our
perception of value is still different.

42
00:02:16.460 --> 00:02:19.590
No matter how much we
would like to try and

43
00:02:19.590 --> 00:02:24.250
deliver a one size fits all
approach to our services,

44
00:02:24.250 --> 00:02:28.590
to our businesses, we can't do
that because value is perceived.

45
00:02:28.590 --> 00:02:32.410
So we looked at that and we looked
at the fact that service management,

46
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:37.890
which ITIL is a framework is a set of
specialized organizational capabilities

47
00:02:37.890 --> 00:02:42.410
for delivering value to customers
in the form of goods or services.

48
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:47.040
Now I know that I just rattled off two
descriptions, two definitions to you.

49
00:02:47.040 --> 00:02:50.440
And now that's made me
look like a bit of a nerd.

50
00:02:50.440 --> 00:02:54.270
[LAUGH] I'm fully aware of that, okay.

51
00:02:54.270 --> 00:03:00.160
And we also looked at the concept of
value being broken down into utility and

52
00:03:00.160 --> 00:03:01.290
warranty and

53
00:03:01.290 --> 00:03:06.570
the fact that it's not just about us
being able to do what it says on the can.

54
00:03:06.570 --> 00:03:09.970
We've gotta be able to send and receive
email but we've gotta do it in a way that

55
00:03:09.970 --> 00:03:15.610
we can assure our customers of
levels of utility and warranty and

56
00:03:15.610 --> 00:03:20.620
availability and capacity and
service continuity and security.

57
00:03:20.620 --> 00:03:23.550
So we're gonna need both that utility and

58
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:27.320
warranty to be present in order for
them to perceive value.

59
00:03:27.320 --> 00:03:32.010
And so in this particular section we're
gonna start off just by going over

60
00:03:32.010 --> 00:03:33.860
what our service assets were.

61
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:39.820
I mentioned them very,
very briefly in the last section about

62
00:03:39.820 --> 00:03:44.390
tangible and our intangible assets and
how we use those to deliver our services.

63
00:03:45.572 --> 00:03:48.220
>> All right, so
let's go ahead and begin, then.

64
00:03:48.220 --> 00:03:50.440
So where are we picking up from there?

65
00:03:50.440 --> 00:03:54.230
>> So as I said,
we begin with our service assets and

66
00:03:54.230 --> 00:03:59.680
our assets are what we use
within our organization to

67
00:03:59.680 --> 00:04:04.098
deliver value by way of goods or
services, as we say.

68
00:04:04.098 --> 00:04:07.135
And an asset is described there,
you've got some definitions there.

69
00:04:07.135 --> 00:04:10.540
An asset is defined as a resource or
a capability.

70
00:04:10.540 --> 00:04:13.540
And a resource is what we
consider to be a tangible asset,

71
00:04:13.540 --> 00:04:16.250
something that you touch and feel.

72
00:04:16.250 --> 00:04:20.780
Such as, as mentioned there,
money, our infrastructure itself,

73
00:04:20.780 --> 00:04:25.960
the software that we have, the actual
data that we have, our hardware.

74
00:04:25.960 --> 00:04:27.650
These are tangible assets.

75
00:04:27.650 --> 00:04:32.750
You'll notice that people span
both capabilities and resources.

76
00:04:32.750 --> 00:04:36.030
So then our tangible assets,
something that you can touch and feel.

77
00:04:36.030 --> 00:04:38.620
But I gave you that warning
in that first section.

78
00:04:38.620 --> 00:04:40.310
Don't you do that too much.

79
00:04:40.310 --> 00:04:45.000
And then [LAUGH] and
people are also intangible assets.

80
00:04:45.000 --> 00:04:48.150
And you know what,
under the intangible assets,

81
00:04:48.150 --> 00:04:51.450
soft assets as they mention
there our capabilities.

82
00:04:51.450 --> 00:04:55.240
We've got things like how we're managed,
who manages us?

83
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:58.900
We've got the organization itself,
how well organized we are.

84
00:04:58.900 --> 00:05:02.750
If there's complete chaos going on then
we're never gonna be able to deliver value

85
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:03.800
to our customers, are we?

86
00:05:03.800 --> 00:05:07.820
Our processes have to be efficient and
effective.

87
00:05:07.820 --> 00:05:10.710
And if our processes don't do
what they're supposed to do and

88
00:05:10.710 --> 00:05:13.450
they're not efficient and
they're not effective, then you know what?

89
00:05:13.450 --> 00:05:18.260
They're not going to deliver value
to our business, to our users and

90
00:05:18.260 --> 00:05:19.735
then our knowledge.

91
00:05:19.735 --> 00:05:24.160
And, that underneath people,
we've got experience and skills, too.

92
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:27.931
And knowledge can be quantified.

93
00:05:27.931 --> 00:05:30.175
We should document our knowledge.

94
00:05:30.175 --> 00:05:34.105
And then it becomes information that we
can put into our knowledge management

95
00:05:34.105 --> 00:05:39.085
system, so a knowledge though is
also our experience and our skills.

96
00:05:39.085 --> 00:05:41.325
And believe it or not, our attitude and

97
00:05:41.325 --> 00:05:45.027
attitude fall under these soft assets,
the capabilities.

98
00:05:45.027 --> 00:05:48.855
Like morale,
I expect to see morale in there as well,

99
00:05:48.855 --> 00:05:53.619
which is why as we've moved through
the service operation class,

100
00:05:53.619 --> 00:05:59.339
you'll see that we put a huge emphasis on
people and on morale and on attitudes.

101
00:05:59.339 --> 00:06:03.307
And on understanding sort of
organizational change management and

102
00:06:03.307 --> 00:06:07.832
the people aspect because our people
are what's going to enable us to deliver

103
00:06:07.832 --> 00:06:12.740
value, but they're also what's going to
hinder us from delivering value, too.

104
00:06:12.740 --> 00:06:14.480
Look at our soft skills,

105
00:06:14.480 --> 00:06:19.560
look at our capabilities there and
how well we are organized.

106
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:24.190
Well, that is, worst it might be,
you might consider it to be

107
00:06:24.190 --> 00:06:27.570
driven by management cuz management
set our organizational structures.

108
00:06:27.570 --> 00:06:29.538
But it's also driven by people,

109
00:06:29.538 --> 00:06:33.950
too as to how collaborative they
are within that organizational.

110
00:06:33.950 --> 00:06:35.620
And think about management.

111
00:06:37.040 --> 00:06:38.240
I know I asked you.

112
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:40.680
I put you on the spot last time,
didn't I, Ronnie?

113
00:06:40.680 --> 00:06:43.820
I said to you do you get on with
your managers all the time?

114
00:06:43.820 --> 00:06:47.080
And the simple fact of the matter
is there are always going

115
00:06:47.080 --> 00:06:48.482

the life cycle phases within ITIL,

347
00:21:21.130 --> 00:21:26.220
you'll see that there were 20
odd processes, well that's

348
00:21:26.220 --> 00:21:30.210
service owner does not take accountability
for all of those processes, okay?

349
00:21:30.210 --> 00:21:33.620
And that service owner takes
accountability of the service and

350
00:21:33.620 --> 00:21:36.220
that diagram in the bottom
right hand corner there,

351
00:21:36.220 --> 00:21:42.420
you will see that each process
applies to each service.

352
00:21:42.420 --> 00:21:46.200
So if we looked at process 1 and
we said that that was incident management,

353
00:21:46.200 --> 00:21:49.780
well incident management applies
to every single service.

354
00:21:49.780 --> 00:21:52.710
And problem management applies
to every single service.

355
00:21:52.710 --> 00:21:55.980
Then request fulfillment applies
to every single service.

356
00:21:55.980 --> 00:22:00.800
But you will notice that each
service is separate, and

357
00:22:00.800 --> 00:22:06.160
so each service or each silo lies it
is there will have a service owner and

358
00:22:06.160 --> 00:22:10.230
we use that word accountable again and
we use the word ensure.

359
00:22:10.230 --> 00:22:14.390
Okay, they ensure that value is delivered

360
00:22:14.390 --> 00:22:19.350
to the organization, so
they'll liaise with the process owners but

361
00:22:19.350 --> 00:22:21.930
they liaise with business
relationship management.

362
00:22:21.930 --> 00:22:26.000
They will liaise with our organization.

363
00:22:26.000 --> 00:22:29.440
And they will be present in
our service review meetings,

364
00:22:29.440 --> 00:22:33.580
which is where we review performance
against those service level targets,

365
00:22:33.580 --> 00:22:38.370
in service level management and
with our customer as well.

366
00:22:38.370 --> 00:22:41.170
So, I expect the service owner
to be present with that.

367
00:22:41.170 --> 00:22:45.510
Ultimately the service owner takes
accountability for a service.

368
00:22:47.080 --> 00:22:49.170
So, in this particular section here, then,

369
00:22:49.170 --> 00:22:53.490
well in the last two sections we've
done a very, very brief overview.

370
00:22:53.490 --> 00:22:59.199
Of some of the fundamentals that we
learned within our IT foundation class.

371
00:23:00.380 --> 00:23:04.300
Now, I do understand that
there is a lot to learn there,

372
00:23:04.300 --> 00:23:08.780
so please feel free to browse
further the IT foundation

373
00:23:08.780 --> 00:23:13.300
material that is available
here through ITPRO.TV.

374
00:23:13.300 --> 00:23:17.820
But, what I would ask you to do know
is obviously to move in to your service

375
00:23:17.820 --> 00:23:23.610
operation material and to take a look
at our other service operation modules.

376
00:23:23.610 --> 00:23:27.550
Alright, Jo, well thank you again for
helping us out and reminding us of some of

377
00:23:27.550 --> 00:23:32.090
those foundational concepts that we may
be a little bit weak on, but now with

378
00:23:32.090 --> 00:23:37.440
this refresher, it means we're ready
to head on to our ITIL intermedia show.

379
00:23:37.440 --> 00:23:39.520
Well, great place for us to sign off then.

380
00:23:39.520 --> 00:23:42.480
For IT pro TV, I'm your host Ronny Wong.

381
00:23:42.480 --> 00:23:43.680
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

382
00:23:43.680 --> 00:23:48.382
>> Stay turned now for
your ITIL intermedia introduction.

383
00:23:48.382 --> 00:23:54.442
[MUSIC]

384
00:23:54.442 --> 00:23:57.451
>> Thank you for watching itpro.tv.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the objectives and scope of CSI.  Jo makes sure that we understand the objective of CSI is to allow the organization to constantly see and improve all service lifecycles for the business.  She also discusses the business values of CSI to the business.
episodes.title: CSI Scope and Objectives
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.247
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.247 --> 00:00:05.303
I'm your host, Don Pezet, coming to you
live from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:05.303 --> 00:00:06.319
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.319 --> 00:00:07.982
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.982 --> 00:00:11.907
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.907 --> 00:00:15.881
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.881 --> 00:00:20.830
You're watching the ITIL Intermediate
Continual Service Improvement show.

8
00:00:20.830 --> 00:00:22.710
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:22.710 --> 00:00:26.720
And today, we're gonna be jumping into,
well, some of the objectives and scope.

10
00:00:26.720 --> 00:00:30.999
Now you've already watched
the introduction to, of course, the show.

11
00:00:30.999 --> 00:00:34.616
And you've also, of course,
gone through the course refresher or

12
00:00:34.616 --> 00:00:37.380
the foundations refresher, I should say.

13
00:00:37.380 --> 00:00:40.602
And that means we are ready to jump
into continual service improvement.

14
00:00:40.602 --> 00:00:44.193
And here to help us once
again is going to be,

15
00:00:44.193 --> 00:00:48.380
well, the ITIL wizard herself,
Miss Jo Peacock.

16
00:00:48.380 --> 00:00:50.070
Jo, welcome back to the show.

17
00:00:50.070 --> 00:00:51.578
>> Thank you very much for
having me, Ronnie.

18
00:00:51.578 --> 00:00:53.870
At least I didn't get called
Dumbledore this time.

19
00:00:53.870 --> 00:00:56.960
>> Well, not Dumbledore this time,
but it may happen again.

20
00:00:56.960 --> 00:01:00.808
>> But Jo, as we begin,
as we start taking a look at this idea

21
00:01:00.808 --> 00:01:05.479
of continual service improvement,
this sounds almost intuitive.

22
00:01:05.479 --> 00:01:09.140
Like it's something that we
should just be able to do.

23
00:01:09.140 --> 00:01:12.460
But I'm assuming since we're
actually doing a whole show on it,

24
00:01:12.460 --> 00:01:15.710
it's not as intuitive as
I think it's gonna be.

25
00:01:15.710 --> 00:01:18.029
>> Well, it is kind of intuitive.

26
00:01:19.210 --> 00:01:23.400
But it's one of those things that
we really don't invest the time and

27
00:01:23.400 --> 00:01:26.928
invest the effort and
invest the money into.

28
00:01:26.928 --> 00:01:30.687
And so, whilst it is kind of intuitive,
at the same time, it's so

29
00:01:30.687 --> 00:01:35.125
obvious the organizations that undertake
continual service improvement and

30
00:01:35.125 --> 00:01:39.495
the organizations that don't undertake
continual service improvement.

31
00:01:39.495 --> 00:01:43.240
So, please, you were gonna say something?

32
00:01:43.240 --> 00:01:46.620
>> No, I was just gonna say that actually
makes sense a lot of times, right?

33
00:01:46.620 --> 00:01:50.521
The very fact that organizations just
think that it's gonna happen naturally

34
00:01:50.521 --> 00:01:52.364
that they don't really plan for it.

35
00:01:52.364 --> 00:01:55.320
They don't expect anything
like that to end up happening.

36
00:01:55.320 --> 00:01:58.500
And they just think it's going
to somehow just, I guess,

37
00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:02.190
exude from their particular processes
that they're already working.

38
00:02:02.190 --> 00:02:03.420
So without planning for

39
00:02:03.420 --> 00:02:06.820
it, then if it doesn't happen,
they don't know where to go.

40
00:02:06.820 --> 00:02:09.427
So what I was gonna say is I believe
that that's why we're doing this show

41
00:02:09.427 --> 00:02:10.012
then, right?

42
00:02:10.012 --> 00:02:13.363
>> Yeah, as I said, you've already seen.

43
00:02:13.363 --> 00:02:17.953
You can see in the real world
organizations that believe in CSI and

44
00:02:17.953 --> 00:02:21.052
actually undertake CSI on a regular basis.

45
00:02:21.052 --> 00:02:24.349
That's why we call it continual and
not continuous.

46
00:02:24.349 --> 00:02:29.106
And we looked at the difference between
continual versus continuous when we

47
00:02:29.106 --> 00:02:31.420
looked at a recap of our foundation.

48
00:02:31.420 --> 00:02:34.152
And those organizations that don't,

49
00:02:34.152 --> 00:02:38.920
the organizations that stay
behind the curve all the time.

50
00:02:38.920 --> 00:02:41.040
If you think about your
cell phone provider.

51
00:02:41.040 --> 00:02:42.970
Your cell phone provider,

52
00:02:42.970 --> 00:02:47.590
for the most part, will engage in
continual service improvement.

53
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:50.370
We see that because every year,
just about now,

54
00:02:50.370 --> 00:02:53.680
it feels like, every year,
we get a new model.

55
00:02:53.680 --> 00:02:55.570
It might be even more
frequently than that.

56
00:02:55.570 --> 00:02:58.110
That's continual service improvement.

57
00:02:58.110 --> 00:03:02.056
That it's continually seeking
to align themselves with their

58
00:03:02.056 --> 00:03:03.848
customers' requirement.

59
00:03:03.848 --> 00:03:05.751
Now, sure, it's driven by market forces.

60
00:03:05.751 --> 00:03:10.180
It's driven by the fact that
competitors will do something.

61
00:03:10.180 --> 00:03:11.820
But look at the organizations,

62
00:03:11.820 --> 00:03:16.010
the phone companies that don't engage
in continual service improvement.

63
00:03:16.010 --> 00:03:20.445
The companies that have actually
not kept up with market forces.

64
00:03:20.445 --> 00:03:25.654
And the companies that have relied
solely on one core product.

65
00:03:25.654 --> 00:03:31.090
And you'll find that that core product
eventually, well, it becomes outdated.

66
00:03:31.090 --> 00:03:36.500
In the foundation recap,
we looked at the concept of value and

67
00:03:36.500 --> 00:03:39.710
the fact that value diminishes over time.

68
00:03:39.710 --> 00:03:43.010
And it doesn't matter in
what environment we're in.

69
00:03:43.010 --> 00:03:47.795
Whether we're in IT, or if we're
going grocery shopping, for instance,

70
00:03:47.795 --> 00:03:51.179
you get bored with the same thing over and
over again.

71
00:03:51.179 --> 00:03:53.060
And you want change.

72
00:03:53.060 --> 00:03:54.770
And change is natural.

73
00:03:54.770 --> 00:03:56.325
And value does diminish over time.

74
00:03:57.430 --> 00:04:02.237
Ten years ago now,
a very large company launched their first

75
00:04:02.237 --> 00:04:06.868
touchscreen telephone with
a graphical interface on it.

76
00:04:06.868 --> 00:04:11.302
And it was the best thing in the world and
everybody wanted one.

77
00:04:11.302 --> 00:04:15.663
Now I remember, or if you remember
when we talked in foundation recap,

78
00:04:15.663 --> 00:04:18.590
we looked at the concept of a service.

79
00:04:18.590 --> 00:04:22.340
And a service is a means of delivering
value by facilitating outcomes.

80
00:04:23.660 --> 00:04:28.600
So the outcome that we facilitate with
a cell phone is the ability to make a call

81
00:04:28.600 --> 00:04:31.700
and receive a call, and
send a text and receive a text.

82
00:04:32.800 --> 00:04:36.800
So that phone ten years
ago met those needs.

83
00:04:36.800 --> 00:04:39.240
Yeah, it facilitated that outcome.

84
00:04:39.240 --> 00:04:43.104
But if I were to give you that
exact cell phone right now,

85
00:04:43.104 --> 00:04:45.087
how would you feel about it?

86
00:04:45.087 --> 00:04:47.880
>> I would probably feel
it's fairly antiquated.

87
00:04:47.880 --> 00:04:53.000
That it does make a phone call, but
it's not what I would expect from a phone.

88
00:04:53.000 --> 00:04:55.470
>> Right, so values diminished over time.

89
00:04:55.470 --> 00:04:58.770
And yet,
that outcome is still facilitated.

90
00:04:58.770 --> 00:05:01.250
It's still doing exactly
what it's supposed to do.

91
00:05:01.250 --> 00:05:03.610
It's still making and
receiving phone calls.

92
00:05:03.610 --> 00:05:07.690
And it still has the same functionality
that it did ten years ago.

93
00:05:07.690 --> 00:05:11.609
But you don't perceive the same
amount of value in it.

94
00:05:11.609 --> 00:05:15.924
And so a company that doesn't engage in
continual service improvement will end up

95
00:05:15.924 --> 00:05:17.810
with that cell phone for ten years.

96
00:05:18.960 --> 00:05:20.400
And will end up losing customers.

97
00:05:20.400 --> 00:05:22.643
And will end up losing profit and

98
00:05:22.643 --> 00:05:28.473
losing revenue because of the fact that
they don't recognize that value changes.

99
00:05:28.473 --> 00:05:32.365
And so the purpose of
continual service improvement,

100
00:05:32.365 --> 00:05:37.537
as we see actually in this slide here
that's coming up on the screen now.

101
00:05:37.537 --> 00:05:41.001
In the bottom blue box there,
the purpose of CSI is

102
00:05:41.001 --> 00:05:45.622
to align services with changing
business needs by identifying and

103
00:05:45.622 --> 00:05:51.170
implementing improvements to services
that support the business processes.

104
00:05:52.300 --> 00:05:56.080
So we talk about cell phones and
we talk about facilitating that outcome

105
00:05:56.080 --> 00:05:59.830
of the ability just to make and
receive a phone call.

106
00:05:59.830 --> 00:06:04.127
Well, consider that to be a business need,
if you will, for a moment.

107
00:06:04.127 --> 00:06:06.950
You're a customer, it's your need.

108
00:06:06.950 --> 00:06:08.840
Those business needs change.

109
00:06:08.840 --> 00:06:10.490
Your needs change.

110
00:06:10.490 --> 00:06:15.762
And no longer do you just wanna be
able to make and receive a phone call.

111
00:06:15.762 --> 00:06:18.240
Now, you wanna be able to send and
receive emails.

112
00:06:18.240 --> 00:06:21.370
You want to be able to send and
receive texts.

113
00:06:21.370 --> 00:06:23.280
You probably wanna do video calling.

114
00:06:23.280 --> 00:06:25.970
Because, let's face it,
we all do nowadays.

115
00:06:25.970 --> 00:06:28.220
You probably wanna be able to play games,
don't you?

116
00:06:28.220 --> 00:06:28.840
>> Right.

117
00:06:28.840 --> 00:06:32.910
>> Right, and so
those things were not possible.

118
00:06:32.910 --> 00:06:36.506
Well, okay, there were some
games around ten years ago, but

119
00:06:36.506 --> 00:06:38.179
they were very simplistic.

120
00:06:38.179 --> 00:06:40.916
And now we've got things
like augmented reality.

121
00:06:40.916 --> 00:06:45.765
And we have all sorts of
possibilities with our phone handsets

122
00:06:45.765 --> 00:06:48.850
now that we didn't have ten years ago.

123
00:06:49.860 --> 00:06:54.440
And that's because we're continually
aligning ourselves to the needs of

124
00:06:54.440 --> 00:06:55.464
the customers.

125
00:06:55.464 --> 00:06:58.429
And a company that is very good at CSI,

126
00:06:58.429 --> 00:07:04.005
that is very proactive at CSI is
the organization that's profitable.

127
00:07:04.005 --> 00:07:06.263
Because they're understanding
their customers.

128
00:07:06.263 --> 00:07:08.545
They're understanding their business.

129
00:07:08.545 --> 00:07:12.815
And they don't have to wait for
the business to come to them and

130
00:07:12.815 --> 00:07:14.495
ask them for something.

131
00:07:14.495 --> 00:07:18.085
Imagine, if you had to go to
your cell phone provider and

132
00:07:18.085 --> 00:07:21.775
tell your cell phone provider, actually,
in the next version of the phone,

133
00:07:21.775 --> 00:07:23.825
I'd like to see this and this and this.

134
00:07:25.090 --> 00:07:27.800
I don't know about you, but
I don't have the time for that.

135
00:07:27.800 --> 00:07:28.770
>> Right.

136
00:07:28.770 --> 00:07:30.145
>> As far as I'm concerned,

137
00:07:30.145 --> 00:07:33.462
I'm gonna wait until something
that catches my eye comes out.

138
00:07:33.462 --> 00:07:36.400
And then I'm gonna say,
hey, I really want that.

139
00:07:36.400 --> 00:07:42.580
And quite often, I don't really perceive
a need until I've seen it advertised.

140
00:07:42.580 --> 00:07:44.940
And then, all of a sudden, I need it.

141
00:07:44.940 --> 00:07:47.487
And I had that with a bit
of wearable technology

142
00:07:47.487 --> 00:07:49.849
that I didn't really have a need for this.

143
00:07:49.849 --> 00:07:52.294
And then, all of a sudden,
I saw it advertised.

144
00:07:52.294 --> 00:07:54.602
And, wow, did I have a need for that.

145
00:07:54.602 --> 00:07:59.573
There was suddenly a hole in my life that
I couldn't fill without that piece of

146
00:07:59.573 --> 00:08:00.498
technology.

147
00:08:00.498 --> 00:08:01.557
>> Right.

148
00:08:01.557 --> 00:08:03.347
And so that's what CSI is about.

149
00:08:03.347 --> 00:08:06.213
And so as you can imagine CSI works very,

150
00:08:06.213 --> 00:08:11.189
very closely with business relationship
management to make sure that

151
00:08:11.189 --> 00:08:16.350
we're recommending ideas for
our services to our organization.

152
00:08:16.350 --> 00:08:18.080
But CSI also works very,

153
00:08:18.080 --> 00:08:22.060
very closely with all of the other
processes and all of our services

154
00:08:22.060 --> 00:08:25.850
to make sure that those processes stay
aligned with the needs of the business.

155
00:08:27.060 --> 00:08:29.090
>> All right Jo now, I was just thinking,

156
00:08:29.090 --> 00:08:31.910
and correct me if I'm wrong
because I may be wrong on this.

157
00:08:31.910 --> 00:08:35.930
It sounds like that CSI does have a direct

158
00:08:35.930 --> 00:08:39.920
bearing at least on
that diminishing value.

159
00:08:39.920 --> 00:08:43.800
That if we can continue to
offer service improvement,

160
00:08:43.800 --> 00:08:45.980
then either the value
is less diminished or

161
00:08:45.980 --> 00:08:51.090
we change the value somehow to make our
business better or more profitable.

162
00:08:51.090 --> 00:08:53.310
Does that seem like what
the service can do for us or

163
00:08:53.310 --> 00:08:55.840
what continual service improvement does?

164
00:08:55.840 --> 00:08:59.310
>> Right, well we do have to,
you mentioned more profitable.

165
00:08:59.310 --> 00:09:03.090
We do have to take into consideration
the strategy of the organization, and

166
00:09:03.090 --> 00:09:05.000
sometimes it's not always about profit.

167
00:09:05.000 --> 00:09:07.610
If we're talking about government
agencies, for instance,

168
00:09:07.610 --> 00:09:09.460
then that's definitely not about profit.

169
00:09:09.460 --> 00:09:10.030
>> Right.

170
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:10.790
>> However,

171
00:09:10.790 --> 00:09:15.590
we do have to make sure that we're aligned
to the business which is why we say that.

172
00:09:15.590 --> 00:09:18.250
And it's not just about
the services either,

173
00:09:18.250 --> 00:09:22.190
so let's think about the fact that,
incident management for instance.

174
00:09:22.190 --> 00:09:26.470
Can you imagine if you
called up a help line now,

175
00:09:26.470 --> 00:09:29.370
a service desk of any type,
and you called them.

176
00:09:29.370 --> 00:09:33.440
And they said hang on a moment,
I just need to write all of this down, and

177
00:09:33.440 --> 00:09:36.580
they wrote down all of your
details on a piece of paper.

178
00:09:37.940 --> 00:09:40.890
How confident would you feel in the level
of service you were going to get

179
00:09:40.890 --> 00:09:42.870
from them?

180
00:09:42.870 --> 00:09:45.950
>> If they had to take all the time to
do that, I don't know if I'd feel very

181
00:09:45.950 --> 00:09:49.200
confident at all, if they couldn't
actually know what was going on.

182
00:09:49.200 --> 00:09:51.860
>> Right, and
then they don't take all of your details,

183
00:09:51.860 --> 00:09:53.300
cuz they want to log it and track it.

184
00:09:53.300 --> 00:09:56.090
They take all of your details
cuz it's on a piece of paper.

185
00:09:56.090 --> 00:09:57.310
And then at that point in time,

186
00:09:57.310 --> 00:10:00.470
you're wondering well what's going
to happen when I put the phone down?

187
00:10:00.470 --> 00:10:02.220
>> Right.
>> How do I know this is going to be

188
00:10:02.220 --> 00:10:03.560
followed through?

189
00:10:03.560 --> 00:10:07.960
And that's because quite
simply we expect that now.

190
00:10:07.960 --> 00:10:11.610
We're customers,
we expect that particular level.

191
00:10:11.610 --> 00:10:18.100
So we expect those processes to be,
or to utilize IT tools.

192
00:10:18.100 --> 00:10:23.700
We don't expect anyone in IT to
be using pieces of paper now.

193
