as well as the scope of CSI, and

425
00:24:57.640 --> 00:24:59.400
even those business values.

426
00:24:59.400 --> 00:25:04.280
Understanding the whole goal behind of
course CSI is that continual improvement.

427
00:25:04.280 --> 00:25:08.460
And Jo emphasized the ideas here of small,
gradual but

428
00:25:08.460 --> 00:25:13.340
always continual types of improvements
that we'd like to actually make with CSI.

429
00:25:13.340 --> 00:25:15.970
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

430
00:25:15.970 --> 00:25:20.200
Signing off for
ITProTV I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

431
00:25:20.200 --> 00:25:21.360
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

432
00:25:21.360 --> 00:25:25.762
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

433
00:25:25.762 --> 00:25:31.923
[MUSIC]

434
00:25:31.923 --> 00:25:34.861
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the CSI Approach.  Jo discusses that the approach helps to set short term improvements and thereby help to also set long term CSI goals as well.  She also takes some time to review the service lifecycles that CSI will be a part.
episodes.title: CSI Scope and Objectives Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:05.423
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:05.423 --> 00:00:07.741
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.741 --> 00:00:11.343
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:11.343 --> 00:00:14.520
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro TV.

5
00:00:14.520 --> 00:00:19.860
You're watching the ITIL Intermediate
Continual Service Improvement show.

6
00:00:19.860 --> 00:00:23.890
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and
we are continuing with a part two here

7
00:00:23.890 --> 00:00:27.300
on the scope and
the objective, right, for CSI.

8
00:00:27.300 --> 00:00:32.500
And here to help us out and
to help fulfill this particular area

9
00:00:32.500 --> 00:00:38.690
is gonna be our sage and master ITIL
specialist for us here is Ms. Jo P Cotton.

10
00:00:38.690 --> 00:00:39.990
Jo, welcome to the show.

11
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:43.280
>> Thank you very much Ronnie, you're
gonna run out of names for me very soon.

12
00:00:43.280 --> 00:00:44.640
>> It can happen, but

13
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:47.928
the great thing is I have a whole
thesaurus that I can pull from.

14
00:00:47.928 --> 00:00:51.376
>> [LAUGH]
>> So Jo, last time we took a look just

15
00:00:51.376 --> 00:00:54.704
really at the beginning of
the introduction of these scopes and

16
00:00:54.704 --> 00:00:56.150
these objectives.

17
00:00:56.150 --> 00:00:58.670
Where are we going to
pick up from right now?

18
00:00:58.670 --> 00:01:01.300
>> Well, we're going to carry
on with where we left off in

19
00:01:01.300 --> 00:01:04.520
part one where we took
a look at the objectives.

20
00:01:04.520 --> 00:01:09.565
We took a look at the scope and as I
mentioned in part one, we're now gonna

21
00:01:09.565 --> 00:01:14.964
start off by just looking very quickly,
very high level at the CSI approach.

22
00:01:14.964 --> 00:01:18.744
And then we're going to look at
the other life cycle processes and

23
00:01:18.744 --> 00:01:23.930
the life cycles themselves and how CSI
fits into each of those life cycle phases.

24
00:01:23.930 --> 00:01:27.340
>> Sounds good Jo,
let's go ahead and get started then.

25
00:01:27.340 --> 00:01:31.280
>> Okay, well let's take a look at this
first slide then that we have in this set.

26
00:01:31.280 --> 00:01:34.050
And you can see that we
have here the CSI approach.

27
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:39.560
And the CSI approach Is a very,
very, very high level, but

28
00:01:39.560 --> 00:01:44.550
iterative, repeatable method of
continual service improvement.

29
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:48.450
Now, I know that we've mentioned in
previous classes, and certainly in our

30
00:01:48.450 --> 00:01:54.820
foundation recap, the difference
between continuous and continual.

31
00:01:54.820 --> 00:01:59.900
Continual, being an iterative,
repeatable process,

32
00:01:59.900 --> 00:02:04.010
whereas continuous means ongoing,
never stopping.

33
00:02:04.010 --> 00:02:09.460
And so the reason that we have
continual service improvement or CSI,

34
00:02:09.460 --> 00:02:14.250
and so to be fair, in future classes,
we're just gonna refer to this as CSI.

35
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:17.660
And that's what IteITIL does,
we just refer refer to it as CSI.

36
00:02:17.660 --> 00:02:22.729
And the reason that we have continual
service improvement, is because with

37
00:02:22.729 --> 00:02:28.220
every single improvement, we can
check that we've made an improvement.

38
00:02:28.220 --> 00:02:33.030
And that's key to being able to
deliver value to the organization

39
00:02:33.030 --> 00:02:36.250
is actually having that
visibility of that value.

40
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:41.470
So let's take a look then very,
very briefly at this high level approach.

41
00:02:41.470 --> 00:02:46.190
Every single improvement initiative
has to be done in a continual way.

42
00:02:47.200 --> 00:02:49.400
It has to be done in an iterative way and

43
00:02:49.400 --> 00:02:53.700
we start off right to the very top
with understanding the vision for

44
00:02:53.700 --> 00:02:57.810
the organization and understanding
the vision for the IT organization.

45
00:02:59.160 --> 00:03:04.820
And those two visions should be aligned,
after all that's the purpose of ITIL.

46
00:03:04.820 --> 00:03:07.110
So the vision of the organization.

47
00:03:07.110 --> 00:03:09.700
Let's say for instance,
I want to go over there.

48
00:03:09.700 --> 00:03:12.910
That's where I want to go so
I'm heading in that direction.

49
00:03:12.910 --> 00:03:16.344
That's as much as I need to
know in terms of vision is that

50
00:03:16.344 --> 00:03:21.328
I'm heading in that direction over there
and I should know where my endpoint is.

51
00:03:21.328 --> 00:03:25.620
Then I look at where I am right now,
and I'm here.

52
00:03:25.620 --> 00:03:26.500
Here I am.

53
00:03:26.500 --> 00:03:28.430
Yeah I'm stood right here.

54
00:03:28.430 --> 00:03:31.340
So let's think about where I want to be.

55
00:03:31.340 --> 00:03:35.360
Now this is the point in time where
we will tell you that you planned for

56
00:03:35.360 --> 00:03:41.720
your short term visible
improvements in detail.

57
00:03:41.720 --> 00:03:46.810
Your long term goal, you don't
plan in detail, because your long

58
00:03:46.810 --> 00:03:52.750
term goal is going to be dependent
on your short term improvement.

59
00:03:52.750 --> 00:03:55.190
And with each iterative improvement,

60
00:03:55.190 --> 00:03:59.540
that next improvement is going
to be dependent on the first.

61
00:03:59.540 --> 00:04:01.290
So let's say that I was walking.

62
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:06.570
And if I look at where I want to be,
I'll say well, I want to be over there.

63
00:04:06.570 --> 00:04:09.504
So I'm going to head in this direction.

64
00:04:09.504 --> 00:04:13.652
And I'll incorporate the how do I
get there, I'm going to walk, well,

65
00:04:13.652 --> 00:04:15.830
okay, I'm gonna take my first step.

66
00:04:15.830 --> 00:04:20.360
And that first step i'm going to plan in
detail under that where do I want to be.

67
00:04:21.550 --> 00:04:26.190
But I'm not gonna plan the following steps
in any great detail because that first

68
00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:30.340
step might be different
to what I expected.

69
00:04:30.340 --> 00:04:32.020
So this is my first step.

70
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:32.880
How do I get there?

71
00:04:32.880 --> 00:04:33.970
I'm gonna take a step.

72
00:04:35.360 --> 00:04:38.970
And then I'm going to say okay
well did I get there yes or no?

73
00:04:38.970 --> 00:04:42.730
Well I'm going to look at where I am
now and I'm going to say yes I did.

74
00:04:42.730 --> 00:04:44.690
Okay so what's next.

75
00:04:44.690 --> 00:04:47.290
Well what's next is I take my next step.

76
00:04:47.290 --> 00:04:50.350
But of course you see in order
to take my next step I have

77
00:04:50.350 --> 00:04:53.070
to look at where I am right now.

78
00:04:53.070 --> 00:04:58.050
Well the reason why we don't plan our next
steps in any great detail until we've made

79
00:04:58.050 --> 00:05:00.910
that first step is very, very simple.

80
00:05:00.910 --> 00:05:04.480
Is that we didn't know just how
long that first step would take.

81
00:05:05.640 --> 00:05:10.690
So we plan for
our short term goals in great detail.

82
00:05:10.690 --> 00:05:14.480
But our long term vision
we plan in high level.

83
00:05:15.520 --> 00:05:17.400
So where do I wanna be?

84
00:05:17.400 --> 00:05:20.140
I want to be here so
I'm gonna take that step.

85
00:05:20.140 --> 00:05:21.790
And I'm gonna say, didn't I get there.

86
00:05:21.790 --> 00:05:23.820
Okay so what's next?

87
00:05:23.820 --> 00:05:26.430
How do I keep the momentum going,
what's next?

88
00:05:26.430 --> 00:05:29.140
Well, the first thing that I'm
gonna do is check my vision.

89
00:05:29.140 --> 00:05:31.730
Because, you see,
I might have changed direction.

90
00:05:31.730 --> 00:05:33.390
And where I thought that, yeah,

91
00:05:33.390 --> 00:05:36.940
I was heading in that direction
now the organization's changed.

92
00:05:36.940 --> 00:05:39.110
And now we're headed in that direction.

93
00:05:39.110 --> 00:05:41.710
So immediately I'm gonna have to change.

94
00:05:41.710 --> 00:05:42.720
And that's okay.

95
00:05:42.720 --> 00:05:45.730
Because as long as I know where I am,
I can make that change.

96
00:05:46.940 --> 00:05:51.330
So our next slide just simply
goes over that CSI approach, and

97
00:05:51.330 --> 00:05:52.930
just looks at, you know,

98
00:05:52.930 --> 00:05:57.740
our alignment to our vision, that's where
I want to be, then, where am I right now?

99
00:05:58.860 --> 00:06:05.406
Well, exactly where do I want to be,
these are my details targets.

100
00:06:05.406 --> 00:06:06.412
How do I get there?

101
00:06:06.412 --> 00:06:07.980
That's my plan.

102
00:06:07.980 --> 00:06:11.580
And then once I've made that improvement,
once I've taken that step,

103
00:06:11.580 --> 00:06:14.400
then well did I achieve
what I wanted to achieve?

104
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:18.530
Did I get there, then I take my
measurement from here to here.

105
00:06:18.530 --> 00:06:20.270
And I said okay, that's great.

106
00:06:20.270 --> 00:06:22.710
Now I embed that change.

107
00:06:22.710 --> 00:06:27.080
I recognize that this is now my new
baseline and I embed that change.

108
00:06:27.080 --> 00:06:29.098
And then I move on, okay?

109
00:06:29.098 --> 00:06:33.580
And that's my next improvement and
again I check my vision.

110
00:06:33.580 --> 00:06:36.840
I realign my vision to make sure
I'm headed in the right direction.

111
00:06:38.010 --> 00:06:41.810
So let's look at those
steps in greater detail,

112
00:06:41.810 --> 00:06:43.640
starting off with our baseline, okay?

113
00:06:43.640 --> 00:06:49.300
So we understand our vision, and now we
want to look at where are we right now.

114
00:06:49.300 --> 00:06:54.260
So our baseline, now our CSI manager's
gonna help us with our baseline if we're

115
00:06:54.260 --> 00:06:58.890
improving processes, then our process
owner's gonna help us with our baseline.

116
00:06:58.890 --> 00:07:00.450
And our baseline can incorporate,

117
00:07:00.450 --> 00:07:04.890
if we look in the middle here,
it can incorporate things like security.

118
00:07:04.890 --> 00:07:06.760
It could be security baseline.

119
00:07:06.760 --> 00:07:12.108
It could incorporate teams like
strategy and finance, and data center.

120
00:07:12.108 --> 00:07:15.690
They're all going to help
us identify our baseline.

121
00:07:15.690 --> 00:07:16.810
Where do I want to be?

122
00:07:17.830 --> 00:07:21.145
And our baseline will be completely
dependent on the type of improvement that

123
00:07:21.145 --> 00:07:22.270
we want to make, as well.

124
00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:26.300
A baseline measurement
is just a measurement.

125
00:07:26.300 --> 00:07:30.490
And we already mentioned in numerous
sessions over the course of

126
00:07:30.490 --> 00:07:34.060
the ITIL intermediate classes that
you don't just take a baseline for

127
00:07:34.060 --> 00:07:36.430
the sake of taking the metric okay?

128
00:07:36.430 --> 00:07:39.360
Because we've got too many metrics in IT.

129
00:07:39.360 --> 00:07:45.059
So we've got to take a baseline that is
relevant to the improvement initiative.

130
00:07:46.690 --> 00:07:52.838
I can tell you now the engine
size of my car is six liter.

131
00:07:52.838 --> 00:07:55.050
There you go, that's the baseline right?

132
00:07:55.050 --> 00:07:59.398
It's a measurement it's a snapshot
of where I'm right now okay.

133
00:07:59.398 --> 00:08:04.112
But what I actually wanna do is put
a server in that room next door.

134
00:08:04.112 --> 00:08:06.390
Hm, so
how that's baseline going to help me?

135
00:08:06.390 --> 00:08:08.140
It's not, okay?

136
00:08:08.140 --> 00:08:11.640
So we don't just take measurements for
the sake of taking measurements.

137
00:08:11.640 --> 00:08:15.660
The baseline that we need to take
is the size of the room next door.

138
00:08:15.660 --> 00:08:17.650
It's the number of power outlets we have.

139
00:08:17.650 --> 00:08:22.850
It's the capacity for increasing the air
conditioning in that room next door.

140
00:08:22.850 --> 00:08:24.970
That's the baseline that we want to take.

141
00:08:25.980 --> 00:08:28.300
So baselines have to be relevant,

142
00:08:28.300 --> 00:08:33.085
just like every other metric
within IT it has to be relevant.

143
00:08:33.085 --> 00:08:36.880
So then we work out our short term plans
of exactly where do we want to be.

144
00:08:36.880 --> 00:08:41.172
And these will include our sponsors,
our executive sponsors,

145
00:08:41.172 --> 00:08:44.315
seniors management, CSI manager.

146
00:08:44.315 --> 00:08:51.755
We put a lot of importance on having
the buy in from senior management.

147
00:08:51.755 --> 00:08:56.160
Senior management should not just be
figureheads, senior management should be

148
00:08:57.410 --> 00:09:01.100
the people that drive any improvements and
initiatives.

149
00:09:01.100 --> 00:09:05.554
If you do not have the buy in, and
you don't have the visibility of senior

150
00:09:05.554 --> 00:09:09.290
management, then very,
very quickly, momentum is lost.

151
00:09:09.290 --> 00:09:13.040
And people will start drifting
back into old ways of working.

152
00:09:13.040 --> 00:09:16.833
So it's really important that we have
that reinforcement, that visibility, and

153
00:09:16.833 --> 00:09:18.521
that buy in for m senior management.

154
00:09:18.521 --> 00:09:22.916
And then when we do our project planning
and how do we get there, well we consider

155
00:09:22.916 --> 00:09:27.380
what our process owners want to see if
we're especially improving the process,

156
00:09:27.380 --> 00:09:29.620
we would look at our project manages.

157
00:09:29.620 --> 00:09:33.919
If it's a large improvement initiative,
we look at our CSI register,

158
00:09:33.919 --> 00:09:37.860
and we'll cover that in another
session in a lot more detail, but

159
00:09:37.860 --> 00:09:41.818
our CSI register is just a database
of improvement initiatives.

160
00:09:41.818 --> 00:09:47.127
Okay, so we'll look at exactly what we
want to achieve from that CSI register,

161
00:09:47.127 --> 00:09:51.964
and again we're gonna involve the CSI
manager and the process owners and

162
00:09:51.964 --> 00:09:53.170
those sponsors.

163
00:09:53.170 --> 00:09:56.539
And then that next arrow,
that arrow between number 3 and

164
00:09:56.539 --> 00:10:01.355
number 4 that's the longest arrow ever in
some instances because that's where we

165
00:10:01.355 --> 00:10:03.260
undertake the project.

166
00:10:03.260 --> 00:10:05.930
And so that could Take as
little as five minutes or

167
00:10:05.930 --> 00:10:10.330
it could take as long as six
months to a year to implement.

168
00:10:10.330 --> 00:10:14.550
And so when we get to number 4 then
we're looking at did we get there?

169
00:10:14.550 --> 00:10:15.938
And did we get there?

170
00:10:15.938 --> 00:10:19.728
Very similar to where we are right now,
we're doing exactly the same,

171
00:10:19.728 --> 00:10:23.590
we're taking that baseline so
that we can make a comparison.

172
00:10:23.590 --> 00:10:27.200
Only we'll also be looking at the KPIs and

173
00:10:27.200 --> 00:10:32.680
management report that we identified
in number two and where do want to be.

174
00:10:32.680 --> 00:10:37.340
And, we'll also look at the CSI register
to make sure that's it has been updated.

175
00:10:37.340 --> 00:10:42.570
And again, we want our CSI managers and
process managers, etc, involved in this.

176
00:10:44.880 --> 00:10:50.016
So if you remember from your
foundation recap that ITIL is,

177
00:10:50.016 --> 00:10:53.212
well, it's a set of publications.

178
00:10:53.212 --> 00:10:58.190
ITIL itself, it tells you what it
is here IT Infrastructure Library.

179
00:10:58.190 --> 00:11:00.370
It's a set of books okay?

180
00:11:00.370 --> 00:11:05.100
And so, in ITIL, we looked at
the concept of a life of a service and

181
00:11:05.100 --> 00:11:09.490
the lives of our services, and we start
out in strategy with our ideas and

182
00:11:09.490 --> 00:11:12.710
then that idea is approved
in the business case.

183
00:11:12.710 --> 00:11:16.312
And the approved business case
is given to a project team and

184
00:11:16.312 --> 00:11:18.256
in design we design that idea and

185
00:11:18.256 --> 00:11:23.170
then that service design package is
produced and handed to service transition.

186
00:11:23.170 --> 00:11:27.870
And at service transition we build and
we test.

187
00:11:27.870 --> 00:11:31.810
And we deploy that live service now and

188
00:11:31.810 --> 00:11:37.260
through early life support we actually
hand over that service to operations.

189
00:11:37.260 --> 00:11:39.558
And operations is where we
have the business as usual.

190
00:11:39.558 --> 00:11:43.170
And, of course CSI oversees
absolutely everything.

191
00:11:43.170 --> 00:11:46.796
And as I've said in a previous
session I like to think CSI

192
00:11:46.796 --> 00:11:50.210
having its tendrils in
absolutely everything.

193
00:11:50.210 --> 00:11:54.911
Because absolutely everything
can be improved everything.

194
00:11:54.911 --> 00:11:58.584
Think of CSI as that little voice
on your shoulder that says,

195
00:11:58.584 --> 00:12:00.250
I think we could do better.

196
00:12:01.560 --> 00:12:06.376
So, in strategy, as a recap,
you see, service strategy looks at

197
00:12:06.376 --> 00:12:11.710
strategy itself at our IT is an asset
to the strategy of the organization.

198
00:12:11.710 --> 00:12:14.696
And that's what we mean
by strategic asset,

199
00:12:14.696 --> 00:12:19.360
is that we need to be an asset to
the strategy of the organization.

200
00:12:19.360 --> 00:12:23.793
You know what, if our organization
doesn't value us then they're

201
00:12:23.793 --> 00:12:27.851
very quickly going to look for
alternative options for them.

202
00:12:27.851 --> 00:12:29.900
They have to value us.

203
00:12:29.900 --> 00:12:33.990
Sometimes value can not be
quantified just in money.

204
00:12:33.990 --> 00:12:38.520
Okay, value can also be quantified
in things like experience, okay?

205
00:12:38.520 --> 00:12:43.924
The knowledge of our stuff, the way that
we are organized, the way that we work.

206
00:12:43.924 --> 00:12:49.240
As well as our ability to
ensure legislative compliance.

207
00:12:49.240 --> 00:12:54.283
I always get myself caught up on that
word, [LAUGH] Legislative, see I told you,

208
00:12:54.283 --> 00:12:59.130
came in the highest although
maybe business ethics as well.

209
00:13:00.250 --> 00:13:04.290
If we are not a value to the organization,

210
00:13:04.290 --> 00:13:08.930
then our organization will look for
alternatives that will be valuable.

211
00:13:10.500 --> 00:13:14.300
So in Service Design then we take
the ideas that we come up within

212
00:13:14.300 --> 00:13:18.080
Service Strategy and we develop
them as we said, we design them.

213
00:13:18.080 --> 00:13:22.920
And one of the analogies that I
used during our foundation recap,

214
00:13:22.920 --> 00:13:26.266
was that analogy of building a house,
okay?

215
00:13:26.266 --> 00:13:31.000
So instead of a strategy we go to the bank
and say, can I have some money please?

216
00:13:31.000 --> 00:13:33.660
In the service design
we've now got the money or

217
00:13:33.660 --> 00:13:35.210
at least we've got the authorization,

218
00:13:35.210 --> 00:13:38.982
cuz I don't know a bank that will give us
a huge big pile of money, unfortunately.

219
00:13:38.982 --> 00:13:42.520
[LAUGH] And we go to the architect
of service design and we say,

220
00:13:42.520 --> 00:13:44.040
hey design this for us.

221
00:13:44.040 --> 00:13:48.530
And at the end of service design the
architect gives us a comprehensive blue

222
00:13:48.530 --> 00:13:50.882
print and it's not just a blueprint for

223
00:13:50.882 --> 00:13:53.820
the layout of the house
is going to look like.

224
00:13:53.820 --> 00:13:54.800
But it's a blue print for

225
00:13:54.800 --> 00:13:59.440
absolutely everything including how
we're going to use all these appliances.

226
00:13:59.440 --> 00:14:02.495
And where we're going to
buy our groceries from,

227
00:14:02.495 --> 00:14:05.704
who's going to supply us
with our utilities, etc.

228
00:14:05.704 --> 00:14:08.420
And that's handed over
to Service Transition.

229
00:14:08.420 --> 00:14:10.627
So think of those as the builders and
the contractors, and

230
00:14:10.627 --> 00:14:13.480
they're the people that are actually
gonna be building that house for us.

231
00:14:13.480 --> 00:14:16.190
They're gonna be building that service.

232
00:14:16.190 --> 00:14:20.750
And then they are going to be
deploying that service into the life

233
00:14:20.750 --> 00:14:23.969
environment through early-life support.

234
00:14:23.969 --> 00:14:27.860
In other words, we don't just hand
over the keys and then run away.

235
00:14:27.860 --> 00:14:30.865
We hand over the keys to the house,
and then we say, come on in and

236
00:14:30.865 --> 00:14:32.769
let me Me show you how to use everything.

237
00:14:32.769 --> 00:14:36.306
Now service operation as a whole,
as a life cycle phase,

238
00:14:36.306 --> 00:14:38.775
is not as stubborn as me.

239
00:14:38.775 --> 00:14:42.415
Okay, cuz I'm the person that takes
the keys off the contractors and

240
00:14:42.415 --> 00:14:44.255
says that's okay, I can do this.

241
00:14:44.255 --> 00:14:46.815
The service operation is not like that.

242
00:14:46.815 --> 00:14:51.073
Service operation wants to be as involved
as possible in the building of the house

243
00:14:51.073 --> 00:14:52.649
that's definitely like me.

244
00:14:52.649 --> 00:14:58.012
[LAUGH] Service operation also, wants to
ensure that before that contractor leaves,

245
00:14:58.012 --> 00:15:01.591
that they've told us absolutely
everything that we need to know.

246
00:15:01.591 --> 00:15:05.317
That I know how to operate all
of this high tech gadgetry and

247
00:15:05.317 --> 00:15:07.840
widgetry that I've got in this house.

248
00:15:08.900 --> 00:15:13.570
So, service design or service transition
doesn't just leave at that point in time.

249
00:15:13.570 --> 00:15:15.190
We have this early life support period.

250
00:15:16.520 --> 00:15:19.360
CSI, obviously is everything.

251
00:15:19.360 --> 00:15:24.160
And if CSI sees a process that could
be improved, CSI will interrupt and

252
00:15:24.160 --> 00:15:26.600
say, I think that could be improved.

253
00:15:26.600 --> 00:15:31.270
If CSI looks at that person that's tiling
the shower room in my brand new house and

254
00:15:31.270 --> 00:15:32.550
says, you know what?

255
00:15:32.550 --> 00:15:37.130
Those tiles don't quite fit, or
those tiles aren't quite the right color.

256
00:15:37.130 --> 00:15:41.621
I think I'd like something different, then
CSI is the person that says, hey look,

257
00:15:41.621 --> 00:15:43.590
let's do this a different way.

258
00:15:43.590 --> 00:15:47.150
Because it's more efficient or
because it's more effective.

259
00:15:47.150 --> 00:15:50.890
So CSI has involvement in
absolutely everything.

260
00:15:50.890 --> 00:15:55.024
And just like your contractor, they will
learn as they're building that house.

261
00:15:55.024 --> 00:15:57.612
And they'll say hey look,
we've done this a different way.

262
00:15:57.612 --> 00:16:01.614
We've done the cabling in a completely
different way to how we normally do it and

263
00:16:01.614 --> 00:16:02.283
this works.

264
00:16:02.283 --> 00:16:05.575
So we're going to carry this on
in all of our future projects.

265
00:16:05.575 --> 00:16:07.550
That's exactly what CSI does.

266
00:16:07.550 --> 00:16:11.240
It improves everything,
not just operations.

267
00:16:11.240 --> 00:16:15.630
It improves everything, but
CSI also keeps operations up to date too.

268
00:16:15.630 --> 00:16:19.900
So CSI also ensures that now that
I'm in my house, that that nice,

269
00:16:19.900 --> 00:16:24.555
fancy refrigerator that I wanted with
a big TV screen on the front that was

270
00:16:24.555 --> 00:16:27.028
connected to all of my other devices.

271
00:16:27.028 --> 00:16:32.336
Well, CSI makes sure that in a couple of
years time, because I am the way I am,

272
00:16:32.336 --> 00:16:36.277
that they're out there
evaluating new refrigerators.

273
00:16:36.277 --> 00:16:39.561
Because once it's reached two years old,
the technology's gone past it and

274
00:16:39.561 --> 00:16:41.115
therefore I need a new one, right?

275
00:16:41.115 --> 00:16:45.567
[LAUGH] So here you have all of
your processes outlined then in

276
00:16:45.567 --> 00:16:51.099
Service Strategy, in Service Design,
in Transition and in Operation.

277
00:16:51.099 --> 00:16:54.560
And then CSI,
we're going to look at the CSI approach.

278
00:16:54.560 --> 00:16:58.437
And we're going to look more in-depth
at the seven step improvement process.

279
00:16:58.437 --> 00:17:02.982
And we are also going to look
at the demi-cycle as well,

280
00:17:02.982 --> 00:17:09.000
which is another intuitive approach
to continual service improvement.

281
00:17:09.000 --> 00:17:13.601
Now it's really, really important, at this
point in time I want you to spend a few

282
00:17:13.601 --> 00:17:18.310
minutes just looking at those processes
and understanding those processes.

283
00:17:18.310 --> 00:17:19.520
And just in a moment,

284
00:17:19.520 --> 00:17:23.900
I'm going to give you an exercise to do
because I want you to go away and every

285
00:17:23.900 --> 00:17:28.910
single process that you see on that slide
in front of you, every single process,

286
00:17:28.910 --> 00:17:34.210
I would like you to identify the
objectives for each of these processes.

287
00:17:34.210 --> 00:17:37.050
Because we've got to
improve these processes,

288
00:17:37.050 --> 00:17:41.570
if you don't know what the processes
do you can't improve them.

289
00:17:41.570 --> 00:17:46.020
So key to the next sessions,
the following sessions in this class,

290
00:17:46.020 --> 00:17:49.820
is going to be understanding
the objectives of all of these processes.

291
00:17:51.080 --> 00:17:52.200
Every single one.

292
00:17:52.200 --> 00:17:54.530
I need you to be very, very clear, and

293
00:17:54.530 --> 00:17:58.650
very comfortable with the objectives
of every single process.

294
00:17:58.650 --> 00:18:02.620
Because at any point in time I
might use the example, of say,

295
00:18:02.620 --> 00:18:06.070
making improvements to financial
management, for instance.

296
00:18:06.070 --> 00:18:10.180
Well if you don't understand what
financial management does, then it's going

297
00:18:10.180 --> 00:18:14.510
to be very difficult for you to follow
along with what we're talking about.

298
00:18:14.510 --> 00:18:17.930
And financial management is
one of those processes that's

299
00:18:17.930 --> 00:18:20.270
got some quite complex objectives.

300
00:18:20.270 --> 00:18:24.400
And we've got accounting, budgeting, and
charging within financial management, but

301
00:18:24.400 --> 00:18:27.380
we also have to think
about value on investment

302
00:18:27.380 --> 00:18:31.710
as opposed to return on investment,
which is about that financial return.

303
00:18:31.710 --> 00:18:34.230
Your value is about a value return.

304
00:18:34.230 --> 00:18:36.550
We've also got to think
about depreciation,

305
00:18:36.550 --> 00:18:40.230
we've also got to think about
the total cost of ownership, and

306
00:18:40.230 --> 00:18:45.990
we've also got to think about
the actual return on any given service.

307
00:18:47.080 --> 00:18:52.703
Which we have to take into consideration
uptime and downtime of a service

308
00:18:52.703 --> 00:18:58.888
because of course downtime of a service
then strips away at that return, okay?

309
00:18:58.888 --> 00:19:03.493
So at any point in time over the next few
sessions throughout this class we could be

310
00:19:03.493 --> 00:19:06.080
looking at any one of these processes.

311
00:19:06.080 --> 00:19:09.740
So in a moment I am going
to ask you to go away and

312
00:19:09.740 --> 00:19:14.580
to spend an hour not just
reviewing CSI objectives,

313
00:19:14.580 --> 00:19:19.259
but also reviewing the objectives of
every single one of your processes.

314
00:19:20.550 --> 00:19:23.850
So here in our lifecycle
wheel as we call it,

315
00:19:23.850 --> 00:19:28.440
in our hub, we've got Service Strategy
right in the middle, and Service Strategy

316
00:19:28.440 --> 00:19:32.190
is where we come up with our ideas and
our policies and our directions.

317
00:19:32.190 --> 00:19:35.920
And in Service Design we design
that service, we transition it.

318
00:19:35.920 --> 00:19:39.310
We build, test, and
implement in Service Transition and

319
00:19:39.310 --> 00:19:42.980
we run in Service Operation.

320
00:19:42.980 --> 00:19:49.330
And you will see that CSI
encompasses absolutely everything.

321
00:19:49.330 --> 00:19:55.680
So, as I've asked you to do then,
I would like you now please to go away

322
00:19:55.680 --> 00:20:00.480
and to review all of
the processes within ITIL.

323
00:20:00.480 --> 00:20:05.380
Look back at the previous slide,
let me pull that slide up for

324
00:20:05.380 --> 00:20:09.840
you, if it's something that
you need to prompt you.

325
00:20:09.840 --> 00:20:12.940
But I'd like you to review all of
the objectives and all of the scope and

326
00:20:12.940 --> 00:20:19.020
purpose of all of those processes and
we will see you in the next session.

327
00:20:19.020 --> 00:20:21.016
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for

328
00:20:21.016 --> 00:20:23.835
helping us as we continue to
take a look at these scopes and

329
00:20:23.835 --> 00:20:27.270
these different objectives that
we've been talking about for CSI.

330
00:20:27.270 --> 00:20:28.294
It really is helpful.

331
00:20:28.294 --> 00:20:31.602
Make sure you do the activity
here to get ready for

332
00:20:31.602 --> 00:20:36.640
some of your ITIL challenges in
the future, such as the exam as well.

333
00:20:36.640 --> 00:20:39.270
Well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode, then.

334
00:20:39.270 --> 00:20:42.390
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

335
00:20:42.390 --> 00:20:43.530
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

336
00:20:43.530 --> 00:20:47.208
>> Stay tuned right here more for
ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

337
00:20:47.208 --> 00:20:54.578
[MUSIC]

338
00:20:54.578 --> 00:20:57.184
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

Jo tells us about the keys to success of CSI and recommended use of Kotterâ€™s 8 step to transformational changes.  She also discusses the need for the responsible person for CSI and the authoritative person for CSI.  Another factor to keep CSI on track is the use of the csi registerâ€”a list of improvement opportunities that give everyone a voice to recommend an improvement too.  Lastly, she describes the how SLM and DIKW play a role in CSI success.
episodes.title: CSI Principles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:01.185
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.185 --> 00:00:02.606
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.606 --> 00:00:04.364
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.364 --> 00:00:07.089
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.089 --> 00:00:10.766
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:10.766 --> 00:00:14.720
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.720 --> 00:00:19.170
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate CSI show.

8
00:00:19.170 --> 00:00:24.790
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
gonna be taking a look at CSI principles

9
00:00:24.790 --> 00:00:28.970
and here to help us of course is gonna be
the ITIL superstar herself, Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:28.970 --> 00:00:30.530
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:30.530 --> 00:00:32.410
>> Thank you very,
much Ronnie, how are you?

12
00:00:32.410 --> 00:00:37.433
>> I am doing fine, now Jo, we've already
talked about the scope and the objectives,

13
00:00:37.433 --> 00:00:42.660
what makes this different when we move
into the realm of CSI principles here?

14
00:00:42.660 --> 00:00:45.400
>> So what we're looking at in
this particular session is we're

15
00:00:45.400 --> 00:00:48.900
looking at what has to happen in order for
CSI to work.

16
00:00:48.900 --> 00:00:52.800
So in the previous sessions we
looked at the objectives of CSI,

17
00:00:52.800 --> 00:00:54.750
what CSI Is trying to achieve?

18
00:00:54.750 --> 00:00:59.880
We also looked at the scope of CSI,
which is pretty much everything.

19
00:00:59.880 --> 00:01:01.860
We can sum that up in one word.

20
00:01:01.860 --> 00:01:04.990
And now we're looking at
what we have to do in CSI,

21
00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:07.740
what we have to have in order for
it to be successful.

22
00:01:10.530 --> 00:01:14.612
So we're starting off then [LAUGH]
with our first slide, okay?

23
00:01:14.612 --> 00:01:18.600
And our first slide really
looks at organizational change.

24
00:01:18.600 --> 00:01:21.840
This goes without saying,
hence the silent pause there,

25
00:01:21.840 --> 00:01:25.050
[LAUGH] because this should
be fairly obvious, okay.

26
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:26.480
Look at that middle bullet point there.

27
00:01:26.480 --> 00:01:30.130
And that middle bullet point tells you
that people generally don't like to change

28
00:01:30.130 --> 00:01:31.860
without some reason to do it.

29
00:01:33.160 --> 00:01:34.920
We're going to expand on this,

30
00:01:34.920 --> 00:01:39.340
a huge amount a little bit later
on in subsequent episodes.

31
00:01:39.340 --> 00:01:41.980
But let me just think about this for
a moment.

32
00:01:41.980 --> 00:01:44.329
Let me just sow some
seeds into your minds.

33
00:01:45.600 --> 00:01:51.740
Even if you want to change, even if you
want to do something completely different,

34
00:01:51.740 --> 00:01:54.430
you're still nervous, and
you're still anxious about it.

35
00:01:55.610 --> 00:01:59.798
I mentioned some anxiety on that last
bullet point and this is where we truly.

36
00:01:59.798 --> 00:02:04.060
You know what, I know a lot of
people that even though they

37
00:02:04.060 --> 00:02:05.945
hate the cellphone that
they got right now,

38
00:02:05.945 --> 00:02:09.690
they don't wanna change because they
know what they've got right now.

39
00:02:09.690 --> 00:02:11.520
And because they 're used to it.

40
00:02:12.520 --> 00:02:15.650
And this goes throughout the whole of IT.

41
00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:17.530
But it doesn't just go
throughout the whole of IT,

42
00:02:17.530 --> 00:02:20.120
it actually goes throughout
our entire lives.

43
00:02:20.120 --> 00:02:24.330
And so here at CSI, we will be spending,
in subsequent episodes,

44
00:02:24.330 --> 00:02:28.090
we'll be spending some time looking
at psychological effect and

45
00:02:28.090 --> 00:02:30.430
actually looking at
organizational change management.

46
00:02:30.430 --> 00:02:33.950
This is not just about the technology,
because in order for

47
00:02:33.950 --> 00:02:38.190
the technology to succeed,
people have got to use it.

48
00:02:38.190 --> 00:02:43.560
And in order to get people to use the
technology, they've got to want to use it.

49
00:02:43.560 --> 00:02:47.230
If you don't want to use something,
then you're going to try and

50
00:02:47.230 --> 00:02:52.230
find any way not to, to the point of even

51
00:02:52.230 --> 00:02:57.570
maybe discovering faults within
that particular piece of equipment.

52
00:02:57.570 --> 00:03:01.880
And I know that this happened before and
I know that I've seen evidence of this in

53
00:03:01.880 --> 00:03:07.970
various organizations where, we don't
convince people of the need to change.

54
00:03:07.970 --> 00:03:09.780
By the way,
it's not just about convincing them.

55
00:03:09.780 --> 00:03:15.948
It's actually about generating a need,
and generating a desire to change.

56
00:03:15.948 --> 00:03:20.186
It's not good, just good enough for you to
convince somebody that it's a good idea.

57
00:03:20.186 --> 00:03:22.330
They've actually gotta be hungry for
change.

58
00:03:23.680 --> 00:03:24.828
They've got to want change.

59
00:03:24.828 --> 00:03:29.676
If we're trying to upgrade or
change an environment within IT,

60
00:03:29.676 --> 00:03:33.010
then the people have got to be hungry for
it.

61
00:03:33.010 --> 00:03:34.770
They've got to be ready for it.

62
00:03:34.770 --> 00:03:37.220
And they've got to be
willing to make that change.

63
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:41.931
I have mentioned in previous
sessions within CSI of

64
00:03:41.931 --> 00:03:46.132
a organization that I worked with
that actually wanted to change their

65
00:03:46.132 --> 00:03:50.334
environment from a Windows environment
to an Apple environment, and

66
00:03:50.334 --> 00:03:54.838
I used that as an example because
that's actually quite a drastic change.

67
00:03:54.838 --> 00:03:59.690
Now, if you have been used to a Microsoft
Windows machine all your life and

68
00:03:59.690 --> 00:04:04.660
let's face it Windows has been around for
quite a number of years now.

69
00:04:04.660 --> 00:04:08.170
And you've been used to that all your
life and somebody comes along and

70
00:04:08.170 --> 00:04:13.140
puts in Apple machine in front of you,
that's one heck of a difference.

71
00:04:14.330 --> 00:04:17.440
And sure, you can browse
the Internet with it, that's great.

72
00:04:17.440 --> 00:04:21.070
And you can use Word, and
you can use Excel, and

73
00:04:21.070 --> 00:04:24.290
you can use all of the Microsoft
applications, and that's not a problem.

74
00:04:24.290 --> 00:04:28.820
But the simple fact is that the way
it works is completely different.

75
00:04:28.820 --> 00:04:32.580
And so, even just to the point
of closing a window,

76
00:04:32.580 --> 00:04:36.120
going to the top left hand corner
of a window instead of the top

77
00:04:36.120 --> 00:04:40.532
right hand corner of a window
can take some getting used to.

78
00:04:40.532 --> 00:04:46.160
So, unless you can find
what drives the person and

79
00:04:46.160 --> 00:04:49.820
find what they really are desperate for
and

80
00:04:49.820 --> 00:04:55.180
then you can sell that
technology to that need.

81
00:04:55.180 --> 00:04:58.610
Unless you can find that,
then you're never gonna be successful with

82
00:04:58.610 --> 00:05:01.070
that change because they're
going to be resistant to it,

83
00:05:01.070 --> 00:05:05.440
because it's not going to work
the way that they want it to work.

84
00:05:05.440 --> 00:05:07.200
It's not going to be the same.

85
00:05:08.510 --> 00:05:13.016
So organizational change is
one of the principles to CSI.

86
00:05:13.016 --> 00:05:15.688
We have to accept that people matter.

87
00:05:15.688 --> 00:05:19.480
Now when we looked in service
operation we looked at people as well.

88
00:05:19.480 --> 00:05:23.560
And we said that people really matter and
people are going to drive success.

89
00:05:23.560 --> 00:05:26.610
Well, people are gonna drive success
in continual service improvement.

90
00:05:28.550 --> 00:05:32.130
On this next page here we
look at Kotter's eight steps.

91
00:05:32.130 --> 00:05:34.748
Kotter's eight steps of
transformational change.

92
00:05:34.748 --> 00:05:39.675
Now, Kotter, JP Kotter,
is an alumni of Harvard and

93
00:05:39.675 --> 00:05:45.486
he looked a transformational
change within an organization.

94
00:05:45.486 --> 00:05:47.386
And he looked at the drivers for

95
00:05:47.386 --> 00:05:50.610
transformational change
within an organization.

96

We'd like something that's
a little bit more tighter.

324
00:20:07.090 --> 00:20:11.390
We'd like it to have more
stringent targets, or

325
00:20:11.390 --> 00:20:16.570
it might be the customer actually
asks us to change a target because,

326
00:20:16.570 --> 00:20:20.880
maybe it's too stringent, or maybe it just
doesn't meet their requirements at all.

327
00:20:22.010 --> 00:20:27.350
So right the way throughout service
level management, CSI is evident.

328
00:20:27.350 --> 00:20:28.490
CSI is there.

329
00:20:28.490 --> 00:20:29.770
It's embedded in.

330
00:20:29.770 --> 00:20:32.750
It's got those tendrils into
service-level management.

331
00:20:32.750 --> 00:20:35.230
Think about using our
service catalog as a check.

332
00:20:36.250 --> 00:20:42.300
And, again,
we do that to enforce CSI II because we're

333
00:20:42.300 --> 00:20:48.450
always verifying that all of the services
in our service catalog have an SLA.

334
00:20:48.450 --> 00:20:52.810
And that every service that we have an SLA
for although this going through the SLA

335
00:20:52.810 --> 00:20:57.590
process, every single service is
mentioned in our service catalog.

336
00:20:57.590 --> 00:21:00.410
And that's what CSI will
take accountability for,

337
00:21:00.410 --> 00:21:05.500
ensuring that we've got that necessary
relationship between the information,

338
00:21:05.500 --> 00:21:07.630
so that everything is accurate and
up to date.

339
00:21:08.720 --> 00:21:11.080
And then, of course,
there's knowledge management.

340
00:21:11.080 --> 00:21:15.070
Now, knowledge management,
I mentioned previously in the section and

341
00:21:15.070 --> 00:21:18.420
I've mentioned to you in
our foundation recap,

342
00:21:18.420 --> 00:21:23.250
that knowledge management is where
we take individual sources of data.

343
00:21:24.320 --> 00:21:27.930
We add in relationships
to those data sources.

344
00:21:27.930 --> 00:21:29.817
So relationships between databases.

345
00:21:29.817 --> 00:21:32.380
And that gives us information.

346
00:21:32.380 --> 00:21:36.450
And then, we analyse that information,
and then that gives us knowledge.

347
00:21:36.450 --> 00:21:40.910
We generally display that by way of a nice
pretty picture, or a nice pretty graph.

348
00:21:40.910 --> 00:21:44.460
And that allows us to make
an informed decision.

349
00:21:45.780 --> 00:21:48.890
And we use that informed
decision to give us wisdom.

350
00:21:50.040 --> 00:21:53.404
And put quite simply,
we don't produce any reports, or

351
00:21:53.404 --> 00:21:58.400
we don't produce any pretty grass unless
they're going to tell us something.

352
00:21:58.400 --> 00:22:01.580
Unless they're going to give us wisdom.

353
00:22:01.580 --> 00:22:05.470
And that knowledge that we have
also includes experience and

354
00:22:05.470 --> 00:22:08.940
ideas and survey results, too.

355
00:22:08.940 --> 00:22:12.240
Because they also will
help us to achieve wisdom.

356
00:22:12.240 --> 00:22:16.366
And the more wisdom that we have, the more
decisions that we're able to make and

357
00:22:16.366 --> 00:22:19.095
the more aligned we are to
the needs of the business.

358
00:22:19.095 --> 00:22:22.690
And therefore, CSI is improvement.

359
00:22:22.690 --> 00:22:26.809
And you can see here what we call
a DIKW Model by way of a graph.

360
00:22:26.809 --> 00:22:30.995
Because what we want to do is we
want to increase our context and

361
00:22:30.995 --> 00:22:35.750
we want to increase our
understanding of our organization.

362
00:22:35.750 --> 00:22:38.570
Now, just taking you
back here to this slide,

363
00:22:38.570 --> 00:22:43.110
on the lifetime side there's a discussion
point, and it says, let's talk.

364
00:22:43.110 --> 00:22:45.730
Which one of these elements
cannot be captured in a tool?

365
00:22:45.730 --> 00:22:47.320
Well, of course, wisdom.

366
00:22:47.320 --> 00:22:52.360
We cannot capture wisdom, but
everything else we can capture in a tool.

367
00:22:52.360 --> 00:22:57.099
But we have to analyze it and
we have to make the informed decision.

368
00:22:58.510 --> 00:23:03.390
So at this particular point in this
section, this is where we will say,

369
00:23:03.390 --> 00:23:07.250
we'd like you to just review the notes
from this particular section.

370
00:23:07.250 --> 00:23:11.200
And then, we'll be back in part
three where we will carry on

371
00:23:11.200 --> 00:23:13.220
with the principles of CSI.

372
00:23:14.600 --> 00:23:15.410
>> All right, Jill.

373
00:23:15.410 --> 00:23:19.220
Well, thank you again for
helping us to go over those concepts

374
00:23:19.220 --> 00:23:23.700
of our CSI principles that will
really help us as we continue on and

375
00:23:23.700 --> 00:23:26.042
take a look at more of
the continual service improvement.

376
00:23:26.042 --> 00:23:30.060
Understanding that's actually involved in
every process in the life cycles that we

377
00:23:30.060 --> 00:23:35.310
need is really going to hopefully
set the solid understanding of how

378
00:23:35.310 --> 00:23:37.433
invaluable it is to us, as well.

379
00:23:37.433 --> 00:23:41.350
But that's a great place for us to also
end this episode then, signing off for

380
00:23:41.350 --> 00:23:44.550
ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

381
00:23:44.550 --> 00:23:45.630
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

382
00:23:45.630 --> 00:23:49.154
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with additional CSI principles.  These include using the Demming Cycle for repeatable ongoing improvement, using service measurements like baseline, governance (control with transparency), frameworks and models, according to Jo.  Jo also mentions the push to standardization can help too!

12

principles and and really got involve

Jo, I'm not sure what is really left,

>> [LAUGH]

more actually to talk about

21
00:01:06.430 --> 00:01:12.180
We mentioned in our first session in
CSI when we looked at the scope and

22
00:01:12.180 --> 00:01:17.948
the objectives, primarily of CSI,
we mentioned the CSI approach.

23
00:01:17.948 --> 00:01:22.911
And one of the things that I said about
the CSI approach It is a method for

24
00:01:22.911 --> 00:01:25.952
iterative, repeatable, improvement.

25
00:01:25.952 --> 00:01:30.854
Well as well as that,
we would consider the demming cycle to

26
00:01:30.854 --> 00:01:35.178
be a concept for
high level iterative improvement.

27
00:01:35.178 --> 00:01:38.300
It's a repeatable method for improvement.

28
00:01:38.300 --> 00:01:42.728
As you can see in the screen
in front of you, it is a very,

29
00:01:42.728 --> 00:01:47.086
very simple high level use for
an improvement method.

30
00:01:47.086 --> 00:01:51.763
And really simply,
what we wanna make sure is that every

31
00:01:51.763 --> 00:01:55.845
single improvement
initiative is iterative and

32
00:01:55.845 --> 00:02:01.715
that it's planned out and that we do
it and we checked that it worked and

33
00:02:01.715 --> 00:02:07.816
then we take any remedial action and
decide what we're going to do next.

34
00:02:07.816 --> 00:02:10.480
And then we plan it out, we do it,
and we check that it's worked and

35
00:02:10.480 --> 00:02:11.870
then we take any remedial action.

36
00:02:11.870 --> 00:02:14.232
And so
if you look at that graph in front of you,

37

over time we become more mature as
we move towards business alignment.

38
00:02:17.882 --> 00:02:21.604
Now one thing that I will say, and

39
