we started off with our vision, and then
we worked out where we were right now.

40
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:26.980
That's our baseline.

41
00:02:26.980 --> 00:02:30.650
And you see that as
a chalk under that wheel.

42
00:02:30.650 --> 00:02:33.390
Okay and then in our CSI approach,

43
00:02:33.390 --> 00:02:37.620
which is a lot more detailed than
the Deming cycle in front of you now.

44
00:02:37.620 --> 00:02:43.814
Then what we will actually do is we
will make our detailed planning.

45
00:02:43.814 --> 00:02:47.915
And then we will work out whether
we actually achieved it or

46
00:02:47.915 --> 00:02:49.990
not in our CSI approach.

47
00:02:49.990 --> 00:02:54.720
And this is what happens, so we do it in
the Deming cycle, without detail plan or

48
00:02:54.720 --> 00:02:56.190
detail approach and we do.

49
00:02:56.190 --> 00:02:57.400
And then we check.

50
00:02:57.400 --> 00:03:00.170
And remember we check
that in the CSI approach.

51
00:03:00.170 --> 00:03:01.510
DId we get that?

52
00:03:01.510 --> 00:03:04.688
But then what we do is we
take another baseline.

53
00:03:04.688 --> 00:03:08.410
In other words, under that wheel
that you've got in front of you.

54
00:03:08.410 --> 00:03:11.158
We put another chalk under that wheel,
and so

55
00:03:11.158 --> 00:03:14.860
over a period of time if you look
on the screen in front of you.

56
00:03:14.860 --> 00:03:20.640
You will see, that as that wheel has
moved upwards toward business alignment

57
00:03:20.640 --> 00:03:26.230
with each evolution of that wheel
as it moves, it moves upwards.

58
00:03:26.230 --> 00:03:32.278
And so the next time it's going to be
here, a lot closer to business alignment,

59
00:03:32.278 --> 00:03:36.628
and we put a chuck under
the wheel to stop it rolling back.

60
00:03:36.628 --> 00:03:41.343
And that's key across absolutely every
single improvement initiative we

61
00:03:41.343 --> 00:03:42.395
have to embed.

62
00:03:42.395 --> 00:03:47.271
And it is mentioned in our CSI approach,
which is an approach for

63
00:03:47.271 --> 00:03:51.935
performing CSI improvement initiatives.

64
00:03:51.935 --> 00:03:55.025
It's also mentioned in our seven
step improvement processes,

65
00:03:55.025 --> 00:04:00.665
which we're gonna get into in a lot
more detail in a later session.

66
00:04:00.665 --> 00:04:04.405
But the seven step improvement
process also mentions

67
00:04:04.405 --> 00:04:06.960
a varying change to be embedded in.

68
00:04:06.960 --> 00:04:09.474
Now, baselines are mentioned
in a previous section.

69
00:04:09.474 --> 00:04:12.212
I mentioned when we looked
at the objectives and

70
00:04:12.212 --> 00:04:13.930
we looked at the scope of CSI.

71
00:04:13.930 --> 00:04:18.470
And a baseline is just a snapshot
of where we are now just to use as

72
00:04:18.470 --> 00:04:21.400
a starting point for later comparison.

73
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:24.760
So, I want to look a little
bit more at metrics, and

74
00:04:24.760 --> 00:04:28.210
this is something that you would have
covered during your foundation class.

75
00:04:28.210 --> 00:04:32.874
It's not something that we covered
during the foundation recap.

76
00:04:32.874 --> 00:04:37.816
So I want to just reiterate this because
I'm sure it may have been a while since

77
00:04:37.816 --> 00:04:39.424
your foundation class.

78
00:04:39.424 --> 00:04:42.750
And memories fade, or
at least mine does anyway.

79
00:04:42.750 --> 00:04:45.770
And there are four main
reasons why we measure okay.

80
00:04:45.770 --> 00:04:48.542
We measure to validate.

81
00:04:48.542 --> 00:04:52.382
To validate that we're going
in the right direction.

82
00:04:52.382 --> 00:04:56.284
And then we measure to justify, and
I call that one the see, I told you so

83
00:04:56.284 --> 00:04:57.600
measurement, right?

84
00:04:57.600 --> 00:04:59.900
See I told you we needed more stuff.

85
00:04:59.900 --> 00:05:01.814
See I told you we needed more money.

86
00:05:01.814 --> 00:05:05.764
Okay, so we measure to validate that
we're going in the right direction and

87
00:05:05.764 --> 00:05:07.850
we measure to justify.

88
00:05:07.850 --> 00:05:11.476
We also measure to direct and
to intervene.

89
00:05:11.476 --> 00:05:15.398
Think about our SLAM charts, our service
level agreement monitoring charts,

90
00:05:15.398 --> 00:05:19.280
or red, amber, green if you want to
call them that, your RAG charts.

91
00:05:19.280 --> 00:05:22.186
When they're amber or orange or yellow,

92
00:05:22.186 --> 00:05:28.092
depending on what shade of the rainbow
you're using, well, that's a direction.

93
00:05:28.092 --> 00:05:31.770
In other words,
that particular area needs some focus.

94
00:05:31.770 --> 00:05:32.944
It needs some improvement.

95
00:05:32.944 --> 00:05:35.680
We've gotta make sure that
we don't breach a target.

96
00:05:35.680 --> 00:05:37.920
But when it's red, that's an intervention.

97
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:40.350
We gotta do something about that, okay.

98
00:05:40.350 --> 00:05:41.840
So we measure for four reasons.

99
00:05:41.840 --> 00:05:43.980
We measure to validate that we're
going in the right direction.

100
00:05:43.980 --> 00:05:48.230
We measure to justify
that's the I told you so.

101
00:05:48.230 --> 00:05:52.412
Then we measure to direct, and we measure
to intervene, and we should always think,

102
00:05:52.412 --> 00:05:56.552
when we're defining any metrics, and of
course we define these in service design.

103
00:05:56.552 --> 00:05:59.457
But CSI is a part of that definition, and

104
00:05:59.457 --> 00:06:04.680
CSI is a part of the review of all of
our monitoring and reporting as well.

105
00:06:05.760 --> 00:06:10.994
So think about why are you measuring it,
is it going to allow you to make

106
00:06:10.994 --> 00:06:16.872
a informed decision, and how long do you
need to take those measurements for.

107
00:06:16.872 --> 00:06:21.220
And all of those should be part of
your decision making process when you

108
00:06:21.220 --> 00:06:24.770
decide what metrics to take and
what reports to see okay.

109
00:06:24.770 --> 00:06:28.689
And again knowledge management has
an input into this, because knowledge

110
00:06:28.689 --> 00:06:32.000
management is responsible for
the ownership of that data too.

111
00:06:33.130 --> 00:06:36.300
So another principle then, with CSI,

112
00:06:36.300 --> 00:06:40.728
something that we have to
have with CSI is governance.

113
00:06:40.728 --> 00:06:43.349
And in ITIL the governance is about
effective decision making to manage

114
00:06:43.349 --> 00:06:43.969
your business.

115
00:06:45.212 --> 00:06:52.536
In ITIL we look at governance as control
but with fairness and transparency.

116
00:06:52.536 --> 00:06:57.907
This is not about having that
control at this level without

117
00:06:57.907 --> 00:07:03.240
any transparency or
without any visible fairness.

118
00:07:03.240 --> 00:07:06.180
There has to be a reason why
we make every single decision.

119
00:07:06.180 --> 00:07:08.560
And that's exactly what we're saying.

120
00:07:08.560 --> 00:07:11.572
And that reason should
be visible to everyone.

121
00:07:11.572 --> 00:07:14.406
If you're in an IT environment and

122
00:07:14.406 --> 00:07:18.522
you have to ask the question,
why am I doing this?

123
00:07:18.522 --> 00:07:20.218
Well for a start,
you're not gonna give 100%.

124
00:07:20.218 --> 00:07:22.751
Because if you don't believe in something,
and

125
00:07:22.751 --> 00:07:26.360
we look to this in a previous section
when we looked at codozay steps.

126
00:07:26.360 --> 00:07:28.650
If you don't believe in doing
something than you're not gonna do it.

127
00:07:28.650 --> 00:07:30.866
You're certainly not
gonna give it your all.

128
00:07:30.866 --> 00:07:36.770
So, we want to make sure that we have that
transparency that everybody knows why.

129
00:07:36.770 --> 00:07:38.808
That we don't have to ask that question.

130
00:07:38.808 --> 00:07:41.749
We already know the answer
to that question.

131
00:07:41.749 --> 00:07:43.190
And it's about fairness too.

132
00:07:43.190 --> 00:07:46.910
And again, that's back to
the reason of why are doing this.

133
00:07:46.910 --> 00:07:50.392
And because I feel like it
is not really an answer.

134
00:07:50.392 --> 00:07:54.709
So IT governance is the responsibility
of the board of directors, and

135
00:07:54.709 --> 00:07:57.630
also the steering group etc as well.

136
00:07:57.630 --> 00:08:02.210
And we've got enterprise governance
that controls just well everything.

137
00:08:02.210 --> 00:08:05.780
In other words the corporate
governance and the business governance.

138
00:08:05.780 --> 00:08:08.743
And then we'll take a look if
we look on our next slide and

139
00:08:08.743 --> 00:08:10.648
it explains it a little bit better.

140
00:08:10.648 --> 00:08:14.148
Under that enterprise which is
the corporation as a whole,

141
00:08:14.148 --> 00:08:18.628
we look at what we call, corporate
governance, which is conformance, and

142
00:08:18.628 --> 00:08:21.870
business governance which is performance.

143
00:08:21.870 --> 00:08:23.554
And what does that mean really?

144
00:08:23.554 --> 00:08:28.612
Well corporate governance is all
about conforming to our ethics,

145
00:08:28.612 --> 00:08:31.500
conforming to our way of working.

146
00:08:31.500 --> 00:08:35.118
So we use words like accountability and
assurance in this.

147
00:08:35.118 --> 00:08:41.732
Whereas, business governance is all about
delivering that return on that investment.

148
00:08:41.732 --> 00:08:46.370
It's about value creation,
in other words, performance.

149
00:08:46.370 --> 00:08:49.901
Because you see,
we can deliver performance but

150
00:08:49.901 --> 00:08:54.998
not necessarily do it in an ethical way,
or not do it in organized way.

151
00:08:54.998 --> 00:08:58.272
Which means that we've got
business governance started out,

152
00:08:58.272 --> 00:09:01.370
it's working great but
the corporate governance isn't.

153
00:09:01.370 --> 00:09:06.969
But we can be as organized as we like, so
we can achieve corporate governance, but

154
00:09:06.969 --> 00:09:13.330
we don't deliver in which case then we're
not achieving business governance, okay?

155
00:09:13.330 --> 00:09:16.885
So we need to have both, and
in the same way that in foundation

156
00:09:16.885 --> 00:09:21.580
we looked at the utility and warranty of
the service it's pretty much the same.

157
00:09:21.580 --> 00:09:26.772
Governance is splitting to those two
factors because we have to have both.

158
00:09:26.772 --> 00:09:32.118
We have to be organized and We have to be
able to deliver that performance within

159
00:09:32.118 --> 00:09:37.140
the organization, otherwise
the organization is simply going to fail.

160
00:09:37.140 --> 00:09:41.112
We've got a lot of tool at
our disposal to help us.

161
00:09:41.112 --> 00:09:47.020
And ITIL is a framework, and
it's a framework for managing IT services.

162
00:09:47.020 --> 00:09:50.824
It's a framework for delivering value,
that's what ITIL is.

163
00:09:50.824 --> 00:09:55.824
Now I have mentioned in
a previous section that ITIL

164
00:09:55.824 --> 00:10:01.560
is like a skeleton,
I think was the analogy that I used.

165
00:10:01.560 --> 00:10:02.960
We're gonna give you a set of bones.

166
00:10:02.960 --> 00:10:07.090
And we're gonna tell you that you need
to have these bones in place, okay.

167
00:10:07.090 --> 00:10:10.030
In order to have a person,

168
00:10:10.030 --> 00:10:12.960
a real live living creature
you need to have a skeleton.

169
00:10:12.960 --> 00:10:13.630
Okay, well that's great.

170
00:10:13.630 --> 00:10:16.630
But it's up to you to meet to those bones.

171
00:10:16.630 --> 00:10:20.676
It's up to you to decide whether
you want it to have 1 eye or

172
00:10:20.676 --> 00:10:24.816
15 eyes or walk on 4 legs or
walk on 2 legs with or 2 arms.

173
00:10:24.816 --> 00:10:26.860
That's entirely up to you.

174
00:10:26.860 --> 00:10:28.908
We'll just tell you that you
need these bones in place.

175
00:10:28.908 --> 00:10:33.706
An ITIL will tell you, you really do need
these processes, in place in order to

176
00:10:33.706 --> 00:10:38.330
have efficient and effective services and
deliver value to the business.

177
00:10:38.330 --> 00:10:39.840
But what those processes look like,

178
00:10:39.840 --> 00:10:42.920
well that's entirely up to you,
we can't tell you that.

179
00:10:42.920 --> 00:10:45.480
It's not a one size fits all approach.

180
00:10:45.480 --> 00:10:50.420
So ITIL is a framework and
it gives you guidance on the structure.

181
00:10:50.420 --> 00:10:54.290
We've also got COBIT,
which is a framework for,

182
00:10:54.290 --> 00:10:59.990
it came out of the financial sector and
is a framework for governance.

183
00:10:59.990 --> 00:11:03.720
It's a framework for strategy and
it's an audit framework.

184
00:11:03.720 --> 00:11:07.030
And as I say, it's geared very
much towards the financial sector.

185
00:11:07.030 --> 00:11:09.750
It certainly came out of
the financial sector.

186
00:11:09.750 --> 00:11:13.256
And so that will,
if we were to put the two together,

187
00:11:13.256 --> 00:11:16.940
COBIT will tell you what you
want to achieve within IT.

188
00:11:16.940 --> 00:11:21.340
In other words,
the strategy and the audit.

189
00:11:21.340 --> 00:11:24.972
Whereas ITIL will tell you
how to achieve it, okay.

190
00:11:24.972 --> 00:11:28.190
And then we've got project management,
okay.

191
00:11:28.190 --> 00:11:31.620
And so in this particular example,
you've got PMBOK.

192
00:11:31.620 --> 00:11:35.870
We also have Prints 2 and PMI, PMP.

193
00:11:35.870 --> 00:11:40.094
Which are framework examples for
project management.

194
00:11:40.094 --> 00:11:43.135
Ultimately, what we're trying to achieve,
is efficiency and

195
00:11:43.135 --> 00:11:45.720
effectiveness in everything that we do.

196
00:11:45.720 --> 00:11:50.284
Whether it be in projects or
whether it be in our service management.

197
00:11:50.284 --> 00:11:53.040
And so what we want to have
is a consistent approach.

198
00:11:53.040 --> 00:11:58.428
And so we use frameworks to help us
achieve that consistency approach.

199
00:11:58.428 --> 00:12:02.250
Frameworks will not
give us the magic cure.

200
00:12:02.250 --> 00:12:04.720
They're not going to do it for us.

201
00:12:04.720 --> 00:12:05.892
We've still got to put in the work.

202
00:12:05.892 --> 00:12:10.063
We've still got define how
it's going to look for us, but

203
00:12:10.063 --> 00:12:12.800
frameworks will help us to get there.

204
00:12:12.800 --> 00:12:14.130
They'll give us that consistency.

205
00:12:15.540 --> 00:12:18.040
And then we have models.

206
00:12:18.040 --> 00:12:19.792
And a model is a predefined set of steps.

207
00:12:19.792 --> 00:12:25.460
And here we have the CMMI model,
the Capability Maturity Model.

208
00:12:25.460 --> 00:12:29.397
Now, the Capability Maturity model
is something that we would use for

209
00:12:29.397 --> 00:12:30.540
process maturity.

210
00:12:30.540 --> 00:12:34.960
And actually I find CMMI
an invaluable tool when it comes

211
00:12:34.960 --> 00:12:39.830
to measuring the maturity
of our ITIL processes.

212
00:12:39.830 --> 00:12:46.043
Because CMMI gives us a model that
was build on a scale from 0 to 5 and

213
00:12:46.043 --> 00:12:50.076
we grade our processes
based on that scale.

214
00:12:50.076 --> 00:12:55.688
Whether it be zero, which is completely ad
hoc processes with no real definition and

215
00:12:55.688 --> 00:12:58.296
documentation right away through to 5

216
00:12:58.296 --> 00:13:03.119
which actually have well developed
processes, with documentation and

217
00:13:03.119 --> 00:13:07.170
that are subject to CSI-
continuous service improvement.

218
00:13:08.620 --> 00:13:13.720
CMMI has generally been accepted as
the standard now for measuring maturity.

219
00:13:13.720 --> 00:13:18.362
And I certainly find it incredibly
helpful when I'm doing assessments and

220
00:13:18.362 --> 00:13:23.310
when I'm doing audits at organizations for
either ISO 20000 or for ITIL.

221
00:13:23.310 --> 00:13:28.147
Then I find CMMI really,
really useful to give organizations

222
00:13:28.147 --> 00:13:32.640
a view of exactly what level
their processes are at.

223
00:13:32.640 --> 00:13:37.642
Sometimes an organization may think that
their process is very well developed.

224
00:13:37.642 --> 00:13:42.748
And I spot something that really takes it
down a couple of points in the CMMI scale,

225
00:13:42.748 --> 00:13:46.818
but sometimes actually processes,
and actually a lot of times,

226
00:13:46.818 --> 00:13:49.783
you find that processes
are doing a lot better.

227
00:13:49.783 --> 00:13:54.775
A lot more mature than what
organization will give them credit for.

228
00:13:54.775 --> 00:13:57.655
But we've gotta have that consistency.

229
00:13:57.655 --> 00:14:01.995
And that again comes out in CMMI
this is about a consistent approach.

230
00:14:01.995 --> 00:14:07.600
And so we have to have a consistent
achievement of that score within CMMI.

231
00:14:07.600 --> 00:14:11.530
And then we have, lastly,
the standards, and

232
00:14:11.530 --> 00:14:17.150
an international standard is
something that you achieve.

233
00:14:17.150 --> 00:14:22.482
So let's look at ISO/IEC 20000 which
is the international standard for

234
00:14:22.482 --> 00:14:24.025
service management.

235
00:14:24.025 --> 00:14:29.346
And what will happen is an ISO
20000 order will come along and

236
00:14:29.346 --> 00:14:32.505
will assess your organization.

237
00:14:32.505 --> 00:14:37.765
For efficiency and effectiveness
within service management processes.

238
00:14:37.765 --> 00:14:41.899
They will check that all of your
service management processes

239
00:14:41.899 --> 00:14:46.747
are consistently managed, that they
have CSI in place and that they have

240
00:14:46.747 --> 00:14:51.690
the relationships between the processes
cuz they are really important.

241
00:14:51.690 --> 00:14:56.030
Because we can't work in silos not in
ITIL, it just simply doesn't work.

242
00:14:56.030 --> 00:15:00.679
And even in the last two sections ,we have
looked at the interactions between CSI and

243
00:15:00.679 --> 00:15:02.000
quite a few processes.

244
00:15:02.000 --> 00:15:07.084
And, without those interactions those
processes would not be efficient or

245
00:15:07.084 --> 00:15:07.964
effective.

246
00:15:07.964 --> 00:15:14.103
So I saw ISO/20000 won't tell you whether
you've implemented ITIL, ISO/20000 will

247
00:15:14.103 --> 00:15:19.450
tell you whether your processes actually
meet the requirements of the organization.

248
00:15:19.450 --> 00:15:23.227
And whether your processes
are efficient and effective,

249
00:15:23.227 --> 00:15:25.617
whether they have relationships and

250
00:15:25.617 --> 00:15:30.794
whether they actually deliver the defined
output and have defined inputs too.

251
00:15:30.794 --> 00:15:37.340
Okay, ITIL will help
you achieve ISO 20000.

252
00:15:37.340 --> 00:15:42.312
But just because you turn round and
you say as an organization that hey look,

253
00:15:42.312 --> 00:15:47.049
I've got an ITIL framework in place,
does not mean that you're going to

254
00:15:47.049 --> 00:15:51.104
obtain ISO/20000 accreditation very,
very easily.

255
00:15:51.104 --> 00:15:54.056
And what we have to do Is
we have to come in and

256
00:15:54.056 --> 00:15:59.304
we have to audit your processes to make
sure that they will meet the standards

257
00:15:59.304 --> 00:16:04.670
that are required bu
the International Standards Organization.

258
00:16:04.670 --> 00:16:08.360
Now every three years you're subject to an
audit with an international standard and

259
00:16:08.360 --> 00:16:11.930
then every year,
you'll have an interim assessment,

260
00:16:11.930 --> 00:16:16.225
just a small so, a very short assessment.

261
00:16:16.225 --> 00:16:20.995
Well, we'll give you a little pointer or
two just to say, hey, this one's slipping,

262
00:16:20.995 --> 00:16:24.025
this one needs some work,
or this one's doing really,

263
00:16:24.025 --> 00:16:26.039
really great in terms of processes.

264
00:16:26.039 --> 00:16:29.187
Then every three years
you'll be fully audited and

265
00:16:29.187 --> 00:16:33.882
you will receive a certificate, and
you will receive that accreditation.

266
00:16:33.882 --> 00:16:39.000
And they're exactly the same is true for
ISO 270002 which

267
00:16:39.000 --> 00:16:43.836
is the international standard for
information security and

268
00:16:43.836 --> 00:16:48.862
ISO 17799 for security management and
we've got process

269
00:16:48.862 --> 00:16:54.288
improvement there as well and
also software asset management too.

270
00:16:54.288 --> 00:16:56.580
And there are lots and
lots of other standards.

271
00:16:56.580 --> 00:17:00.450
We have standards for
quality management access,

272
00:17:00.450 --> 00:17:03.650
standards for service continuity as well.

273
00:17:03.650 --> 00:17:04.950
So there are a lot of standards.

274
00:17:04.950 --> 00:17:08.075
Now ITIL will help you
achieve those standards, but

275
00:17:08.075 --> 00:17:12.830
ITIL is not going to guarantee
an achievement of those standards.

276
00:17:12.830 --> 00:17:19.800
Okay, so in terms of CSI principles,
well we have

277
00:17:19.800 --> 00:17:23.960
finished to look at CSI principles and
what we would really like you to do now.

278
00:17:23.960 --> 00:17:29.216
Is go to your course exercises, and your
course materials, and you'll find some

279
00:17:29.216 --> 00:17:34.338
exercises there that will help you
understand these principles in more depth.

280
00:17:34.338 --> 00:17:38.146
You'll find a case study,
something to base your exercises on,

281
00:17:38.146 --> 00:17:42.260
and you'll find some exercises and
some very simple questions.

282
00:17:42.260 --> 00:17:45.293
That will either look over
your foundation material and

283
00:17:45.293 --> 00:17:49.048
ensure that you understand
the integration between the processes.

284
00:17:49.048 --> 00:17:51.316
And and
I know that in the previous section,

285
00:17:51.316 --> 00:17:54.640
I have asked you to understand
the objectives of the processes.

286
00:17:54.640 --> 00:17:57.970
These questions will ensure
that you do understand that

287
00:17:57.970 --> 00:18:01.090
before we move onto our next section.

288
00:18:01.090 --> 00:18:05.671
As always, we are available in the forum
if you do have ny questions, and so

289
00:18:05.671 --> 00:18:09.630
feel free to contact us, and
we'll see you in the next section.

290
00:18:09.630 --> 00:18:12.535
>> All right, Jo, well,
thank you again for

291
00:18:12.535 --> 00:18:16.910
helping us to round out our CSI
principles here in this part two.

292
00:18:16.910 --> 00:18:19.780
Remember that we did take
a look at the ways that

293
00:18:19.780 --> 00:18:24.110
we can have the improvement
using that demming step process.

294
00:18:24.110 --> 00:18:24.730
What do we call it?

295
00:18:24.730 --> 00:18:26.200
Demming cycle?

296
00:18:26.200 --> 00:18:26.848
>> Cycle.

297
00:18:26.848 --> 00:18:30.508
>> Cycle, using the demming cycle as well,
and taking a look, of course,

298
00:18:30.508 --> 00:18:33.448
as using frameworks, of course,
that help us to do this.

299
00:18:33.448 --> 00:18:35.538
As well as achieving
some of those standards,

300
00:18:35.538 --> 00:18:38.960
all these are good practices and
good things that we should review.

301
00:18:38.960 --> 00:18:43.725
Make sure those concepts are really
engrained in you before you get ready for

302
00:18:43.725 --> 00:18:47.312
the exam and then,
of course further on, ITIL studies.

303
00:18:47.312 --> 00:18:50.630
Well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode, then.

304
00:18:50.630 --> 00:18:54.147
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong,

305
00:18:54.147 --> 00:18:55.740
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

306
00:18:55.740 --> 00:18:59.108
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

307
00:18:59.108 --> 00:19:05.520
[MUSIC]

308
00:19:05.520 --> 00:19:08.791
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the Seven Step Improvement Process at a high level overview.  Jo explains the key to making CSI a reality revolve around the consistency in our approach to CSI.  She reviews the basic concepts and principles that should be included and shows how these 7 activities become inputs toward the rest of ITIL.
episodes.title: 7 Step Improvement Process
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:06.586
I'm your host, Don,
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.586 --> 00:00:08.288
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.288 --> 00:00:12.410
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.410 --> 00:00:14.910
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.910 --> 00:00:19.040
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate CSI show.

7
00:00:19.040 --> 00:00:20.590
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

8
00:00:20.590 --> 00:00:24.530
today we'll be taking a look at
the Seven Step Improvement Process.

9
00:00:24.530 --> 00:00:30.550
Here with us live from Downtown Abbey
is the aristocrat Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:30.550 --> 00:00:32.170
Joe, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:32.170 --> 00:00:33.070
>> Hi, Ronnie.

12
00:00:33.070 --> 00:00:35.010
Pleased to be here.
How are you?

13
00:00:35.010 --> 00:00:36.210
>> I am doing fine.

14
00:00:36.210 --> 00:00:39.813
Now, Jo we were joking about Downtown
Abbey a little bit before the show just

15
00:00:39.813 --> 00:00:40.720
briefly.

16
00:00:40.720 --> 00:00:45.330
So here we are, what we're talking now in
the CSI phase of what we're doing, and

17
00:00:45.330 --> 00:00:49.950
we're talking about
the Seven Step Improvement.

18
00:00:49.950 --> 00:00:56.330
Now Jo, does it really take seven steps
to do this continual service improvement?

19
00:00:56.330 --> 00:00:57.930
>> Well, yes it does.

20
00:00:57.930 --> 00:00:58.620
>> Okay.

21
00:00:58.620 --> 00:01:00.783
>> If you don't what
you're going to improve.

22
00:01:00.783 --> 00:01:03.370
>> Okay, well that sounds good.

23
00:01:03.370 --> 00:01:06.700
>> Quite often we
are presented with a problem.

24
00:01:06.700 --> 00:01:08.970
And we just don't know
what the problem is.

25
00:01:08.970 --> 00:01:12.030
We don't understand how we're
gonna make life better.

26
00:01:12.030 --> 00:01:15.300
And this is where the Seven Step
Improvement Process really comes in.

27
00:01:15.300 --> 00:01:17.580
So that's what we're going
to be looking at right now.

28
00:01:17.580 --> 00:01:21.590
If we look at just the purpose of
the Seven Step Improvement Process you'll

29
00:01:21.590 --> 00:01:26.030
see that the first step in this
process is actually to define.

30
00:01:27.550 --> 00:01:31.030
And that's the key to the Seven Step
Improvement Process is really just

31
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:35.180
understanding that sometimes
we know we need to improve but

32
00:01:35.180 --> 00:01:39.180
we don't know exactly what
we need to improve on.

33
00:01:39.180 --> 00:01:44.150
So the purpose really is just to define
and then manage the steps that are needed

34
00:01:44.150 --> 00:01:47.940
to identify and define and
gather and process, et cetera.

35
00:01:47.940 --> 00:01:50.440
And then implement improvements.

36
00:01:50.440 --> 00:01:55.061
So we use the Seven Step Improvement
Process a lot within CSI because we're

37
00:01:55.061 --> 00:01:59.384
quite often in a position where we
know we need to do things better, but

38
00:01:59.384 --> 00:02:01.535
we just don't know exactly what.

39
00:02:01.535 --> 00:02:04.180
Let me give you an example.

40
00:02:04.180 --> 00:02:06.070
Let's just say we've got a service desk.

41
00:02:06.070 --> 00:02:10.620
And we know that customer satisfaction
is low on the service desk, but

42
00:02:10.620 --> 00:02:11.620
we're not too sure why.

43
00:02:13.000 --> 00:02:14.250
And that's where we are.

44
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:18.740
And this is quiet often how our
improvements are generated.

45
00:02:18.740 --> 00:02:20.200
This is where we get the ideas for

46
00:02:20.200 --> 00:02:25.710
improvements from is that we know we
really have, it's not a technical problem,

47
00:02:25.710 --> 00:02:28.480
but we know that we've got
an issue that we need to resolve.

48
00:02:28.480 --> 00:02:31.580
And so the first thing that we need
to do is we need to workout, well,

49
00:02:31.580 --> 00:02:32.389
okay, what's wrong?

50
00:02:33.560 --> 00:02:36.960
And this is where we define and
then we go out and

51
00:02:36.960 --> 00:02:40.020
gather information that
will tell us what's wrong.

52
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:42.620
So that first objective
that you see on that screen

53
00:02:42.620 --> 00:02:45.840
there is about identifying
opportunities for improvement.

54
00:02:45.840 --> 00:02:50.190
That's exactly what the CSI Seven
Step Improvement Process will do,

55
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:54.020
will help us identify opportunities for
improvement.

56
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:57.130
Now, hopefully, if we take a look at the
rest of the objectives that are up on your

57
00:02:57.130 --> 00:03:02.700
screen there, you'll notice that other
objectives include reducing cost,

58
00:03:02.700 --> 00:03:05.400
reviewing service achievement.

59
00:03:05.400 --> 00:03:07.780
But really, look at the bottom
one under the objectives,

60
00:03:07.780 --> 00:03:11.850
understanding what we need to measure and
why we need to measure it.

61
00:03:11.850 --> 00:03:16.060
In other words, again making
sure that when we take a metric,

62
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:17.280
when we take any measurement,

63
00:03:17.280 --> 00:03:21.120
we're doing it for a reason because
we want to make an informed decision.

64
00:03:21.120 --> 00:03:27.290
In a previous session, we looked at
the knowledge management scale, the data,

65
00:03:27.290 --> 00:03:32.300
information, knowledge and wisdom, and the
fact that we will only take reports, and

66
00:03:32.300 --> 00:03:36.620
we only will analyze data if we
want to make an informed decision.

67
00:03:36.620 --> 00:03:38.745
And here we go it's, linked into CSI,

68
00:03:38.745 --> 00:03:43.225
it's all about making informed decisions
and about making improvements.

69
00:03:43.225 --> 00:03:47.005
And of course when we mean improvements we
mean aligning ourselves to the needs of

70
00:03:47.005 --> 00:03:50.065
the organization,
of the business, not just of IT.

71
00:03:51.330 --> 00:03:54.860
And so the scope there, when you look at
that second bullet point in the scope

72
00:03:54.860 --> 00:03:58.848
it talks about aligning ourselves
with the business needs.

73
00:03:58.848 --> 00:04:03.190
It means that we have to be organized in
order to meet the needs of the business

74
00:04:03.190 --> 00:04:07.820
and that we have to deliver the services,
and the processes, and

75
00:04:07.820 --> 00:04:13.580
all of the technologies, et cetera,
that will deliver value to the business.

76
00:04:13.580 --> 00:04:18.500
Let's remember that
a service defined in ITIL

77
00:04:18.500 --> 00:04:23.410
is a means of delivering value
by facilitating outcomes.

78
00:04:23.410 --> 00:04:26.340
So we want to facilitate
their business outcomes.

79
00:04:26.340 --> 00:04:30.820
We want to deliver value to them and
value, of course, is perceived.

80
00:04:30.820 --> 00:04:35.080
So quite often we will be faced with
a dilemma, such as I mentioned Ronnie,

81
00:04:35.080 --> 00:04:38.660
about the fact that the service
desk just isn't performing and

82
00:04:38.660 --> 00:04:40.450
we don't know what to do about it.

83

continually looking to see

315
00:18:40.160 --> 00:18:44.640
what is out there in the big wide world,
and what we can make use of.

316
00:18:44.640 --> 00:18:46.377
CSI is not something that's ad hoc,

317
00:18:46.377 --> 00:18:50.245
cuz when I mention continually,
I mean on a regular basis.

318
00:18:50.245 --> 00:18:55.062
So we should have tasks set for
absolutely everybody in our organization,

319
00:18:55.062 --> 00:18:57.895
our IT organization to
review what they do.

320
00:18:57.895 --> 00:19:01.795
And compare it against what's
happening in the big wide world

321
00:19:01.795 --> 00:19:03.805
outside of our organization.

322
00:19:03.805 --> 00:19:05.336
We should be doing that
on a regular basis, okay.

323
00:19:06.630 --> 00:19:11.420
We should be understanding what
we offer to our organization and

324
00:19:11.420 --> 00:19:13.080
what's available out there.

325
00:19:13.080 --> 00:19:16.350
In other words, what they can source
out there, that they can't get from us.

326
00:19:16.350 --> 00:19:21.058
Cuz that might be a key driver in
them making any decisions that might

327
00:19:21.058 --> 00:19:23.629
actually affect us in the long term.

328
00:19:25.100 --> 00:19:28.470
So CSI is not something that
you can do just as a one off.

329
00:19:28.470 --> 00:19:31.790
CSI is something that we have
to undertake regularly, okay.

330
00:19:33.350 --> 00:19:40.410
CSI features in management framework, so
process maturity framework, such as CMMI.

331
00:19:40.410 --> 00:19:44.820
Where we look at CSI as being
the pinnacle of maturity for any process.

332
00:19:44.820 --> 00:19:49.580
So we're continually looking to
improve any particular process and

333
00:19:49.580 --> 00:19:53.150
we should be doing that with our service
and our services and our technologies,

334
00:19:53.150 --> 00:19:54.710
etc as well.

335
00:19:54.710 --> 00:19:59.900
Now of course, you can't know whether
you can improve if you don't know

336
00:19:59.900 --> 00:20:06.000
how you're performing right now and this
is why we need to start with measurement.

337
00:20:06.000 --> 00:20:08.390
Start looking at where we are right now.

338
00:20:08.390 --> 00:20:11.830
But again, go back to knowledge
management and think about the fact

339
00:20:11.830 --> 00:20:16.120
that when you take any metric, it has to
enable you to make an informed decision.

340
00:20:16.120 --> 00:20:17.879
In other words,
it has to tell you something.

341
00:20:19.020 --> 00:20:24.021
So let's take a look at this CSI then
seven step improvement process, okay.

342
00:20:24.021 --> 00:20:26.940
And we start off right at the very top.

343
00:20:26.940 --> 00:20:29.459
Number one, with our vision.

344
00:20:31.170 --> 00:20:33.680
And we call this our strategy for
improvement.

345
00:20:33.680 --> 00:20:35.380
What is our vision?

346
00:20:35.380 --> 00:20:39.230
We have to know what
direction we're going in.

347
00:20:39.230 --> 00:20:41.340
If you don't know what
direction you're going in,

348
00:20:41.340 --> 00:20:45.560
then any data you gather could
just be meaningless data.

349
00:20:45.560 --> 00:20:50.160
And of course, if we go into step number
two, that's all about defining data.

350
00:20:50.160 --> 00:20:53.010
So let's take a look at
step number one then.

351
00:20:53.010 --> 00:20:54.050
Step number one, and

352
00:20:54.050 --> 00:20:57.630
we're gonna go through these in
more detail in our next session.

353
00:20:57.630 --> 00:21:01.790
But step number one talks about
identifying the strategy for improvement.

354
00:21:01.790 --> 00:21:03.400
And that strategy,

355
00:21:03.400 --> 00:21:07.880
as I've already mentioned is the service
desk is just not performing.

356
00:21:07.880 --> 00:21:09.130
Okay, we're just not well.

357
00:21:09.130 --> 00:21:10.630
No, that's wrong to say.

358
00:21:10.630 --> 00:21:13.520
The example that I gave you
with the service desk, well,

359
00:21:13.520 --> 00:21:16.240
our users just weren't happy with them.

360
00:21:16.240 --> 00:21:19.620
So that's our strategy is to
improve the service desk.

361
00:21:19.620 --> 00:21:20.770
But I don't know what's wrong.

362
00:21:21.800 --> 00:21:24.950
So now I'm gonna go and
define what I'm going to measure.

363
00:21:26.020 --> 00:21:29.310
By defining what I'm going to measure,
I'm going to say okay, so

364
00:21:29.310 --> 00:21:32.630
how do I know where I am right now?

365
00:21:32.630 --> 00:21:36.440
So I might look at things like
incident resolution rates.

366
00:21:36.440 --> 00:21:39.710
Right, are we achieving incident
resolution within those service level

367
00:21:39.710 --> 00:21:43.100
targets that are defined in the SLA, okay?

368
00:21:43.100 --> 00:21:47.600
Or I might look at the core value or
I might look at how quickly we're

369
00:21:47.600 --> 00:21:51.650
resolving telephone calls or how quickly
we're answering telephone calls.

370
00:21:51.650 --> 00:21:55.379
I might look at the called the queuing
rate, in other words how many people

371
00:21:55.379 --> 00:21:58.910
are sat in the queue or
system at any one point in time.

372
00:21:58.910 --> 00:22:03.698
I might actually look at say
the incident backlog for instance, okay.

373
00:22:04.780 --> 00:22:09.514
So here I am defining what
measurements I'm going to take,

374
00:22:09.514 --> 00:22:12.550
and then I go out and I gather the data.

375
00:22:12.550 --> 00:22:15.086
And the people that
are gonna be doing this for

376
00:22:15.086 --> 00:22:19.370
me in this particular example
are going to be service desk analysts.

377
00:22:19.370 --> 00:22:22.220
We may even have reporting analysts, okay.

378
00:22:22.220 --> 00:22:26.500
These are people that are going to go
out and just take that information.

379
00:22:26.500 --> 00:22:30.410
Event management is going to help us with
this because as a process event management

380
00:22:30.410 --> 00:22:32.470
will be doing a lot of monitoring.

381
00:22:32.470 --> 00:22:35.290
So they're going to
provide some input too.

382
00:22:35.290 --> 00:22:38.480
Service level management are gonna be
providing some input too because they're

383
00:22:38.480 --> 00:22:42.300
going to be telling us what
service level targets they have.

384
00:22:42.300 --> 00:22:46.370
So we might want to compare ourselves
against those service level targets.

385
00:22:46.370 --> 00:22:49.470
But of course, we're gonna be gathering
as I mentioned a lot of data that is

386
00:22:49.470 --> 00:22:51.400
not in the service level target.

387
00:22:51.400 --> 00:22:55.240
Data such as number of people in
the called queuing system at any point

388
00:22:55.240 --> 00:22:55.890
in time, etc.

389
00:22:56.920 --> 00:22:59.920
So here I go out and I gather the data.

390
00:22:59.920 --> 00:23:04.680
Now in that particular section there,
number three there,

391
00:23:04.680 --> 00:23:09.200
the second bullet point,
look at the word integrity.

392
00:23:09.200 --> 00:23:13.470
And that's a really key word is we've
got to ensure the integrity of the data.

393
00:23:13.470 --> 00:23:18.510
Okay and the integrity of that data,
if it's open to any type of,

394
00:23:18.510 --> 00:23:24.320
and I hate to use the word corruption,
but if it's used to any type of change,

395
00:23:24.320 --> 00:23:29.677
manual intervention, then we've got to
ensure that the integrity is intact, okay.

396
00:23:30.780 --> 00:23:36.610
Because if we're trying to achieve
a certain goal, then it's very,

397
00:23:36.610 --> 00:23:40.980
very easy for us to try and make the data
look as though we're achieving the goal.

398
00:23:40.980 --> 00:23:44.760
But as I always say,
I never wanna see a green in a slam chart.

399
00:23:44.760 --> 00:23:48.430
If I see a slam chart and everything
is all green, I will tell you that your

400
00:23:48.430 --> 00:23:51.998
measuring the wrong thing because
I wanna see areas for improvement.

401
00:23:51.998 --> 00:23:54.524
I donâ€™t wanna see that
everything is going great,

402
00:23:54.524 --> 00:23:57.928
cuz I guarantee Iâ€™ll walk out to
one of your customers and say, hey,

403
00:23:57.928 --> 00:24:00.830
is everything okay with IT,
and they wonâ€™t tell me that.

404
00:24:00.830 --> 00:24:07.090
So now once I've gathered the data,
then I'm going to process it.

405
00:24:07.090 --> 00:24:09.400
I'm going to categorize it,
that's what this really means.

406
00:24:09.400 --> 00:24:11.510
I'm going to format it, okay.

407
00:24:11.510 --> 00:24:16.280
I'm going to format and I'm going
to put in maybe days of the week,

408
00:24:16.280 --> 00:24:20.100
for instance, or
I might put it in hours of the day.

409
00:24:20.100 --> 00:24:22.050
This is where we just process the data and

410
00:24:22.050 --> 00:24:26.040
we'll have a data analyst
that's going to do that for us.

411
00:24:26.040 --> 00:24:26.850
Okay.

412
00:24:26.850 --> 00:24:29.080
And the data analyst might be
the service desk analyst or

413
00:24:29.080 --> 00:24:32.370
it might be a defined reporting analyst,
or a CSI analyst.

414
00:24:32.370 --> 00:24:35.160
Depends on the size of the organization
as to whoâ€™s going to be involved.

415
00:24:36.190 --> 00:24:38.320
And then I'm going to analyze the data.

416
00:24:38.320 --> 00:24:45.290
Now that analysis is where we come
up with exactly what's happening.

417
00:24:45.290 --> 00:24:47.390
That gives us the information,

418
00:24:47.390 --> 00:24:52.960
this is in our knowledge part where
already we've done the information part.

419
00:24:52.960 --> 00:24:57.250
If you look in the furthest
corners of the dotted line there,

420
00:24:57.250 --> 00:24:59.810
you'll see data information,
knowledge, and wisdom.

421
00:24:59.810 --> 00:25:02.050
That's from knowledge management.

422
00:25:02.050 --> 00:25:05.340
So we've done the information part,
in other words we've joined the dot,

423
00:25:05.340 --> 00:25:09.600
we've joined our relationships
together between our data sources, and

424
00:25:09.600 --> 00:25:11.040
now we're into analyzing it.

425
00:25:11.040 --> 00:25:14.790
This is where we put
the knowledge together.

426
00:25:14.790 --> 00:25:15.940
Okay.
And we'll analyze.

427
00:25:15.940 --> 00:25:20.080
So we can break it down and
we can see that, maybe for

428
00:25:20.080 --> 00:25:23.570
example, that we've got
an issue on a Monday morning.

429
00:25:23.570 --> 00:25:29.360
And that issue on a Monday morning
is quite simply the fact that well,

430
00:25:29.360 --> 00:25:33.280
Ronnie seems to not get through too
many phone calls on a Monday morning,

431
00:25:33.280 --> 00:25:36.400
yeah he's not too great at
answering the phone on a Monday.

432
00:25:36.400 --> 00:25:36.940
>> True.

433
00:25:36.940 --> 00:25:42.100
>> And this is why our customers are
particularly unhappy, because on a Monday

434
00:25:42.100 --> 00:25:47.550
morning we seem to have an extended number
of people in the call queuing system.

435
00:25:48.710 --> 00:25:52.720
So we present that information, normally
by the way of a nice pretty picture,

436
00:25:52.720 --> 00:25:56.810
to enable informed decision making,
thereby giving us wisdom.

437
00:25:56.810 --> 00:25:58.100
We present that information.

438
00:25:58.100 --> 00:26:01.130
And in this instance, it's probably gonna
be to the service desk manager, and

439
00:26:01.130 --> 00:26:05.359
the service desk manager is going to say,
okay, I see exactly where the problem is.

440
00:26:06.470 --> 00:26:08.580
And this is where we
implement the improvement.

441
00:26:08.580 --> 00:26:14.230
And at this point in time, we're kind of
now into that CSI approach where we're

442
00:26:14.230 --> 00:26:18.890
looking at, okay, so we know where we
are right now, now where do I want to be?

443
00:26:20.050 --> 00:26:21.720
And how am I going to get there?

444
00:26:21.720 --> 00:26:24.580
And in this instance,
we know that Ronnie is weird,

445
00:26:24.580 --> 00:26:30.220
he's not doing his work on a Monday
morning, okay, he's just not up to it.

446
00:26:30.220 --> 00:26:32.890
So what kind of improvements
do we want to implement?

447
00:26:32.890 --> 00:26:35.880
Well we might want to get him in and
out earlier on a Monday morning and

448
00:26:35.880 --> 00:26:37.260
give him more coffee.

449
00:26:37.260 --> 00:26:40.120
Okay that might be an option for us.

450
00:26:40.120 --> 00:26:43.380
So what we're going to do is we're
going to implement that improvement.

451
00:26:44.400 --> 00:26:46.550
And then we implement that improvement and

452
00:26:46.550 --> 00:26:51.230
we do check after we implemented
the improvement that it has worked.

453
00:26:52.960 --> 00:26:58.670
And that then helps us identify the
strategy for our next improvement because

454
00:26:58.670 --> 00:27:02.780
of course even with the CSI approach we
look at this and say well what's next?

455
00:27:02.780 --> 00:27:05.710
Okay because you never
ever want to stagnate.

456
00:27:07.120 --> 00:27:11.930
So that in a nutshell is the seven
step improvement process.

457
00:27:11.930 --> 00:27:14.680
We're going to go into each
step in non-excession.

458
00:27:14.680 --> 00:27:19.860
We're going to go into each step in
more detail, but I just want to.

459
00:27:19.860 --> 00:27:23.730
Before we close this particular
session I want to just take a look at

00:27:23.730 --> 00:27:27.010
the next slide that we have in front

461
00:27:27.010 --> 00:27:32.810
And it really just shows you
that at every single level,

462
00:27:32.810 --> 00:27:37.290
at every single level
we have an input into,

463
00:27:38.500 --> 00:27:41.860
well I was going to say
hierarchical levels above.

464
00:27:41.860 --> 00:27:45.570
So if you look at step six, and
I'm going to bring up the previous slide,

465
00:27:45.570 --> 00:27:48.630
step six here presenting that information.

466
00:27:48.630 --> 00:27:52.040
Presenting that information that tells me

00:27:52.040 --> 00:27:56.390
that Ronnie's not particularly
great on a Monday morning, okay?

468
00:27:56.390 --> 00:28:01.980
Well, that is actually an input into
what we call the tactical level.

469
00:28:01.980 --> 00:28:06.400
And that could be an input into
the gathering the data at tactical level.

470
00:28:06.400 --> 00:28:09.780
And at tactical level our management
might decide, well, actually,

471
00:28:09.780 --> 00:28:13.160
maybe the right place for
Ronnie is not on the service desk.

472
00:28:14.760 --> 00:28:18.850
And again they're going to do exactly

473
00:28:18.850 --> 00:28:22.770
And we can see that Ronnie's not
particularly performing well.

474
00:28:22.770 --> 00:28:28.090
And therefore in step six at a tactical
level the suggestion might be after

475
00:28:28.090 --> 00:28:32.900
analyzing the data that actually maybe
Ronnie might be suited somewhere else.

476
00:28:32.900 --> 00:28:36.640
And that will then feed into the strategy,
and maybe the strategy for

477
00:28:36.640 --> 00:28:37.260
the service desk.

478
00:28:37.260 --> 00:28:42.820
Or maybe the strategy for third level guys
because they had their eye on Ronnie for

479
00:28:42.820 --> 00:28:45.040

they're really desperate to have him.

480
00:28:46.650 --> 00:28:49.610
So every single output from the seven
step improvement process is

481
00:28:49.610 --> 00:28:53.070
going to be an input
into another improvement.

482
00:28:53.070 --> 00:28:57.830
And this is what we are trying
to tell you by use of

483
00:28:57.830 --> 00:29:01.040
that particular slide is that
nothing's done in isolation.

484
00:29:01.040 --> 00:29:08.050
CSI, ultimately, cannot be, as we've
already said, an ad-hoc one of activity.

485
00:29:08.050 --> 00:29:09.870
It has to be something
that's continual and

486
00:29:09.870 --> 00:29:12.580
all of our improvements
are linked together.

487
00:29:12.580 --> 00:29:17.490
So, now that we've taken a look at
the seven step improvement process

488
00:29:17.490 --> 00:29:22.020
just from a very, very high level,
we're going to expand in the next session.

489
00:29:22.020 --> 00:29:24.340
We're going to expand on
each one of those steps.

490
00:29:24.340 --> 00:29:26.400
And we're just gonna take
you a little bit further,

491
00:29:26.400 --> 00:29:30.240

into the identify in the strategy, etc.

492
00:29:30.240 --> 00:29:31.960
And then gather in information.

00:29:41.320 --> 00:29:45.670

497
00:29:45.670 --> 00:29:48.860

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the 7 step improvement process in more depth. Jo also helps us to under the gathering of data and use of monitoring technology metrics, process metrics and service metrics.  Then lastly, she identifies the processing of data.
