00:30:32.620 --> 00:30:35.140
All of that data that we
gathered in step three.

491
00:30:36.165 --> 00:30:39.330
And what comes out, well,

492
00:30:39.330 --> 00:30:44.510
that's the process data that we then
start to analyze in our next step,

493
00:30:44.510 --> 00:30:47.870
as it says there, groupings of data,
logical groupings of data.

494
00:30:48.920 --> 00:30:49.880
And in our next step,

495
00:30:49.880 --> 00:30:55.420
we go on to look at analysis techniques
and how we might analyze that data.

496
00:30:55.420 --> 00:30:58.700
So for this particular session,
we're just gonna take a break.

497
00:31:00.010 --> 00:31:03.980
And at this point in time,
what I really need everybody to do, is to

498
00:31:03.980 --> 00:31:08.680
just go back over the first four steps of
our seven step improvement process, and

499
00:31:08.680 --> 00:31:11.410
just make sure you are familiar with that.

500
00:31:11.410 --> 00:31:16.700
And in our next session, we are going to
move on from steps five through to seven,

501
00:31:16.700 --> 00:31:18.250
and then, again,

502
00:31:18.250 --> 00:31:23.290
back to step number one again because
this is a continual improvement process.

503
00:31:24.458 --> 00:31:28.790
>> All right Jo, well thank you again for
helping us to dive a bit deeper into,

504
00:31:28.790 --> 00:31:31.300
of course, these seven steps that

505
00:31:31.300 --> 00:31:34.970
will help us to continue that cycle
of improvement that we need to.

506
00:31:34.970 --> 00:31:36.160
Remember to take a look at that and

507
00:31:36.160 --> 00:31:41.100
make sure that those are, kind of really
internalized into your study as well.

508
00:31:41.100 --> 00:31:44.012
And that will help you to proceed on.

509
00:31:44.012 --> 00:31:46.200
All right, well that's a great place for
us to also end this up.

510
00:31:46.200 --> 00:31:50.870
So then, signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

511
00:31:50.870 --> 00:31:52.110
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

512
00:31:52.110 --> 00:31:56.764
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the ITIL intermediate CSI show.

513
00:31:56.764 --> 00:32:03.180
[MUSIC]

514
00:32:03.180 --> 00:32:05.674
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the with some of the other activities in the 7 step improvement process.  Jo begins with explains analyzing data and information in CSI.  She discusses the usage of reports to help make more informed decisions.  Lastly, she discusses implementing improvements.
episodes.title: 7 Step Improvement Process Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.484
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.484 --> 00:00:10.547
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:10.547 --> 00:00:14.690
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.690 --> 00:00:18.850
You're watching the ITIL
intermediate CSI show.

5
00:00:18.850 --> 00:00:20.750
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

6
00:00:20.750 --> 00:00:25.920
we're jumping into a part three on
the seven-step improvement process.

7
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:27.930
And here to help us,
of course, is gonna be, well,

8
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:31.010
our ITIL commissar herself, Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:31.010 --> 00:00:32.012
Jo, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:32.012 --> 00:00:33.460
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Thank you very much for

11
00:00:33.460 --> 00:00:34.630
having me, Ronnie.

12
00:00:34.630 --> 00:00:36.720
How are you?
>> I am doing fine.

13
00:00:36.720 --> 00:00:40.754
Now, Jo, we've already been taking
a look at a deep dive here,

14
00:00:40.754 --> 00:00:42.730
on some of these different processes.

15
00:00:42.730 --> 00:00:44.920
We've gone through the first four steps.

16
00:00:44.920 --> 00:00:49.640
So we are now ready to actually
jump into the last few.

17
00:00:49.640 --> 00:00:51.583
Jo, where are we going to begin now?

18
00:00:51.583 --> 00:00:54.334
>> Okay.
Well, let's just take a quick recap as to

19
00:00:54.334 --> 00:00:57.649
what the seven-step improvement
process is all about, and

20
00:00:57.649 --> 00:01:00.750
that should be on your screen right now.

21
00:01:00.750 --> 00:01:05.870
And you will see that we start off with
identifying what it is we want to improve.

22
00:01:05.870 --> 00:01:09.290
And we started off in the last
two sessions actually looking at

23
00:01:09.290 --> 00:01:11.430
the challenge with the service desk.

24
00:01:11.430 --> 00:01:15.540
We're not actually achieving what
our organization thinks we should be

25
00:01:15.540 --> 00:01:17.540
achieving, or at least they're not happy.

26
00:01:17.540 --> 00:01:21.560
So, then we defined what we were going to
measure, and of course in the previous

27
00:01:21.560 --> 00:01:25.530
session we looked more in-depth at
actually the realities behind that.

28
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:28.280
And it's not just about what
measurements we can take, but

29
00:01:28.280 --> 00:01:31.630
making sure that they're aligned
with the organization's vision.

30
00:01:31.630 --> 00:01:36.050
And it's not just about the fact that
our customer satisfaction ratings aren't

31
00:01:36.050 --> 00:01:39.910
very high, but we have to think about
the direction of the organization too.

32
00:01:39.910 --> 00:01:44.990
And the simple fact that those two
objectives might actually be conflicting.

33
00:01:44.990 --> 00:01:47.840
And then we went out, and we gathered
the data, and we looked at the type of

34
00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:52.750
tools etc that we would use in gathering
in the data, and then we processed it.

35
00:01:52.750 --> 00:01:58.770
And now, here we are, in step five,
where we are actually analyzing the data.

36
00:02:00.710 --> 00:02:04.480
Without analysis,
it says here we have information.

37
00:02:04.480 --> 00:02:06.920
But with analysis we have knowledge.

38
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:11.010
In other words, if we don't do anything
with that data that we've got, we've added

39
00:02:11.010 --> 00:02:16.420
in the relationship, so we've processed
the data, and that gives us information.

40
00:02:16.420 --> 00:02:17.420
It tells us something.

41
00:02:17.420 --> 00:02:23.750
But if we don't do anything with that
data, then it's just, well, taking data

42
00:02:23.750 --> 00:02:27.760
for the sake of taking data, and reports
just for the sake of having reports.

43
00:02:27.760 --> 00:02:29.290
Well, they're a waste of time and

44
00:02:29.290 --> 00:02:32.170
they certainly are not going
to be efficient, okay?

45
00:02:32.170 --> 00:02:36.300
And they are not going to lead us to be
efficient and effective in delivering

46
00:02:36.300 --> 00:02:40.920
our services, or rather delivering
value and facilitating those outcomes.

47
00:02:40.920 --> 00:02:45.246
So the kind of questions that we
might want to ask are things around,

48
00:02:45.246 --> 00:02:47.300
say, trending, for instance.

49
00:02:47.300 --> 00:02:50.540
Are these good trends or
bad trends, positive or negative?

50
00:02:50.540 --> 00:02:53.690
Are we heading in a downward slope or
an upward trend?

51
00:02:55.010 --> 00:02:58.020
Are we meeting the needs of
the organisation that we've defined in

52
00:02:58.020 --> 00:02:59.210
the SLA?

53
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:02.230
You know,
is everything running according to plan?

54
00:03:02.230 --> 00:03:04.470
That can be a little bit
of an ambiguous one,

55
00:03:04.470 --> 00:03:06.770
what does running according to plan mean?

56
00:03:06.770 --> 00:03:09.769
Well, only you know that
answer to that one.

57
00:03:10.890 --> 00:03:16.210
Now, I mentioned that in the last session,
when we looked at step four,

58
00:03:16.210 --> 00:03:21.190
that you are going to process
the data based on your organization.

59
00:03:21.190 --> 00:03:24.340
You're gonna have your own methods,
your own techniques.

60
00:03:24.340 --> 00:03:29.300
But you're also going to do that based on
what the vision for this improvement is.

61
00:03:29.300 --> 00:03:33.220
And so we analyze the data, understanding
the vision for the improvement.

62
00:03:33.220 --> 00:03:36.930
We don't just need to
analyze it in terms of trends

63
00:03:36.930 --> 00:03:38.890
if we're not interested in trends.

64
00:03:38.890 --> 00:03:42.480
If what we're interested in is, say, well,

65
00:03:42.480 --> 00:03:46.450
improving customer satisfaction,
do we need to look at trends?

66
00:03:47.848 --> 00:03:51.270
Bearing in mind that in the last
two sessions, part one and

67
00:03:51.270 --> 00:03:56.490
part two, we've looked at, you know,
the ability to answer the telephone.

68
00:03:56.490 --> 00:04:01.380
But then I've also mentioned
that the organizational

69
00:04:01.380 --> 00:04:05.340
direction is to move away
from answering the telephone.

70
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:08.860
So if the trend's showing us that the
number of telephone calls, well, actually

71
00:04:08.860 --> 00:04:13.830
the number of telephone calls that
are waiting in the queue is increasing.

72
00:04:13.830 --> 00:04:17.710
But the number of telephone calls coming
into the service desk is decreasing,

73
00:04:17.710 --> 00:04:20.090
is that valuable information to us?

74
00:04:20.090 --> 00:04:21.230
You could argue, well, yes,

75
00:04:21.230 --> 00:04:25.320
it is, because it shows us that
our vision is actually working.

76
00:04:25.320 --> 00:04:28.520
But no, it isn't,
because people are still waiting.

77
00:04:28.520 --> 00:04:29.920
Now, I've heard things.

78
00:04:29.920 --> 00:04:33.210
I've heard people say to me, well,
yeah, but we want them to wait,

79
00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:36.790
because then hopefully, that will prompt
them to actually get their app out.

80
00:04:36.790 --> 00:04:41.680
Or maybe it'll prompt them to email you,
but that's not, let's face it,

81
00:04:41.680 --> 00:04:46.110
that is not a best practice in
terms of the business environment.

82
00:04:46.110 --> 00:04:47.710
We don't want people to wait.

83
00:04:47.710 --> 00:04:50.500
That is going to cause them to be unhappy.

84
00:04:50.500 --> 00:04:53.210
However we analyze the data,
the fact of the matter is,

85
00:04:53.210 --> 00:04:57.534
we have to analyze the data in order
to be able to make a decision from it.

86
00:04:57.534 --> 00:05:02.360
And only you will understand what
you want to do with that data, and

87
00:05:02.360 --> 00:05:04.300
what decisions you want to make.

88
00:05:04.300 --> 00:05:07.740
And therefore only you will
understand how you analyze that data.

89
00:05:07.740 --> 00:05:11.670
And of course, it has to be aligned
with the vision for that improvement.

90
00:05:13.730 --> 00:05:17.320
So then we present the information, and
we always say that we present this by way

91
00:05:17.320 --> 00:05:21.230
of a nice pretty picture,
generally it's by way of a graph.

92
00:05:21.230 --> 00:05:25.330
So action plans, reporting.

93
00:05:25.330 --> 00:05:31.180
I expect to see lots of graphs in this
particular section here in this step.

94
00:05:31.180 --> 00:05:33.590
We might be reporting on an exception.

95
00:05:33.590 --> 00:05:36.130
We might be reporting for trends.

96
00:05:36.130 --> 00:05:39.480
We might be reporting on benefits, okay.

97
00:05:39.480 --> 00:05:42.549
Think about who our audience is.

98
00:05:44.640 --> 00:05:49.500
I'm gonna ask you a question Ronnie, and
it's something that I talk about a lot

99
00:05:49.500 --> 00:05:52.790
throughout ITIL, because it's really,
really, important.

100
00:05:52.790 --> 00:05:54.500
But I'm gonna ask you a question.

101
00:05:54.500 --> 00:05:59.450
So if I am sending a report to somebody,
what language,

102
00:05:59.450 --> 00:06:02.400
then, do you think that
report should be in?

103
00:06:03.550 --> 00:06:04.988
>> What language should it be.

104
00:06:04.988 --> 00:06:09.747
>> [SOUND] [LAUGH]
>> It should be in a language that they

105
00:06:09.747 --> 00:06:11.370
understand.

106
00:06:11.370 --> 00:06:15.120
>> Right, exactly, the first,
the first response,

107
00:06:15.120 --> 00:06:17.280
I always get to this, is English.

108
00:06:17.280 --> 00:06:21.150
Well, that's great, okay, but
if they don't understand English,

109
00:06:21.150 --> 00:06:22.640
then that's not going to help.

110
00:06:22.640 --> 00:06:23.760
And I mean, let's face it,

111
00:06:23.760 --> 00:06:26.620
there's a different version of
English here to the one that I speak.

112
00:06:26.620 --> 00:06:27.160
>> Right.

113
00:06:27.160 --> 00:06:28.080
>> Right?
Which is completely

114
00:06:28.080 --> 00:06:29.360
different to the one that you speak.

115
00:06:29.360 --> 00:06:30.405
>> Correct.
>> As well, right?

116
00:06:30.405 --> 00:06:32.350
[LAUGH] We both use different words.

117
00:06:32.350 --> 00:06:35.370
The key is that it should be in
the language of the audience, okay?

118
00:06:35.370 --> 00:06:36.865
>> Right.
>> Whoever you're reporting to,

119
00:06:36.865 --> 00:06:42.380
that's whose language you
need to be reporting in.

120
00:06:43.380 --> 00:06:44.670
Why does that make any difference?

121
00:06:44.670 --> 00:06:47.840
Well, think about our audiences
that we've got labelled there.

122
00:06:47.840 --> 00:06:49.470
You've got customer language.

123
00:06:49.470 --> 00:06:53.120
Customers are interested in whether it's
effective and whether it's efficient.

124
00:06:53.120 --> 00:06:57.350
So they are interested in whether we're
meeting these agreed targets that we

125
00:06:57.350 --> 00:06:58.940
have with them.

126
00:06:58.940 --> 00:07:01.060
Senior management,
what are they interested in?

127
00:07:01.060 --> 00:07:05.630
Well, senior management, they want
to see what we're doing about it.

128
00:07:06.790 --> 00:07:11.880
If we're presenting them with any graph or
any report, the first question

129
00:07:11.880 --> 00:07:16.160
that comes out of their mind is, what is
this telling me, and what do I need to do?

130
00:07:17.320 --> 00:07:19.800
That's what they want to know.

131
00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:22.900
Internal IT, I expect that to
be in a technical language.

132
00:07:22.900 --> 00:07:24.650
They want to see the nuts and bolts.

133
00:07:24.650 --> 00:07:27.790
They want to see exactly
where the challenge is.

134
00:07:27.790 --> 00:07:32.290
They want to see
the individual pieces of data.

135
00:07:32.290 --> 00:07:33.760
They want a breakdown.

136
00:07:33.760 --> 00:07:35.490
They want the analysis.

137
00:07:35.490 --> 00:07:36.790
Our suppliers.

138
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:38.320
Well, we have a contract with them.

139
00:07:38.320 --> 00:07:40.280
A legally binding contract.

140
00:07:40.280 --> 00:07:43.819
So they want to know what changes
there needs to be to that contract.

141
00:07:43.819 --> 00:07:48.950
Cuz if we're changing a contract, if
they're on the performing on the contract,

142
00:07:48.950 --> 00:07:53.859
for instance, if they need to make
changes, then don't forget we're talking

143
00:07:53.859 --> 00:07:58.795
legally binding here, so we have to
ensure that we manage this appropriately.

144
00:07:58.795 --> 00:08:06.702
Take a look at the little icon there that
says Let's Talk and let's have a think.

145
00:08:06.702 --> 00:08:08.808
As I say, let's think about this.

146
00:08:08.808 --> 00:08:14.312
The business isn't interested
in that 99% availability.

147
00:08:14.312 --> 00:08:19.021
They're not interested in how
available a service is they

148
00:08:19.021 --> 00:08:22.970
are interested in how
unavailable a service is.

149
00:08:22.970 --> 00:08:25.710
I'm gonna a show you a SLAM chart.

150
00:08:25.710 --> 00:08:28.190
This is a Service Level
Agreement Monitoring chart.

151
00:08:28.190 --> 00:08:31.614
We normally call this a RAG chart.

152
00:08:31.614 --> 00:08:35.280
Now RAG chart means Red,
Amber, Green okay.

153
00:08:35.280 --> 00:08:37.060
Which are traffic lights.

154
00:08:37.060 --> 00:08:38.956
Well actually they're traffic lights for
me okay.

155
00:08:38.956 --> 00:08:42.046
>> [LAUGH]
>> In the states they call it yellow.

156
00:08:42.046 --> 00:08:42.976
>> Yellow.

157
00:08:42.976 --> 00:08:43.998
>> Yeah, yeah,.

158
00:08:43.998 --> 00:08:46.242
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's not go there,

159
00:08:46.242 --> 00:08:48.690
we're talking about language,
let's not go there, okay.

160
00:08:48.690 --> 00:08:51.622
Because RUG chart doesn't
sound quite right, does it?

161
00:08:51.622 --> 00:08:54.479
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, we'll stick with RAG, okay, red,

162
00:08:54.479 --> 00:08:55.990
amber, green.

163
00:08:55.990 --> 00:08:57.505
Unfortunately, this one is in black and
white.

164
00:08:57.505 --> 00:08:58.080
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

165
00:08:58.080 --> 00:09:00.030
>> So we're looking at gray,

166
00:09:00.030 --> 00:09:01.350
gray, and gray.

167
00:09:01.350 --> 00:09:04.410
No, with a bit of white
thrown in there too.

168
00:09:04.410 --> 00:09:05.086
I'm not interested.

169
00:09:05.086 --> 00:09:07.630
If I see your RAG chart.

170
00:09:07.630 --> 00:09:11.160
Now, normally that white
would be displayed green.

171
00:09:11.160 --> 00:09:14.458
I'm not interested in where
I'm meeting my targets.

172
00:09:14.458 --> 00:09:16.906
I'm interested in the amber,
or the orange, or

173
00:09:16.906 --> 00:09:18.888
the yellow whatever you wanna call it.

174
00:09:18.888 --> 00:09:20.050
I'm interested in the red.

175
00:09:20.050 --> 00:09:23.970
I'm interested in where we threaten
the target, in other words,

176
00:09:23.970 --> 00:09:25.512
when we nearly breached.

177
00:09:25.512 --> 00:09:28.282
And I'm interested in where
we did actually breach.

178
00:09:28.282 --> 00:09:30.310
That's what I'm interested in.

179
00:09:30.310 --> 00:09:33.248
These are my areas for improvement.

180
00:09:33.248 --> 00:09:36.440
These are my opportunities for
improvement.

181
00:09:36.440 --> 00:09:39.509
If you show me a SLAM
chart that is all green

182
00:09:40.830 --> 00:09:45.190
I will challenge anybody to show me to
show me a green RUG chart and I will

183
00:09:45.190 --> 00:09:49.790
go up to your customers and I will ask
them if they are happy with the service.

184
00:09:50.930 --> 00:09:55.760
And I will guarantee that your customers,
at least one of them, will come back and

185
00:09:55.760 --> 00:09:58.640
say, well, actually,
things would be better if.

186
00:10:00.680 --> 00:10:05.560
Because you see, they're not interested
in the fact that everything is

187
00:10:05.560 --> 00:10:08.040
meeting the availability targets.

188
00:10:08.040 --> 00:10:11.290
The only thing they remember
is that one time it failed.

189
00:10:11.290 --> 00:10:15.476
You see you never log on to your
PC first thing on the morning,

190
00:10:15.476 --> 00:10:20.238
on a Monday morning, and
think to yourself, hey this is fantastic,

191
00:10:20.238 --> 00:10:25.930
everything is available and everything
is working great, isn't it fantastic.

192
00:10:27.150 --> 00:10:29.444
No.
You log on to your PC on a Monday morning

193
00:10:29.444 --> 00:10:31.763
and you look at it and
you go, my goodness,

194
00:10:31.763 --> 00:10:34.950
something is not working,
what am I going to do about this?

195
00:10:36.410 --> 00:10:41.320
Because you never notice when
something's available, it's expected.

196
00:10:41.320 --> 00:10:45.106
You only notice when it's not available.

197
00:10:45.106 --> 00:10:48.615
So your customers and
your end users are not looking for

198
00:10:48.615 --> 00:10:52.816
availability targets,
they're looking for unavailability.

199
00:10:52.816 --> 00:10:56.834
They're looking at when something
is not meeting their expectation.

200
00:10:56.834 --> 00:10:59.894
So when we talk about
presenting information,

201
00:10:59.894 --> 00:11:04.270
only show people the information
that's important to them.

202
00:11:04.270 --> 00:11:09.100
If you show a customer a SLAM chart that's
all green, they won't believe you, and

203
00:11:09.100 --> 00:11:10.209
they won't care.

204
00:11:10.209 --> 00:11:14.317
Cuz what they actually wanted to see is
what you're doing about the time when

205
00:11:14.317 --> 00:11:15.610
something went wrong.

206
00:11:17.490 --> 00:11:21.098
It's really tempting to look at
an all green SLAM chart within IT and

207
00:11:21.098 --> 00:11:22.314
to say that's great.

208
00:11:22.314 --> 00:11:24.690
Everything's working
exactly as it should be.

209
00:11:24.690 --> 00:11:27.030
We're meeting all of our
service level targets, and

210
00:11:27.030 --> 00:11:30.370
therefore we're going to show them that
green SLAM chart, that green RAG chart,

211
00:11:30.370 --> 00:11:32.439
and we're gonna say,
hey everything's working great.

212
00:11:34.110 --> 00:11:38.900
And as I've said before I will challenge
you that there're always is an area for

213
00:11:38.900 --> 00:11:39.842
opportunity.

214
00:11:39.842 --> 00:11:44.603
So we should always think about when we
are presenting information we should think

215
00:11:44.603 --> 00:11:46.820
about what the audience wants to see.

216
00:11:46.820 --> 00:11:50.020
Your customer doesn't want to
see an all green SLAM chart.

217
00:11:50.020 --> 00:11:55.287
What they actually want to see Is where
your next improvement opportunity is.

218
00:11:55.287 --> 00:11:58.943
So, even if you're presented them
with an all agreen SLAM chart,

219
00:11:58.943 --> 00:12:02.970
because you have met all of
your service level targets.

220
00:12:02.970 --> 00:12:06.843
Then I would suggest you should also be
presenting something underneath that,

221
00:12:06.843 --> 00:12:10.080
that says okay, we've highlighted
this area for opportunity and

222
00:12:10.080 --> 00:12:11.954
that's what we're going to do next.

223
00:12:11.954 --> 00:12:16.755
Or maybe even we ascertained that our
service level targets are really not

224
00:12:16.755 --> 00:12:18.080
quite high enough.

225
00:12:18.080 --> 00:12:22.708
Because we'd like to highlight areas for
improvement.

226
00:12:22.708 --> 00:12:26.980
So therefore we'd like you to amend to
agree with us to amend the service level

227
00:12:26.980 --> 00:12:27.580
targets.

228
00:12:27.580 --> 00:12:31.388
So that it can actually show us
opportunities or improvement.

229
00:12:31.388 --> 00:12:36.519
An all green SLAM chart is not
something that we would expect to see

230
00:12:36.519 --> 00:12:42.598
on a regular basis, even though in IT,
we'd really, really like to see it.

231
00:12:42.598 --> 00:12:46.160
It doesn't really tell us much about
our delivery of value perception.

232
00:12:47.210 --> 00:12:49.915
So when we're presenting any information.

233
00:12:49.915 --> 00:12:52.500
Then, think about how we're presenting it.

234
00:12:52.500 --> 00:12:54.550
Think about who we're presenting it to.

235
00:12:54.550 --> 00:12:57.050
Are they actually going to
believe what's being presented?

236
00:12:57.050 --> 00:12:58.690
That's the first challenge.

237
00:12:58.690 --> 00:13:00.630
If it's all green, then probably not.

238
00:13:00.630 --> 00:13:03.740
But, also, think about what's in it for
that audience.

239
00:13:04.960 --> 00:13:06.630
Answer the question, what's in it for me?

240
00:13:07.650 --> 00:13:09.376
What do they need to know from that?

241
00:13:09.376 --> 00:13:13.240
Or more importantly what decision
do they need they need to make.

242
00:13:13.240 --> 00:13:17.966
If I am presenting a chart of
a graph to a senior IT manager,

243
00:13:17.966 --> 00:13:21.450
what decision am I expecting them to make?

244
00:13:21.450 --> 00:13:25.140
Because I've got to present it to them for
a reason.

245
00:13:25.140 --> 00:13:30.500
So underneath that particular graph I need
to not only highlight whatever it is that

246
00:13:30.500 --> 00:13:35.850
I'm showing, but I also need to
highlight what my recommendation is.

247
00:13:37.110 --> 00:13:39.376
What needs to happen.

248
00:13:39.376 --> 00:13:42.525
If I'm not putting that at
the bottom of my graph then I have

249
00:13:42.525 --> 00:13:45.990
to ask the question is that
graph really necessary?

250
00:13:45.990 --> 00:13:49.360
Because we've got to be able to
make in informed decision, and

251
00:13:49.360 --> 00:13:53.430
if you're presenting it to IT senior
management it's probably because you

252
00:13:53.430 --> 00:13:55.417
either want them to make a decision.

253
00:13:55.417 --> 00:13:59.408
Or you need their endorsement
because you've made the decision and

254
00:13:59.408 --> 00:14:03.270
you need them to endorse or
to concur with that decision.

255
00:14:03.270 --> 00:14:07.129
In which case,
then put that at the bottom of the graph.

256
00:14:07.129 --> 00:14:10.720
That's exactly what needs
to be there in the key.

257
00:14:10.720 --> 00:14:14.995
Because you see, you cannot implement
any improvement unless you know what

258
00:14:14.995 --> 00:14:17.686
the improvement is that
you want to implement.

259
00:14:17.686 --> 00:14:21.378
So the graphs that you present and
the pretty pictures as we've said that you

260
00:14:21.378 --> 00:14:25.360
present, well, you have to know what the
intention of what the intention of those

261
00:14:25.360 --> 00:14:29.190
pretty pictures are, in order to be
able to then implement that improvement.

262
00:14:30.400 --> 00:14:35.522
So we use all of that knowledge, and that
enables us to make that informed decision.

263
00:14:35.522 --> 00:14:41.750
Now improvement opportunities should
then be listed in our CSI register.

264
00:14:41.750 --> 00:14:45.740
I mentioned in the previous session,
the CSI register can be something very,

265
00:14:45.740 --> 00:14:46.900
very simple.

266
00:14:46.900 --> 00:14:48.270
Like a spreadsheet or

267
00:14:48.270 --> 00:14:53.860
it can be a database depend on the scale
of the organization and how mature.

268
00:14:53.860 --> 00:14:57.412
How well developed CSIA is
within the organization.

269
00:14:57.412 --> 00:14:59.336
It should be listed, and

270
00:14:59.336 --> 00:15:04.831
then we shouldn't prioritize that
improvement initiative based on,

271
00:15:04.831 --> 00:15:10.800
both impact to the organization and
impact to IT and also the urgency as well.

272
00:15:10.800 --> 00:15:13.585
Bearing in mind that whatever
changes we want to make and

273
00:15:13.585 --> 00:15:17.437
if we are improving the service desk,
and lets say for instance, that we know

274
00:15:17.437 --> 00:15:22.060
that Ronnie is not particularly hot as we
mentioned first thing on a Monday morning.

275
00:15:22.060 --> 00:15:24.961
Then the improvement might mean just
simply to bring in more coffee okay right.

276
00:15:26.080 --> 00:15:30.338
Well there shouldn't be any training or
any documentation involved in that but

277
00:15:30.338 --> 00:15:34.420
somebody needs to understand that Ronnie
needs more caffeine on a morning.

278
00:15:34.420 --> 00:15:38.409
Or the improvement initiative might be
to change the shift rotors around in

279
00:15:38.409 --> 00:15:42.791
the service desk, in which case then yes,
you need communication and training.

280
00:15:42.791 --> 00:15:46.760
But not only that you need buy in too.

281
00:15:46.760 --> 00:15:49.474
Because if people aren't brought
in to any improvement initiative,

282
00:15:49.474 --> 00:15:51.318
and we'll talk about
this in another section.

283
00:15:51.318 --> 00:15:54.307
But if people aren't brought in for
an improvement initiative,

284
00:15:54.307 --> 00:15:56.931
then that improvement
initiative isn't going to work.

285
00:15:56.931 --> 00:16:01.292
So, effective communication is
going to be really, really key.

286
00:16:01.292 --> 00:16:06.563
Think about, and here we talk
about language of interest, but

287
00:16:06.563 --> 00:16:14.090
think about on what level your improvement
initiative needs to be implemented.

288
00:16:14.090 --> 00:16:17.240
So, does it need to be implemented
in the bottom left hand

289
00:16:17.240 --> 00:16:20.260
corner there at operational level or

290
00:16:20.260 --> 00:16:23.330
does it need to be implemented in
the top right hand corner there.

291
00:16:23.330 --> 00:16:28.150
A sort of first level, as we call it
which is within the organization.

292
00:16:28.150 --> 00:16:32.380
Any improvement initiatives that we
implemented operational level should

293
00:16:33.900 --> 00:16:38.460
improve at the very top level
because that's what we want to do.

294
00:16:39.650 --> 00:16:43.820
Remember that vision to metrics tree that
we looked at in the previous sections.

295
00:16:43.820 --> 00:16:49.800
Everything should feed
up to the next layer up.

296
00:16:49.800 --> 00:16:53.730
Whether those KPIs feed into
our CSFs that tell us whether

297
00:16:53.730 --> 00:16:58.090
we're achieving that critical success
factor, which feed into our objectives,

298
00:16:58.090 --> 00:17:02.520
which feed into our goals and
then our vision and our mission, etc.

299
00:17:02.520 --> 00:17:08.963
Well, every single improvement should
have a direct link up to our vision.

300
00:17:08.963 --> 00:17:10.041
And therefore,

301
00:17:10.041 --> 00:17:15.835
every single improvement we make should
be seen at each consecutive level.

302
00:17:15.835 --> 00:17:18.028
But the same is true reversely too and

303
00:17:18.028 --> 00:17:22.840
any improvement that's made here right at
the very top in what we call business,

304
00:17:22.840 --> 00:17:25.834
the first level manager
should be filtered down.

305
00:17:25.834 --> 00:17:31.482
And we should be able to see that
at operational level as well.

306
00:17:31.482 --> 00:17:37.090
So CSI continual,
not continuous, continual.

307
00:17:37.090 --> 00:17:40.130
As we mentioned right at the very
introduction to continual service

308
00:17:40.130 --> 00:17:43.530
improvement, it's about intuitive,
ongoing improvement.

309
00:17:43.530 --> 00:17:46.500
This is not just a one off activity.

310
00:17:46.500 --> 00:17:52.190
And if we think about our
CSI seven step improvement

311
00:17:52.190 --> 00:17:56.670
process, it kind of ends with
number seven, doesn't it?

312
00:17:56.670 --> 00:18:01.600
No it doesn't, that arrow carries back
around to looking at the vision again.

313
00:18:01.600 --> 00:18:04.810
And we look at the vision, and
we look at the mission and again,

314
00:18:04.810 --> 00:18:09.390
we go back to identifying further
improvement opportunities, okay.

315
00:18:10.680 --> 00:18:14.625
So improvement should be as it says here,

316
00:18:14.625 --> 00:18:19.030
incremental okay, but they're not ad hoc.

317
00:18:19.030 --> 00:18:20.460
They shouldn't be ad hoc.

318
00:18:20.460 --> 00:18:22.150
It should be iterative.

319
00:18:22.150 --> 00:18:24.202
It should be repeatable, okay.

320
00:18:24.202 --> 00:18:28.345
CSI is something that should be
part of every single process and

321
00:18:28.345 --> 00:18:30.510
every single service.

322
00:18:30.510 --> 00:18:34.090
And the sense that improvement
process is just a technique

323
00:18:34.090 --> 00:18:38.130
that we will use to
implement improvements and

324
00:18:38.130 --> 00:18:41.977
to actually identify specific areas for
improvement, okay.

325
00:18:43.710 --> 00:18:46.820
So let's take a look then at our triggers,
and for

326
00:18:46.820 --> 00:18:49.199
the seven step improvement process.

327
00:18:50.880 --> 00:18:54.310
And our triggers to any
improvement initiative.

328
00:18:54.310 --> 00:18:56.850
Well, they could be started
off by our organization.

329
00:18:56.850 --> 00:19:01.420
And our organization will tell us
whether they are changing direction.

330
00:19:01.420 --> 00:19:04.870
Any change to the vision
of the organization

331
00:19:04.870 --> 00:19:08.460
is a change that we will
need to accommodate and

332
00:19:08.460 --> 00:19:13.947
that we will need to adopt within our
IT service provider organization, okay.

333
00:19:15.080 --> 00:19:18.270
So triggers could be a change
in business requirement.

334
00:19:18.270 --> 00:19:21.097
That's gonna come in from our business
relationship management, by the way, okay.

335
00:19:22.350 --> 00:19:27.010
That's not going to come in because
there's been a huge major announcement.

336
00:19:27.010 --> 00:19:29.710
That should come in way before
the major announcement, and

337
00:19:29.710 --> 00:19:32.626
that should come in via business
relationship management, okay.

338
00:19:34.220 --> 00:19:38.287
Other triggers to the seven step
improvement process include the example I

339
00:19:38.287 --> 00:19:41.656
gave you, such as low customer
satisfaction scores, okay.

340
00:19:41.656 --> 00:19:45.760
Or customer complaints,
as well as maybe incentivizing staff or

341
00:19:45.760 --> 00:19:50.550
maybe just something that is on the CSI
register as an area we need to look at.

342
00:19:52.100 --> 00:19:56.750
So, all of the inputs that we've got
listed here, are all going to help us not

343
00:19:56.750 --> 00:20:02.480
only identify areas for improvement or
opportunities for improvement,

344
00:20:02.480 --> 00:20:08.200
they're also going to help us
with gathering the data, as well.

345
00:20:08.200 --> 00:20:12.831
Because if we look at service level
requirements and service level catalog.

346
00:20:12.831 --> 00:20:17.248
And we look at some of our technology
exception, supply information,

347
00:20:17.248 --> 00:20:19.540
that's all part of data gathering.

348
00:20:19.540 --> 00:20:22.110
That's all part of the information
we want to pull in.

349
00:20:23.240 --> 00:20:26.422
So, all of these can not
only be triggers but

350
00:20:26.422 --> 00:20:29.698
they can also be inputs
into the process too.

351
00:20:29.698 --> 00:20:35.308
And then of course our output, our output
runs into our improvement data itself,

352
00:20:35.308 --> 00:20:40.840
that's the initiative, and that is
also the project plan for improving.

353
00:20:40.840 --> 00:20:46.530
Bear it in mind that step number
seven in that CSI process,

354
00:20:46.530 --> 00:20:50.580
well that might not
necessarily be a small step.

355
00:20:50.580 --> 00:20:55.101
Okay, that could be an improvement
initiative that could require a project to

356
00:20:55.101 --> 00:20:56.190
implement.

357
00:20:56.190 --> 00:21:01.360
It could be a project or improvement
initiative that lasts for an entire year.

358
00:21:01.360 --> 00:21:04.210
It's not necessarily something that's
just going to be very small but

359
00:21:04.210 --> 00:21:07.460
changing the shift routers on
the service desk for instance.

360
00:21:09.130 --> 00:21:15.630
So at this point in time, we've now looked
at our seven step improvement process.

361
00:21:15.630 --> 00:21:18.480
And what we're going to look
at in our next session,

362
00:21:18.480 --> 00:21:23.100
which will be our fourth part to the seven
step improvement process, is we're gonna

363
00:21:23.100 --> 00:21:27.850
look at the input from other life cycle
phases and from other processes as well.

364
00:21:27.850 --> 00:21:31.840
So we're going to look at what say
business relationship management can do

365
00:21:31.840 --> 00:21:34.930
for us and what service level
management can do for us.

366
00:21:34.930 --> 00:21:37.340
So we're gonna take a look at
that over the next session so

367
00:21:37.340 --> 00:21:42.860
what I'd like you to do right now is just
to take a look back over this session and

368
00:21:42.860 --> 00:21:44.500
the previous two sessions.

369
00:21:44.500 --> 00:21:46.960
Familiarize yourself
with those seven steps.

370
00:21:46.960 --> 00:21:51.220
Because that's going to help us as we
move forward into the next session,

371
00:21:51.220 --> 00:21:54.020
where we look at where
we get our data from.

372
00:21:55.340 --> 00:21:57.380
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for

373
00:21:57.380 --> 00:22:02.190
helping us to round out our deep dive
into these seven steps just a little bit.

374
00:22:02.190 --> 00:22:04.640
We're not completely done yet,
as Jo has been saying.

375
00:22:04.640 --> 00:22:07.780
We've still got at least
one more process or

376
00:22:07.780 --> 00:22:10.470
one more step that we need
to take a look at as well.

377
00:22:10.470 --> 00:22:14.660
But in this episode you take a look at
some of the analysis that we had to do

378
00:22:14.660 --> 00:22:16.070
as well as presenting and

379
00:22:16.070 --> 00:22:20.310
even the idea here of implementing
the improvements that need to be done.

380
00:22:20.310 --> 00:22:23.820
So remember that and there's actually more
to come, so this is a great place for

381
00:22:23.820 --> 00:22:25.190
us to end this episode.

382
00:22:25.190 --> 00:22:28.530
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong

383
00:22:28.530 --> 00:22:29.700
>> and I'm Jo Peacock

384
00:22:29.700 --> 00:22:31.688
>> Stay tuned right here for

385
00:22:31.688 --> 00:22:34.913
more of the ITIL intermediate CSI show.

386
00:22:34.913 --> 00:22:40.986
[MUSIC]

387
00:22:40.986 --> 00:22:44.113
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the how the the other Service Lifecycle Phase provides the input for CSI.  She also discusses the different management activities that help with different part os the 7 step improvement process.  Jo discusses the csfs and kpis along with the challenges and risk of CSI Integration.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:03.456
Welcome to ITProTV,

2

>> Welcome to another great

6
00:00:15.020 --> 00:00:19.310
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate CSI show.

7
00:00:19.310 --> 00:00:20.950
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:20.950 --> 00:00:23.610
And we are now actually
going to be taking a look

9
00:00:23.610 --> 00:00:27.500
at finishing up the seven step
continual improvement process.

10
00:00:27.500 --> 00:00:31.890
And here to help us out and round out our
particular knowledge and skills in this,

11
00:00:31.890 --> 00:00:36.680
is going to be, well,
the macado herself in ITIL, Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:36.680 --> 00:00:38.020
Jo, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:38.950
>> Thank you, Ronnie.

14
00:00:38.950 --> 00:00:39.870
How are you?

15
00:00:39.870 --> 00:00:40.650
>> I am doing fine.

16
00:00:40.650 --> 00:00:45.100
Now, Jo, we've spent a lot of time
in diving into the seven steps, and

17
00:00:45.100 --> 00:00:49.150
in our previous episode we actually
finished those seven steps, but

18
00:00:49.150 --> 00:00:51.462
we're still in a part
four on the seven steps.

19
00:00:51.462 --> 00:00:56.940
So, Jo, I don't know but
that sounds like at least eight to me.

20
00:00:56.940 --> 00:00:58.240
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] No,

21
00:00:58.240 --> 00:01:02.590
what we're actually doing right now is if
we take a look at the seven step process

22
00:01:02.590 --> 00:01:07.170
itself, you can see all of these steps,
we have to get our input from somewhere.

23
00:01:07.170 --> 00:01:10.580
And so what we're going to do
in this particular session is,

24
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:16.800
we're just going to look at the other
processes in the other life cycle phases.

25
00:01:16.800 --> 00:01:20.190
And we're just going to really ask
the question, how do they contribute

26
00:01:20.190 --> 00:01:23.580
to all of these steps that you
see in front of you right now?

27
00:01:23.580 --> 00:01:26.560
So how do they contribute to
identifying the strategy?

28
00:01:26.560 --> 00:01:30.590
How do they contribute towards
defining what we're going to measure?

29
00:01:30.590 --> 00:01:32.560
And then gathering the data, etc.

30
00:01:32.560 --> 00:01:37.230
Okay, so what we're really gonna do is
just look at the interfaces between

31
00:01:37.230 --> 00:01:41.120
all of our other lifecycle phases and
all of our other processes.

32
00:01:41.120 --> 00:01:43.940
Because you see if we take
a look at this right now and

33
00:01:43.940 --> 00:01:48.690
look at these other four lifecycle phases,
because obviously CSI is the fifth.

34
00:01:48.690 --> 00:01:53.060
In service strategy, well, that's where
we define all of our policies and

35
00:01:53.060 --> 00:01:56.970
where we make all of our decisions,
where we define our standards.

36
00:01:56.970 --> 00:02:01.880
But importantly for
this particular process, this is where

37
00:02:01.880 --> 00:02:07.520
we interpret the organization's
vision into a vision for IT.

38
00:02:07.520 --> 00:02:11.640
So, in business relationship management,
in the strategy management, and even in

39
00:02:11.640 --> 00:02:15.750
the processes of demand management,
we take the organization's vision and

40
00:02:15.750 --> 00:02:20.480
we take their way of working, and
we translate that into a vision for IT.

41
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:26.480
And then in service design, well,
service design we design our services and

42

the service desk more than incident
management will help us with reporting.

273
00:17:58.590 --> 00:18:03.150
I mentioned in a previous section
that our service desk will be

274
00:18:03.150 --> 00:18:07.720
the people that will actually have
compiled these reports for us, and

275
00:18:07.720 --> 00:18:12.770
will gather the data for us, and then we
will use either a service desk analyst or

276
00:18:12.770 --> 00:18:15.640
a reporting analyst to
analyze these reports.

277
00:18:16.750 --> 00:18:18.440
The service desks are really valuable.

278
00:18:19.890 --> 00:18:25.140
Because you see the service desk
understand our customers and our users.

279
00:18:25.140 --> 00:18:32.900
I like to think of the service
desk as a translation role.

280
00:18:32.900 --> 00:18:35.890
I was gonna say a tool, but
that's the wrong word to use.

281
00:18:35.890 --> 00:18:40.320
They act as a translator
between our users and IT.

282
00:18:41.600 --> 00:18:45.560
And so,
the service desk understand what format

283
00:18:45.560 --> 00:18:50.895
the graphs and the nice pretty pictures
that we wanna produce need to be in.

284
00:18:50.895 --> 00:18:55.270
They understand the question,
what's in for me?

285
00:18:55.270 --> 00:18:58.580
They know what's in it for
the customer and for the users, and

286
00:18:58.580 --> 00:19:02.540
therefore their best place to
produce that information and

287
00:19:02.540 --> 00:19:06.100
to display it in a way that
means something to the customer.

288
00:19:07.260 --> 00:19:09.240
And what about problem management then?

289
00:19:09.240 --> 00:19:13.750
Well, problem management, don't forget,
their role is to provide and

290
00:19:13.750 --> 00:19:18.520
to perform some root cause analysis,
get to the bottom of problems.

291
00:19:18.520 --> 00:19:20.950
So in terms of analyzing information,

292
00:19:20.950 --> 00:19:25.100
problem management is going
to be really key to this.

293
00:19:25.100 --> 00:19:26.535
Because problem management,

294
00:19:26.535 --> 00:19:31.780
they got all of those analysis
techniques that can help us with

295
00:19:31.780 --> 00:19:36.550
making recommendations when we want to
present and to use that information.

296
00:19:38.740 --> 00:19:40.430
And then what about
the other processes then?

297
00:19:40.430 --> 00:19:44.970
We mentioned change management
in a previous session.

298
00:19:44.970 --> 00:19:50.010
What I want to tell you is just to
reiterate really that every single

299
00:19:50.010 --> 00:19:55.350
improvement opportunity needs
to go through change management.

300
00:19:55.350 --> 00:19:57.720
It has to be controlled.

301
00:19:57.720 --> 00:20:02.720
That doesn't mean that we add in
bureaucracy, what it means is that we

302
00:20:02.720 --> 00:20:07.300
perform changes to our organization and

303
00:20:07.300 --> 00:20:12.590
to our infrastructure in a controlled and
a consistent manner.

304
00:20:12.590 --> 00:20:17.820
It doesn't mean that we add in red tape or
that we make the process lengthy.

305
00:20:17.820 --> 00:20:22.164
We use models to ensure the efficiency and

306
00:20:22.164 --> 00:20:26.640
the effectiveness of our changes, okay?

307
00:20:26.640 --> 00:20:30.790
So this is not about bureaucracy,
this is about control.

308
00:20:30.790 --> 00:20:36.176
And sometimes our changes are large
changes, they're improvements

309
00:20:36.176 --> 00:20:41.020
that need the evaluation of
the change advisory board, okay?

310
00:20:41.020 --> 00:20:46.130
So there is nothing wrong with
involving our CAB in our decisions.

311
00:20:47.300 --> 00:20:50.500
And then, of course, we mentioned
service level management, again.

312
00:20:50.500 --> 00:20:54.020
Well, when we talk about implementing the
improvements, service level management is

313
00:20:54.020 --> 00:20:59.270
going to help us because they speak
to our customers on a regular basis.

314
00:20:59.270 --> 00:21:03.680
They will help us prioritize our
improvement opportunities and

315
00:21:03.680 --> 00:21:06.650
they will help us with
the communication to our customers.

316
00:21:08.670 --> 00:21:13.140
So what our CSFs then, for
our seven step improvement process?

317
00:21:13.140 --> 00:21:15.400
These are our critical success factors.

318
00:21:15.400 --> 00:21:17.930
What is it that we have to achieve?

319
00:21:19.700 --> 00:21:24.070
Well, a CSF, as it says up there,
is something that has to happen.

320
00:21:24.070 --> 00:21:26.610
And a KPI will tell us whether
we are achieving that.

321
00:21:26.610 --> 00:21:30.642
And I've already mentioned in a previous
section that we should have at least two

322
00:21:30.642 --> 00:21:31.362
KPIs per CSF.

323
00:21:31.362 --> 00:21:37.208
When we looked at that vision to
metrics tree in the previous section,

324
00:21:37.208 --> 00:21:39.882
I said to you that for every CSF,

325
00:21:39.882 --> 00:21:43.970
we should have at least two to three KPIs,
okay?

326
00:21:43.970 --> 00:21:46.705
It says recommended no more
than two to five KPIs.

327
00:21:46.705 --> 00:21:53.380
I think more than five is a little bit,
how should we say, confusing?

328
00:21:53.380 --> 00:21:56.730
It can be, but
certainly they should be no less than two.

329
00:21:56.730 --> 00:22:01.260
My personal recommendation is around about
three to four, which is an optimum number.

330
00:22:03.950 --> 00:22:08.840
For CSF for seven step improvement
process, while the critical

331
00:22:08.840 --> 00:22:13.540
success factor is well, we've got to
identify improvement opportunities.

332
00:22:13.540 --> 00:22:18.820
And this is just examples by the way,
of CSFs for this individual process.

333
00:22:18.820 --> 00:22:22.310
Another CSF could be lower in
the cost of service provision.

334
00:22:22.310 --> 00:22:27.690
That could be something that
we've identified as needed for

335
00:22:27.690 --> 00:22:29.370
our IT organization.

336
00:22:29.370 --> 00:22:34.370
Or maybe that it's we are achieving
the required business outcomes from our IT

337
00:22:34.370 --> 00:22:35.950
services, okay.

338
00:22:35.950 --> 00:22:38.500
You will decide on your CSFs.

339
00:22:38.500 --> 00:22:42.590
And you will see here that even
though it says in the last bullet

340
00:22:42.590 --> 00:22:47.440
point in the last slide that we
wanna say two to five KPIs per CSF,

341
00:22:47.440 --> 00:22:52.930
you see just an example of
one KPI here for each CSF.

342
00:22:52.930 --> 00:22:57.240
These are just examples,
nothing more than that.

343
00:22:57.240 --> 00:23:01.700
These are just a recommendation based on

344
00:23:01.700 --> 00:23:06.460
what we talked about in the last few
sessions, nothing more than that.

345
00:23:06.460 --> 00:23:12.630
You will define for your organization
CSFs that are appropriate to you.

346
00:23:12.630 --> 00:23:16.270
We are not going to tell you what
your critical success factors are.

347
00:23:16.270 --> 00:23:18.100
That is entirely up to you.

348
00:23:19.200 --> 00:23:24.520
So lastly,
what is it then we have to got to overcome

349
00:23:24.520 --> 00:23:29.450
in order to be able to implement seven
step improvement process and CSI?

350
00:23:31.160 --> 00:23:33.900
Well, CSI has got to be seen as important.

351
00:23:34.990 --> 00:23:37.560
And that's the biggest challenge,
is that quite often,

352
00:23:37.560 --> 00:23:39.360
we just wanna get the job done.

353
00:23:40.410 --> 00:23:43.710
And we just wanna carry on
as we are right now, and

354
00:23:43.710 --> 00:23:46.910
as long as we haven't got any complaints,
then there's no reason to improve, right?

355
00:23:48.610 --> 00:23:51.872
An organization, and
I mean a service provider,

356
00:23:51.872 --> 00:23:55.135
an IT service provider as well,
any organization

357
00:23:55.135 --> 00:23:59.576
that doesn't seek to improve will
eventually start rolling back.

358
00:23:59.576 --> 00:24:04.025
Because in comparison to the rest of
the world, if you wanna stay here Well,

359
00:24:04.025 --> 00:24:04.798
guess what?

360
00:24:04.798 --> 00:24:07.984
The rest of the world is going here.

361
00:24:07.984 --> 00:24:11.272
And an organization that
stays here will end up

362
00:24:11.272 --> 00:24:15.670
comparatively rolling back as
the rest of the world moves on.

363
00:24:17.460 --> 00:24:22.820
CSI has to be seen as a very important
part of every single organization.

364
00:24:22.820 --> 00:24:25.220
And I mean service provider as well.

365
00:24:25.220 --> 00:24:30.180
We have to continually improve, because
if we don't, we'll start to move back.

366
00:24:30.180 --> 00:24:32.964
Quite often that's a challenge in itself,

367
00:24:32.964 --> 00:24:36.208
just convincing people
that CSI is really needed.

368
00:24:36.208 --> 00:24:37.690
Why can't we just stay where we are?

369
00:24:39.300 --> 00:24:42.048
And of course, once we've decided
that CSI is really needed,

370
00:24:42.048 --> 00:24:45.600
then there are certain risks
that could cause it to fail.

371
00:24:45.600 --> 00:24:47.870
Such as the fact that we
don't take it seriously,

372
00:24:47.870 --> 00:24:51.820
that we think that it's something that
just has to be done every now and then.

373
00:24:51.820 --> 00:24:55.830
And so, we don't have consistency,
and we don't have funding, and

374
00:24:55.830 --> 00:24:59.120
we don't have a need to do it.

375
00:24:59.120 --> 00:25:00.810
We don't see this.

376
00:25:00.810 --> 00:25:05.550
And therefore, that can cause CSI to
kinda fall by the wayside, really, and

377
00:25:05.550 --> 00:25:06.790
be forgotten about.

378
00:25:06.790 --> 00:25:11.790
And as I've already said,
an organization that stays where it is is

379
00:25:11.790 --> 00:25:17.595
an organization that will eventually
fall back in line with its competitors.

380
00:25:17.595 --> 00:25:21.260
And CSI's not just about
technological improvement.

381
00:25:21.260 --> 00:25:24.950
It's not just about having the latest and
greatest PCs.

382
00:25:24.950 --> 00:25:27.810
It's not just about having
the fastest servers.

383
00:25:27.810 --> 00:25:32.624
It's also about having the processes
in place to enable us to have

384
00:25:32.624 --> 00:25:36.575
the fastest servers and
the latest and greatest PCs.

385
00:25:36.575 --> 00:25:39.706
If you wanna buy the latest and
greatest PC,

386
00:25:39.706 --> 00:25:45.260
then you've gotta have that right
relationship with our suppliers.

387
00:25:45.260 --> 00:25:47.817
To enable us to buy them efficiently and

388
00:25:47.817 --> 00:25:50.999
cost-effectively, as we
might wanna call it.

389
00:25:50.999 --> 00:25:55.915
So we have to have the right processes in
place to be able to support all of our

390
00:25:55.915 --> 00:25:58.140
technology as well.

391
00:25:58.140 --> 00:26:04.670
So in order for CSI to work,
it has to be embedded into our culture.

392
00:26:06.010 --> 00:26:10.880
CSI has to be seen as being
an important part of who

393
00:26:10.880 --> 00:26:13.280
we are as an IT service provider.

394
00:26:13.280 --> 00:26:18.730
And even when we look at CMMI and
when we look at the usage of the CMMI

395
00:26:19.750 --> 00:26:24.270
tool to analyze our process maturity,

396
00:26:24.270 --> 00:26:29.250
we'll see that the pinnacle of CMMI,
number five on the CMMI chart is

397
00:26:29.250 --> 00:26:34.990
actually the adoption of CSI
within every single process.

398
00:26:34.990 --> 00:26:40.800
So CSI is really important and
will help us remain competitive,

399
00:26:40.800 --> 00:26:47.350
both as a service provider and
also as a organization,

400
00:26:47.350 --> 00:26:49.847
out in the big wide world
in the marketplace.

401
00:26:51.140 --> 00:26:57.750
So what I would like you to do is
I would like you now to review

402
00:26:57.750 --> 00:27:02.580
what you have learned in the last four
sections as we looked at the CSI process.

403
00:27:02.580 --> 00:27:09.195
You have some exercises within your
material that you've downloaded.

404
00:27:09.195 --> 00:27:11.952
I'd like you to take those exercises now.

405
00:27:11.952 --> 00:27:14.870
It takes you around about an hour to

406
00:27:14.870 --> 00:27:17.472
one hour 30 minutes to
undertake the exercises.

407
00:27:17.472 --> 00:27:19.435
I'm available.

408
00:27:19.435 --> 00:27:23.255
We're here on our forum, so
please, if you have any questions,

409
00:27:23.255 --> 00:27:27.835
any queries at all about those exercises,
then please come back to us.

410
00:27:27.835 --> 00:27:31.785
Let us know, and we'll be happy to respond
to any queries that you might have.

411
00:27:33.145 --> 00:27:34.975
>> All right, Jo, well,
thank you again for

412
00:27:34.975 --> 00:27:40.300
helping us to see where CSI is really
getting all of the inputs from those other

413
00:27:40.300 --> 00:27:44.350
phases in the service life cycles that
we've been looking at previously as well.

414
00:27:44.350 --> 00:27:47.890
It really does help to be able to see
how it all integrates together and

415
00:27:47.890 --> 00:27:49.800
fits in the way that we need to.

416
00:27:49.800 --> 00:27:53.950
And the idea that I've also pulled away
from this is that an entire organization,

417
00:27:53.950 --> 00:27:58.720
even without CSI, is probably not
going to actually be improving

418
00:27:58.720 --> 00:28:01.560
not only not improving but
maybe even falling backward.

419
00:28:01.560 --> 00:28:04.230
>> And that maybe something that we all
have to think about before we move on.

420
00:28:04.230 --> 00:28:08.590
But that's also a great place for
us to end this episode too.

421
00:28:08.590 --> 00:28:12.660
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

422
00:28:12.660 --> 00:28:13.730
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

423
00:28:13.730 --> 00:28:19.071
>> Stay tuned right here,
there are more CSI shows coming your way.

424
00:28:19.071 --> 00:28:24.834
[MUSIC]

425
00:28:24.834 --> 00:28:28.083
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Jo take a look at using a CSI technique of assessments.  She describes the purpose, the usage and output of assessments.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Assessments
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.771
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.771 --> 00:00:06.352
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.352 --> 00:00:08.482
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.482 --> 00:00:12.520
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.520 --> 00:00:15.960
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.960 --> 00:00:19.404
You're watching the ITIL
intermediate CSI show.

7
00:00:19.404 --> 00:00:21.278
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:21.278 --> 00:00:24.302
And today we're taking a look
at different CSI techniques and

9
00:00:24.302 --> 00:00:26.233
we're gonna begin with assessments.

10
00:00:26.233 --> 00:00:31.337
And here to help us out is going to be
our ITIl's arena herself, Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:31.337 --> 00:00:34.138
Jo, welcome back to our show
>> Thank you for having me Ronnie.

12
00:00:34.138 --> 00:00:34.974
How are you?

13
00:00:34.974 --> 00:00:36.631
>> All right Joe, here we are,

14
00:00:36.631 --> 00:00:40.170
we have taken a look at a lot
of different things so far.

15
00:00:40.170 --> 00:00:43.763
And now we're moving into
the realm of CSI techniques,

16
00:00:43.763 --> 00:00:46.372
and we are beginning with assessments.

17
00:00:46.372 --> 00:00:49.110
Why is it so important that we start
with the idea of assessments Jo?

18
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:55.163
>> Well a lot of improvement
initiatives are born out of the fact

19
00:00:55.163 --> 00:00:57.998
that we need to improve obviously.

20
00:00:57.998 --> 00:01:01.270
An improvement means aligned
to the needs of the business.

21
00:01:01.270 --> 00:01:03.472
And before we can make any improvement,

22
00:01:03.472 --> 00:01:06.775
we have to really understand
exactly where we are right now,

23
00:01:06.775 --> 00:01:10.789
in order to us retain whether we
are aligned to the business, or whether we

24
00:01:10.789 --> 00:01:15.040
need to make improvements in order to be
aligned to the needs of the business.

25
00:01:15.040 --> 00:01:19.740
So an assessment really is a look
at where we are right now.

26
00:01:19.740 --> 00:01:21.909
What is our starting point?

27
00:01:21.909 --> 00:01:24.824
And we can assess in many different ways,
and

28
00:01:24.824 --> 00:01:28.060
we can assess on many different things,
as well.

29
00:01:28.060 --> 00:01:30.502
We're not just talking about
assessment of our processes.

30
00:01:30.502 --> 00:01:34.372
We could be talking about assessment
of our services, also even our people,

31
00:01:34.372 --> 00:01:37.630
too and we'll get into that
in a little bit more detail.

32
00:01:37.630 --> 00:01:41.615
But what we're really aiming for
is complete and utter, total,

33
00:01:41.615 --> 00:01:45.033
continual alignment to
the needs of the organization.

34
00:01:45.033 --> 00:01:48.940
And in order to do that,
we understand that we have to improve,

35
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:53.388
because the organization changes and
so we'll always have to change.

36
00:01:53.388 --> 00:01:57.273
And therefore, we need to understand
where we are right now and

37
00:01:57.273 --> 00:02:00.365
that's really what
an assessment will do for us.

38
00:02:00.365 --> 00:02:04.643
>> All right Jo, so when we start taking
a look at this idea of an assessment,

39
00:02:04.643 --> 00:02:09.410
does it really come down to let's say
it's like a paper exam that I sit for?

40
00:02:09.410 --> 00:02:13.422
Are you just gonna hand me out or
my organization as like, fill out this and

41
00:02:13.422 --> 00:02:14.405
I'll grade you?

42
00:02:14.405 --> 00:02:16.597
Ronnie, you've made a failing grade.

43
00:02:16.597 --> 00:02:19.123
>> Well, the only answer I've
got to that is it depends.

44
00:02:19.123 --> 00:02:19.915
>> Okay.

45
00:02:19.915 --> 00:02:22.545
>> [LAUGH] It completely depends
on the type of assessment that we

46
00:02:22.545 --> 00:02:23.720
want to undertake.

47
00:02:23.720 --> 00:02:28.495
Not all assessments are tested for
legislative requirements or for

48
00:02:28.495 --> 00:02:32.525
adherence to international standards,
for instance.

49
00:02:32.525 --> 00:02:36.988
We could also be assessing for not only
our alignment to the organization, but

50
00:02:36.988 --> 00:02:40.369
also our alignment to, say,
corporate requirements, or

51
00:02:40.369 --> 00:02:43.625
government's requirements,
ethical requirements.

52
00:02:43.625 --> 00:02:45.538
Or perhaps even our own policies and

53
00:02:45.538 --> 00:02:48.970
our own procedures within our processes or
within our teams.

54
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:52.610
So an assessment can be carried
out a variety of levels,

55
00:02:52.610 --> 00:02:55.641
every single level
within the organization.

56
00:02:55.641 --> 00:03:01.093
And it can be carried out on both
processes, on services as well.

57
00:03:01.093 --> 00:03:06.423
Also on our alignment, we can compare
ourselves to an industry standard,

58
00:03:06.423 --> 00:03:10.520
we can compare ourselves
to our competitors as well.

59
00:03:10.520 --> 00:03:15.034
So an assessment can be carried
out at a multitude of levels with

60
00:03:15.034 --> 00:03:18.965
a multitude of results coming
out of that assessment.

61
00:03:18.965 --> 00:03:23.102
And it really depends on what we
want the assessment to show us,

62
00:03:23.102 --> 00:03:26.860
as to how we assess and
whether we do it on a piece of paper.

63
00:03:27.920 --> 00:03:29.282
>> All right Jo, so let's take for

64
00:03:29.282 --> 00:03:33.075
example what you're talking about in terms
of different compliance assessments here.

65
00:03:33.075 --> 00:03:38.760
If we were to do that, is it that we're
then focusing in on just that one area?

66
00:03:38.760 --> 00:03:41.914
Or when we start talking about
the CSI assessment here,

67
00:03:41.914 --> 00:03:44.408
that we're talking about multiple areas?

68
00:03:44.408 --> 00:03:47.862
So is this an all or nothing, or
are we really able to divide it up and

69
00:03:47.862 --> 00:03:50.540
say, here's what I really
need an assessment on?

70
00:03:50.540 --> 00:03:53.224
>> Right, well you're kinda
jumping ahead of me here.

71
00:03:53.224 --> 00:03:54.276
>> I'm sorry.

72
00:03:54.276 --> 00:03:57.056
>> Because I'm gonna talk a little
bit more about that in a second.

73
00:03:57.056 --> 00:04:00.390
The first thing we gotta understand
is really what an assessment is.

one of the cons as we say,

300
00:17:25.567 --> 00:17:28.926
of using a self assessment technique.

301
00:17:28.926 --> 00:17:33.236
In the lower half of that slide there
you've got performance self assessment,

302
00:17:33.236 --> 00:17:37.689
and we've got pros and cons there to self
assessments and to external resources.

303
00:17:37.689 --> 00:17:42.535
You see, one of the cons of using a or
the negative side,

304
00:17:42.535 --> 00:17:47.899
the downside to using an internal
person to do an assessment or

305
00:17:47.899 --> 00:17:52.459
group of people is that
lack of objectivity, okay?

306
00:17:52.459 --> 00:17:56.449
It's very, very subjective viewpoint,
which means that

307
00:17:56.449 --> 00:18:01.097
you're subject to internal politics and
maybe little acceptance.

308
00:18:01.097 --> 00:18:04.867
And of course we've got to free you
up to do that assessment but then,

309
00:18:04.867 --> 00:18:07.150
you can use somebody external to come in.

310
00:18:07.150 --> 00:18:12.727
And then of course look at the pros
of using somebody external.

311
00:18:12.727 --> 00:18:17.393
We've got the objectivity, we've got
the the knowledge and somebody whose

312
00:18:17.393 --> 00:18:22.721
knowledgeable on techniques etc., as well,
and they've also got the credibility.

313
00:18:22.721 --> 00:18:27.226
But then look at the cons of
bringing in somebody external which

314
00:18:27.226 --> 00:18:29.865
are the pros of doing it internally.

315
00:18:29.865 --> 00:18:34.251
Because bringing in somebody
external is going to cost money and

316
00:18:34.251 --> 00:18:39.045
they don't have that knowledge of
the environment itself to be able to

317
00:18:39.045 --> 00:18:41.741
give you a very in-depth assessment.

318
00:18:41.741 --> 00:18:44.376
And of course, they might not be
there to see it through to the end.

319
00:18:44.376 --> 00:18:49.369
So they don't really get involved
in the result of the assessment.

320
00:18:49.369 --> 00:18:54.032
But then that could also be seen as
being a pro to using self assessment or

321
00:18:54.032 --> 00:18:59.098
an internal assessment, and that's
gotta gonna be seen through to the end.

322
00:18:59.098 --> 00:19:02.206
If somebody internal does the assessment,

323
00:19:02.206 --> 00:19:07.672
it's not gonna cost us anything other
than just resources, freeing you up.

324
00:19:07.672 --> 00:19:14.876
But it's actually going to, well not
necessarily give us that objectivity.

325
00:19:14.876 --> 00:19:19.631
The way that we would normally work
this is that in an organization a self

326
00:19:19.631 --> 00:19:24.307
assessment as we call it would normally
be done by somebody external as

327
00:19:24.307 --> 00:19:26.069
a starting point, okay?

328
00:19:26.069 --> 00:19:32.049
And then, as we move into that sort of,
into looking at assessment in more depth

329
00:19:32.049 --> 00:19:37.229
then we want to actually make progress
along a route of improvement,

330
00:19:37.229 --> 00:19:41.546
then we bring in somebody
external to do the assessment.

331
00:19:41.546 --> 00:19:44.617
We'd also bring in an external
consultant to do an assessment

332
00:19:44.617 --> 00:19:47.579
where we simply didn't have
the skills in-house as well.

333
00:19:47.579 --> 00:19:52.417
And where we really wanted to bring
in somebody with that credible sort

334
00:19:52.417 --> 00:19:56.689
of viewpoint, an unbiased,
impartial viewpoint in there.

335
00:19:56.689 --> 00:19:58.568
You have to outweigh the pros and

336
00:19:58.568 --> 00:20:02.197
cons before you make any decision
as to who is going to assess.

337
00:20:02.197 --> 00:20:06.170
Ideally an assessment should
be an objective view.

338
00:20:06.170 --> 00:20:09.742
Ideally, we don't want a subjective view.

339
00:20:09.742 --> 00:20:13.388
But as it says there under the risks,
okay?

340
00:20:13.388 --> 00:20:18.510
It shouldn't be just a one-off
activity that we undertake.

341
00:20:18.510 --> 00:20:23.492
And if we're bringing in somebody
external, it's going to give us that

342
00:20:23.492 --> 00:20:28.556
objective view, then it's probably
going to be just a one off exercise,

343
00:20:28.556 --> 00:20:32.578
because it's going to be
expensive to bring somebody in.

344
00:20:32.578 --> 00:20:36.170
So we've got to be really,
really careful with assessments,

345
00:20:36.170 --> 00:20:39.510
because an assessment will tell
us where we are right now.

346
00:20:39.510 --> 00:20:44.489
But you've got to make sure that you get
that objective viewpoint to allow us to

347
00:20:44.489 --> 00:20:46.158
then make improvements.

348
00:20:46.158 --> 00:20:49.682
So I've mentioned a number of occasions
both in previous sessions and

349
00:20:49.682 --> 00:20:51.366
also in this session about CMMI.

350
00:20:51.366 --> 00:20:56.595
And CMMI is just a standard,
it's on the next slide here,

351
00:20:56.595 --> 00:21:01.307
CMMI is a standard for
process improvement really.

352
00:21:01.307 --> 00:21:04.938
It's a maturity model as it's called for
process improvements.

353
00:21:04.938 --> 00:21:08.494
Now you will see that in those processes

354
00:21:08.494 --> 00:21:13.034
we will assess every process
on a scale of 0 to 5.

355
00:21:14.180 --> 00:21:17.512
And if we can just expand that slide,
you'll see this, so

356
00:21:17.512 --> 00:21:18.876
we start off with zero.

357
00:21:18.876 --> 00:21:21.180
Zero is a non existent process, okay?

358
00:21:21.180 --> 00:21:23.310
The process doesn't exist at all, okay?

359
00:21:23.310 --> 00:21:26.797
And I'm going to use incident
management as an example here.

360
00:21:26.797 --> 00:21:30.550
So zero means that that
process doesn't exist.

361
00:21:30.550 --> 00:21:37.576
One means that, okay, the process is
there, and it's probably ad hoc, okay?

362
00:21:37.576 --> 00:21:41.007
So it's done just purely
done on an ad hoc basis,

363
00:21:41.007 --> 00:21:43.694
it is not done in a consistent manner.

364
00:21:43.694 --> 00:21:48.120
Number two, so
a level two means repeatable.

365
00:21:48.120 --> 00:21:52.503
So there's some consistency there,
there's probably going to

366
00:21:52.503 --> 00:21:57.214
be some documentation and there that,
well it is repeatable, okay?

367
00:21:57.214 --> 00:22:01.791
But nevertheless it would still
be considered potentially to be

368
00:22:01.791 --> 00:22:06.000
somewhat ad hoc,
certainly not well developed.

369
00:22:06.000 --> 00:22:08.854
Now, three means that it
should be consistent,

370
00:22:08.854 --> 00:22:12.556
there should be a standard approach and
should be documented.

371
00:22:12.556 --> 00:22:16.063
And that's in level three for
process maturity.

372
00:22:16.063 --> 00:22:19.102
Level four means that its managed.

373
00:22:19.102 --> 00:22:22.618
So not only is documented,
not only it consistent but

374
00:22:22.618 --> 00:22:27.153
actually somebody is managing
the process to ensure that it works and

375
00:22:27.153 --> 00:22:29.828
that it's delivering the objectives.

376
00:22:29.828 --> 00:22:35.424
Now level five, well that means
that we've got CSI involved, okay?

377
00:22:35.424 --> 00:22:40.162
And CSI, well,
we're here to make sure that that process

378
00:22:40.162 --> 00:22:44.623
stays aligned to the needs
of he organization, okay?

379
00:22:44.623 --> 00:22:48.924
So it says that processes are considered
best practice through improvement.

380
00:22:48.924 --> 00:22:52.620
That's best practice for
your organization.

381
00:22:52.620 --> 00:22:56.035
That's not, that doesn't mean that they've
been copied out of the ideal publications

382
00:22:56.035 --> 00:22:58.784
and you've implemented them, and
hey, look, they're gonna work.

383
00:22:58.784 --> 00:23:02.214
No, what it means is that they're
best practice for your organization.

384
00:23:02.214 --> 00:23:07.143
So they are constantly being
checked on a continual basis for

385
00:23:07.143 --> 00:23:11.397
alignment with the needs
of the organization and for

386
00:23:11.397 --> 00:23:14.117
efficiency and effectiveness.

387
00:23:14.117 --> 00:23:16.067
Do we want all of our
processes though Ronnie?

388
00:23:16.067 --> 00:23:17.828
Do you think they should
be at number five?

389
00:23:17.828 --> 00:23:19.748
>> Ideally, yes.

390
00:23:19.748 --> 00:23:23.180
[LAUGH]
>> No.

391
00:23:23.180 --> 00:23:24.628
>> Well, there you go.

392
00:23:24.628 --> 00:23:26.848
>> [LAUGH] Is the answer to that.

393
00:23:26.848 --> 00:23:29.592
We have to think about this logically.

394
00:23:29.592 --> 00:23:30.096
>> Okay.

395
00:23:30.096 --> 00:23:33.775
>> All right, we don't always
wanna use all of our processes.

396
00:23:33.775 --> 00:23:35.070
>> Yeah.

397
00:23:35.070 --> 00:23:42.235
>> So we only want those processes that
we're going to use to be at level five.

398
00:23:42.235 --> 00:23:47.675
Those processes that we don't use,
they don't need to be at level five,

399
00:23:47.675 --> 00:23:50.943
depending on the size of the organization.

400
00:23:50.943 --> 00:23:55.443
In a small organization, we might not
actually have a separate process of demand

401
00:23:55.443 --> 00:23:58.563
management, it might be part
of capacity management.

402
00:23:58.563 --> 00:24:03.327
In which case, then, we don't need to
have demand management as level five.

403
00:24:03.327 --> 00:24:03.928
Okay.

404
00:24:03.928 --> 00:24:08.255
>> And if we look at the slide or
the graph that's in front of us here,

405
00:24:08.255 --> 00:24:13.170
you'll see, where we really need to
be is this white band in the middle.

406
00:24:13.170 --> 00:24:14.720
That's where we need to be.

407
00:24:14.720 --> 00:24:18.770
Where if a process is of low
value to the organization,

408
00:24:18.770 --> 00:24:21.520
then it really just needs
to have low maturity.

409
00:24:21.520 --> 00:24:26.700
And if a process is of a high value,
that's when it should have high maturity.

410
00:24:26.700 --> 00:24:29.740
So if we're not using demand management,

411
00:24:29.740 --> 00:24:32.550
then it should be down here in
this bottom left hand corner.

412
00:24:33.600 --> 00:24:38.421
If we are using demand management,
then, well, the greater importance it

413
00:24:38.421 --> 00:24:43.450
is to the organization,
then the higher the maturity it should be.

414
00:24:43.450 --> 00:24:48.350
So you'll see here that service level
management in this particular graph,

415
00:24:48.350 --> 00:24:49.970
that's at an optimum level.

416
00:24:49.970 --> 00:24:55.317
In other words, it has sort of,
well, a kind of midrange value.

417
00:24:55.317 --> 00:24:58.920
And it's between a 2 and
a 3 in terms of maturity.

418
00:24:58.920 --> 00:25:03.408
But availability management and
capacity management have a high value, but

419
00:25:03.408 --> 00:25:05.347
they're very immature, okay?

420
00:25:05.347 --> 00:25:10.365
So the idea is that with our processes,
it really is down to what

421
00:25:10.365 --> 00:25:15.300
the organization requires and
what the organization needs.

422
00:25:15.300 --> 00:25:20.100
And if we don't need
a process to be mature,

423
00:25:20.100 --> 00:25:24.360
then it's not efficient for
us to have that maturity on level five.

424
00:25:25.910 --> 00:25:30.938
So I go back to that last slide, and
the question that I asked you was,

425
00:25:30.938 --> 00:25:33.645
do we want everything at level five?

426
00:25:33.645 --> 00:25:36.593
And the answer that we've gotta have is-
>> No!

427
00:25:36.593 --> 00:25:38.547
>> No, right, exactly.

428
00:25:38.547 --> 00:25:42.971
Okay, think about the value
to the organization.

429
00:25:42.971 --> 00:25:45.450
So what do we use an assessment for?

430
00:25:45.450 --> 00:25:49.275
Well, we use an assessment as a benchmark,
okay?

431
00:25:49.275 --> 00:25:52.885
So as an assessment of where we
are right now as a baseline,

432
00:25:52.885 --> 00:25:55.395
that's the word I was looking for, okay?

433
00:25:55.395 --> 00:25:57.615
And a baseline is just
where we are right now.

434
00:25:57.615 --> 00:26:01.810
And we will use an assessment
to perform a gap analysis, and

435
00:26:01.810 --> 00:26:07.970
a gap analysis is a technique where
we look at where we want to be.

436
00:26:07.970 --> 00:26:13.060
And we will compare where we are right now
against where we want to be in the future.

437
00:26:14.410 --> 00:26:19.370
So for example,
we're doing a process maturity assessment

438
00:26:19.370 --> 00:26:23.800
here in that previous example, then if I
take a look at this previous example, and

439
00:26:23.800 --> 00:26:29.410
you see on this graph here,
availability management is, well.

440
00:26:29.410 --> 00:26:33.077
Look at it, we've got high value
to the organization, or kind of

441
00:26:33.077 --> 00:26:37.828
medium to high value to the organization
but yet it's very, very long on maturity.

442
00:26:37.828 --> 00:26:42.225
So where we actually want to be, if I can
get my arrow, here we go, we want to be,

443
00:26:42.225 --> 00:26:47.570
well, if this is where it is in terms of
value, then I wanna be over here with it.

444
00:26:47.570 --> 00:26:49.200
So this is my gap.

445
00:26:49.200 --> 00:26:52.225
My gap is from here,
availability management,

446
00:26:52.225 --> 00:26:54.449
right where you see to here, okay?

447
00:26:54.449 --> 00:26:56.257
There's my gap analysis and

448
00:26:56.257 --> 00:27:00.710
that shows me that I need to have
availability management at level 4.

449
00:27:00.710 --> 00:27:05.966
Now, capacity management, if I take this
line across, then capacity management,

450
00:27:05.966 --> 00:27:09.628
I actually want to be here,
which is about a four and a half.

451
00:27:09.628 --> 00:27:12.221
So now I know I've got my gap analysis,

452
00:27:12.221 --> 00:27:17.252
I've got both of these processes that
are on between levels one and two, and

453
00:27:17.252 --> 00:27:22.219
I actually want one of them on level four,
and one of them on four and a half.

454
00:27:22.219 --> 00:27:22.930
So that's my gap.

455
00:27:24.160 --> 00:27:29.950
And my gap analysis then looks at where
I am right now, where I want to be,

456
00:27:29.950 --> 00:27:33.980
and then, okay, this is where we
start on our CSI approach, and

457
00:27:33.980 --> 00:27:36.940
we say, right, okay, so
how do I get there, okay?

458
00:27:36.940 --> 00:27:41.990
So my CSI approach when I bring into this,
my CSI approach started off with

459
00:27:41.990 --> 00:27:47.460
my vision and then my second step in my
CSI approach was, where am I right now?

460
00:27:47.460 --> 00:27:49.308
That's my assessment.

461
00:27:49.308 --> 00:27:52.941
And now I look at where do I want
to be before I move onto well,

462
00:27:52.941 --> 00:27:54.563
okay, how do I get there?

463
00:27:54.563 --> 00:27:57.391
And then, of course, we look back and
say, well, did we get there?

464
00:27:57.391 --> 00:28:01.400
And again, there's another assessment
that we take at that point in time.

465
00:28:02.890 --> 00:28:04.880
So, this gap analysis then.

466
00:28:04.880 --> 00:28:08.760
Well, this gap analysis can be conducted
on processes, as we've already

467
00:28:08.760 --> 00:28:12.720
talked about, but it actually can be
conducted in terms of technology.

468
00:28:12.720 --> 00:28:14.720
Think about the assessments that we do.

469
00:28:14.720 --> 00:28:18.241
We do processes, but we do people and
processes and technology.

470
00:28:18.241 --> 00:28:22.330
It can even be in organizational
direction and culture as well.

471
00:28:23.390 --> 00:28:26.080
You even got a mention
there of human resources.

472
00:28:26.080 --> 00:28:29.500
It's about the number of people
that we have as well as the skills,

473
00:28:29.500 --> 00:28:33.440
as well as their culture, too.

474
00:28:33.440 --> 00:28:38.780
So we can assess at any particular level,
and then we can use that to assist

475
00:28:38.780 --> 00:28:44.740
with a gap analysis that will allow us to
highlight exactly where we want to be.

476
00:28:44.740 --> 00:28:49.590
Now something else that we use
assessments for is for benchmarking.

477
00:28:49.590 --> 00:28:53.950
And when we come back in our next session,
we're going to look a lot further into

478
00:28:53.950 --> 00:28:58.769
benchmarking and benchmarking techniques,
and also the value of benchmarking.

479
00:28:59.856 --> 00:29:01.810
>> All right, Jo, well,
thank you again for

480
00:29:01.810 --> 00:29:05.180
helping us to at least get started
in understanding the idea of using

481
00:29:05.180 --> 00:29:10.010
assessments as a formal approach to help
us in our continual service improvement.

482
00:29:10.010 --> 00:29:12.270
It is something that we
need to take seriously and

483
00:29:12.270 --> 00:29:16.540
to actually understand the value
that it has to our business as well.

484
00:29:16.540 --> 00:29:19.580
And Jo has helped us out
by explaining that to us.

485
00:29:19.580 --> 00:29:22.040
All right, well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

486
00:29:22.040 --> 00:29:25.740
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

487
00:29:25.740 --> 00:29:26.830
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

488
00:29:26.830 --> 00:29:30.760
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

489
00:29:30.760 --> 00:29:37.214
[MUSIC]

490
00:29:37.214 --> 00:29:40.538
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the use of benchmarks as leverage for CSI.  Jo explains that benchmarks are comparisons agains the norm or even an industry standard.  This is a competitive comparison that can be used to trigger CSI according to Jo.  She also explains that benchmarks help to keep our company aligned not only with business values but also with legislative demands and competitor performance.  She makes sure to emphasize that benchmarks do not help us to see where we need to be but only where we are in comparison to competitors and the standards.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Benchmarks

We've taken a look at some of the CSI
techniques such as assessment here,

00:01:00.896 --> 00:01:03.440
and now we're moving onto benchmarks.

22
00:01:03.440 --> 00:01:07.980
Now, Jo, to me,
they sound almost exactly the same.

00:01:07.980 --> 00:01:11.170
