24
00:01:11.170 --> 00:01:15.908
>> So, an assessment is the baseline,
a snapshot of where we are right now and

25
00:01:15.908 --> 00:01:22.000
we might assess against a maturity model,

26
00:01:22.000 --> 00:01:26.760

a standard, or

So, a benchmark is really taking the
assessment, taking what we've already done

258
00:16:02.510 --> 00:16:05.820
What is it going to tell you and what
are you gonna do with the information?

259
00:16:05.820 --> 00:16:08.610
I've already explained that
benchmarking can be quite costly.

260
00:16:08.610 --> 00:16:10.260
Benchmarking is not something cheap.

261
00:16:10.260 --> 00:16:15.373
We bring an external assessor
to be able to undertake this.

262
00:16:15.373 --> 00:16:19.365
And therefore assure the integrity of
the information that we get from that.

263
00:16:19.365 --> 00:16:22.065
So if it's not going to be
cheap then you have to have

264
00:16:22.065 --> 00:16:24.235
a very defined purpose in mind.

265
00:16:24.235 --> 00:16:27.357
We don't just benchmark because
we feel like it at the time.

266
00:16:27.357 --> 00:16:33.975
We benchmark for a reason and that reason
should be because we want to improve.

267
00:16:33.975 --> 00:16:38.885
Because we want to improve our alignment
to the needs of the organization.

268
00:16:40.470 --> 00:16:46.630
But we also have to consider
the vision of the organization as well.

269
00:16:46.630 --> 00:16:49.744
And it's not just about
the needs of the organization,

270
00:16:49.744 --> 00:16:53.521
we have to improve our alignment
to the vision of the organization,

271
00:16:53.521 --> 00:16:55.990
the strategy of the organization.

272
00:16:55.990 --> 00:16:58.050
And the reason why we benchmark?

273
00:16:58.050 --> 00:17:02.794
Well, we benchmark to ensure that not
only are we aligning ourselves to

274
00:17:02.794 --> 00:17:04.692
the needs of the business but

275
00:17:04.692 --> 00:17:10.590
also that we are aligning ourselves to
the future strategies of the organization.

276
00:17:10.590 --> 00:17:14.256
Bearing in mind where
the organization is in terms of

277
00:17:14.256 --> 00:17:19.106
a comparison with industry standards and
with competitors, okay.

278
00:17:19.106 --> 00:17:23.376
What we want to do is we want to ensure
that our organization, as a whole,

279
00:17:23.376 --> 00:17:27.856
has got that competitive edge that is
required to make them world leaders and

280
00:17:27.856 --> 00:17:30.070
to make them world class.

281
00:17:30.070 --> 00:17:34.080
They can't do that if we
are not align to their vision.

282
00:17:34.080 --> 00:17:36.270
So we have to ensure that
we're aligned to them.

283
00:17:37.412 --> 00:17:39.632
>> All right Jo, well, thank you again for

284
00:17:39.632 --> 00:17:43.170
helping us to understand a little
bit more about benchmarking.

285
00:17:43.170 --> 00:17:46.869
Taking a look at that idea of
the comparison against our competitors,

286
00:17:46.869 --> 00:17:49.660
as well as the industry standards.

287
00:17:49.660 --> 00:17:51.000
Helping us to keep competitive.

288
00:17:51.000 --> 00:17:53.880
This is actually a kind of key idea for
us as well.

289
00:17:53.880 --> 00:17:58.580
Now, this is also a great place for
us sign off for this episode as well.

290
00:17:58.580 --> 00:18:02.000
For ITPRO.TV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

291
00:18:02.000 --> 00:18:03.090
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

292
00:18:03.090 --> 00:18:08.023
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the ITIL Intermediate CSI Shows.

293
00:18:08.023 --> 00:18:13.895
[MUSIC]

294
00:18:13.895 --> 00:18:17.464
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Joe discuss service measurement.  Jo reminds that customers to the service are rarely concerned about the details of how the service works they are concerned with end result.  This is what we must measure according to Jo.  Availability and reliability and performance are key measurements that we must measure.  These service measures provide validation, justification, direction and intervention.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Service Measurements
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.463
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.463 --> 00:00:06.438
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.438 --> 00:00:08.632
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.632 --> 00:00:11.217
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.217 --> 00:00:14.890
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.890 --> 00:00:19.280
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate CSI show.

7
00:00:19.280 --> 00:00:21.560
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

8
00:00:21.560 --> 00:00:25.270
we are continuing on taking a look
at some of the CSI techniques.

9
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:28.180
And we are now into service measurement.

10
00:00:28.180 --> 00:00:30.090
And here to help us out once again,

11
00:00:30.090 --> 00:00:33.920
it's good to be with our ITIL master
blaster herself, Ms. Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:33.920 --> 00:00:35.120
Jo, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:35.120 --> 00:00:36.330
>> Thank you for having me, Ronnie.

14
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:37.200
How are you?

15
00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:37.850
>> I am doing fine.

16
00:00:37.850 --> 00:00:38.930
Now, Jo, here we are.

17
00:00:38.930 --> 00:00:41.220
We've already taken a look
at some assessments.

18
00:00:41.220 --> 00:00:43.198
We've talked about benchmarking a bit.

19
00:00:43.198 --> 00:00:46.610
And now,
we're going into service measurement, and

20
00:00:46.610 --> 00:00:52.113
you are very clear about this, this is not
measurements, it's service measurement.

21
00:00:52.113 --> 00:00:54.241
So what are we really talking about here,
Jo?

22
00:00:54.241 --> 00:00:58.171
>> Well, we're in CSI,
and because I think so

23
00:00:58.171 --> 00:01:06.010
is not really a good enough measurement on
whether we have improved or not, right?

24
00:01:06.010 --> 00:01:07.990
>> I mean, eyeing it is not enough.

25
00:01:07.990 --> 00:01:08.490
>> Exactly.
>> Okay.

26
00:01:08.490 --> 00:01:09.093
>> Right,

27
00:01:09.093 --> 00:01:11.790
exactly.
We've gotta make sure that we

28
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:12.640
are improving.

29
00:01:12.640 --> 00:01:13.660
>> Right.
>> And so

30
00:01:13.660 --> 00:01:17.700
the key to any improvement
has gotta be the measurement.

31
00:01:17.700 --> 00:01:21.080
And it's about measuring
the end to end service.

32
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:24.170
It's not about taking
individual measurements

33
00:01:24.170 --> 00:01:26.802
from individual components of a service.

34
00:01:26.802 --> 00:01:30.030
We wanna measure the entire
end to end service.

35
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:35.620
And we've got to be able to
demonstrate whether we are actually

36
00:01:35.620 --> 00:01:38.270
meeting the needs of the organization.

37
00:01:38.270 --> 00:01:41.370
So if we take a look at
the service measurement itself,

38
00:01:41.370 --> 00:01:45.110
you see that we've actually got three
basic measurements on our service.

39
00:01:45.110 --> 00:01:48.760
We've got the availability of the service,
we've got reliability, and

40
00:01:48.760 --> 00:01:52.550
then we've got the actually performance,
the end to end performance metric.

41
00:01:52.550 --> 00:01:55.480
Well reliability is about how
often something breaks down.

42
00:01:55.480 --> 00:01:58.740
And we can take that from our component.

43
00:01:58.740 --> 00:02:01.520
But the availability of
a service is not just about how

44
00:02:01.520 --> 00:02:02.770
often something breaks down.

45
00:02:04.250 --> 00:02:09.140
Availability is defined as
the ability of a service, or

46
00:02:09.140 --> 00:02:13.690
a component, to perform its
agreed function when required.

47
00:02:15.110 --> 00:02:18.490
That sounds fairly straightforward,
because it sounds as though, well, look,

48
00:02:18.490 --> 00:02:22.010
hang on a minute,
if the server is down, then therefore,

49
00:02:22.010 --> 00:02:24.100
the service can't be available, right?

50
00:02:24.100 --> 00:02:24.907
It makes sense?

51
00:02:24.907 --> 00:02:26.350
>> Mm-hm.

52
00:02:26.350 --> 00:02:27.188
>> That's not true.

53
00:02:27.188 --> 00:02:27.934
Okay.

54
00:02:27.934 --> 00:02:31.300
[LAUGH]
>> An incident is described as

55
00:02:31.300 --> 00:02:36.290
an interruption to or reduction in
the quality of service as defined by

56
00:02:37.390 --> 00:02:40.940
the customer in the service
level agreement.

57
00:02:42.170 --> 00:02:43.700
We're okay so far?

58
00:02:43.700 --> 00:02:48.663
Well, let's say I've got two servers, and

59
00:02:48.663 --> 00:02:52.410
they're both mirrored.

60
00:02:52.410 --> 00:02:53.400
>> All right.

61
00:02:53.400 --> 00:02:59.500
>> And they are both providing us with
the ability to send and receive e-mail.

62
00:02:59.500 --> 00:03:04.320
So, in my SLA,
I state that my service Is me

63
00:03:04.320 --> 00:03:09.260
providing the ability to send and
receive email via two mirrored servers.

64
00:03:10.380 --> 00:03:12.784
Yeah, that sounds good so far.

65
00:03:12.784 --> 00:03:18.397
So if one of those servers goes down,
it dies.

66
00:03:19.957 --> 00:03:22.400
Then that's gonna affect the reliability.

67
00:03:23.510 --> 00:03:24.820
>> Right.

68
00:03:24.820 --> 00:03:28.360
>> Well, it is all gonna affect the
reliability of that individual component.

69
00:03:28.360 --> 00:03:30.180
Has the service been interrupted?

70
00:03:31.580 --> 00:03:32.980
>> No, not fully interrupted.

71
00:03:32.980 --> 00:03:35.650
>> Right, well,
it shouldn't have been interrupted at all,

72
00:03:35.650 --> 00:03:39.525
because if it's mirroring, then it
shouldn't have been interrupted at all.

73
00:03:39.525 --> 00:03:42.945
Because that's what we call resilience or
high availability.

74
00:03:42.945 --> 00:03:46.215
And therefore, there shouldn't
be any interruptions to service.

75
00:03:46.215 --> 00:03:50.575
Now, in terms of incident management,
that's defined as an incident

76
00:03:50.575 --> 00:03:55.385
because it's a reduction in the quality
of a service that's defined in the SLA.

77
00:03:55.385 --> 00:03:59.195
But in terms of providing
the service to the business and

78
00:03:59.195 --> 00:04:03.440
to the end user,
service hasn't actually been interrupted.

79
00:04:03.440 --> 00:04:05.990
So the service is still available.

80
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:11.768
So even though the reliability
has been impacted,

81
00:04:11.768 --> 00:04:16.880
the availability hasn't.

82
00:04:16.880 --> 00:04:20.740
>> Okay.
[LAUGH] Now, Jo, we've talked about this

83
00:04:20.740 --> 00:04:25.530
before when you mentioned the idea
of the value of a business, right?

84
00:04:25.530 --> 00:04:31.110
It is perceived, so
if we talk about this idea, the perception

85
00:04:31.110 --> 00:04:36.480
though seems to indicate that it has
been interrupted, the perception.

86
00:04:36.480 --> 00:04:37.376
I'm not saying that's the reality.

87
00:04:37.376 --> 00:04:38.148
>> Not necessarily.

88
00:04:38.148 --> 00:04:38.875
>> No, okay.

89
00:04:38.875 --> 00:04:42.481
>> But the reality now, yeah,
the reality would suggest that service,

90
00:04:42.481 --> 00:04:46.092
while it hasn't been interrupted,
it's certainly been degraded,

91
00:04:46.092 --> 00:04:48.090
the quality's been degraded.

92
00:04:48.090 --> 00:04:50.920
But the question is, value is perceived.

93
00:04:50.920 --> 00:04:54.100
Has the business noticed that
the service has been degraded?

94
00:04:55.750 --> 00:04:56.313
>> I don't know, yeah.

95
00:04:56.313 --> 00:04:57.385
>> Well, I should hope not.

96
00:04:57.385 --> 00:04:58.253
>> Yeah, I should hope not.

97
00:04:58.253 --> 00:05:02.685
>> Cuz that's the idea of putting in
reliability options or redundancy options,

98
00:05:02.685 --> 00:05:06.670
is that the business, the organization
shouldn't actually notice.

99
00:05:06.670 --> 00:05:09.660
So that means that the service
is still available.

100
00:05:10.820 --> 00:05:13.090
It still has a reduction in quality.

101
00:05:13.090 --> 00:05:13.780
>> Right.

102
00:05:13.780 --> 00:05:16.990
But perception should
be that the service is

103
00:05:16.990 --> 00:05:19.680
still available to the business
>> All

104
00:05:19.680 --> 00:05:20.400
right
>> So

105
00:05:20.400 --> 00:05:24.670
the business shouldn't know what chaos
we've got going on in the background.

106
00:05:24.670 --> 00:05:26.860
>> Right
>> They don't need to see that.

107
00:05:26.860 --> 00:05:27.408
>> Okay
>> Now,

108
00:05:27.408 --> 00:05:30.413
it should still feature
those service level targets.

109
00:05:30.413 --> 00:05:34.768
And we talked in previous sessions about
the SLAM charts and the RAG charts and

110
00:05:34.768 --> 00:05:38.118
that should still feature,
in the SLAM and the RAG charts,

111
00:05:38.118 --> 00:05:41.803
because there was a degradation
in the quality of the service, or

112
00:05:41.803 --> 00:05:44.220
a reduction in the quality of the service.

113
00:05:44.220 --> 00:05:48.460
But nevertheless,
availability hasn't been impacted.

114
00:05:48.460 --> 00:05:49.120
>> Okay.

115
00:05:49.120 --> 00:05:52.440
>> And this is why we don't
just focus on reliability.

116
00:05:52.440 --> 00:05:55.640
In order to get the end-to-end
performance of a service,

117
00:05:55.640 --> 00:05:59.770
we're looking at both availability,
and we're looking at reliability.

118
00:05:59.770 --> 00:06:03.320
And we're also looking at the amount
of time it takes then for

119
00:06:03.320 --> 00:06:07.420
incident management to bring that other
server back up and running again.

120
00:06:08.460 --> 00:06:12.560
So these metrics, then,
the measurement of a service, and

121
00:06:12.560 --> 00:06:16.280
the metrics that we take to tell
us the measurement of a service,

122
00:06:16.280 --> 00:06:20.500
it's all about delivering
value to the organization.

123
00:06:20.500 --> 00:06:22.400
And look at that bottom
bullet point there,

124
00:06:22.400 --> 00:06:26.679
it says a meaningful view as
the customer experiences the service.

125
00:06:28.600 --> 00:06:33.170
I have mentioned, when we look at
service operation and we looked at

126
00:06:33.170 --> 00:06:37.520
the service desk, and I said to you,
I said to everybody, if you go and

127
00:06:37.520 --> 00:06:42.490
look at the service operation class of
the service desk, is that window into IT.

128
00:06:44.100 --> 00:06:45.940
And a really good service
desk can make up for

129
00:06:45.940 --> 00:06:48.590
all of the chaos that's
on going on behind us.

130
00:06:48.590 --> 00:06:54.870
Well, the simple fact is that if we
have our availability targets and

131
00:06:54.870 --> 00:06:59.490
our service articulated correctly so
that we deliver perceived value

132
00:06:59.490 --> 00:07:04.270
to the business, then yeah, there can
be all of this chaos going on, but

133
00:07:04.270 --> 00:07:10.580
nevertheless, the perceived value,
it's what the customer experiences.

134
00:07:10.580 --> 00:07:12.560
And that's what's really important.

135
00:07:13.790 --> 00:07:16.270
I'm not saying that we should
never ever have failures and

136
00:07:16.270 --> 00:07:20.930
that we should never ever go for
high availability on all of our services.

137
00:07:20.930 --> 00:07:22.090
I mean we can't do that.

138
00:07:22.090 --> 00:07:26.842
That's gonna be really expensive to put in
redundancy options, resilience options for

139
00:07:26.842 --> 00:07:27.929
all of our service.

140
00:07:27.929 --> 00:07:33.791
But nevertheless, there is a difference
between the reliability of a component,

141
00:07:33.791 --> 00:07:37.641
which is what that is,
a component of the service, and

142
00:07:37.641 --> 00:07:42.940
the ability of that service to facilitate
the outcomes that are required.

143
00:07:45.080 --> 00:07:47.620
So here we are in IT, then.

144
00:07:47.620 --> 00:07:53.034
We are looking at the measurement
of the end-to-end service.

145
00:07:53.034 --> 00:07:56.792
And so what we do is we'll take
individual measurements and

146
00:07:56.792 --> 00:08:01.163
then we combine them to provide
that view the customer experienced.

147
00:08:01.163 --> 00:08:06.380
And if we take a look at this particular
measurement model on the left-hand side.

148
00:08:06.380 --> 00:08:11.720
You'll see we build now from each of the
components to show us service management

149
00:08:11.720 --> 00:08:14.280
and then we're looking at
performance against KPIs.

150
00:08:14.280 --> 00:08:17.480
Remember those service
level targets in the SLAs.

151
00:08:17.480 --> 00:08:21.180
And then what we will do is we'll
take two types of measurements, and

152
00:08:21.180 --> 00:08:25.770
we'll take a look at the scorecard
on the left-hand side, and

153
00:08:25.770 --> 00:08:29.450
then on the right-hand side there,
we also see our dashboard.

154
00:08:29.450 --> 00:08:33.917
Now scorecard is a point
in time information, okay?

155
00:08:33.917 --> 00:08:38.251
That is, we'll take these maybe
once a week, once a month etc.

156
00:08:38.251 --> 00:08:42.900
That is point in time where as
the dashboard is real time.

157
00:08:42.900 --> 00:08:44.491
That's what's happening right now.

158
00:08:44.491 --> 00:08:48.690
Now I know probably on the screen in
front of you the graphics are looking

159
00:08:48.690 --> 00:08:49.820
quite small.

160
00:08:49.820 --> 00:08:52.930
I know that I think I need my
magnified glass to read that.

161
00:08:52.930 --> 00:08:56.580
But never the less in the notes that
you've downloaded you can zoom in and

162
00:08:56.580 --> 00:09:02.490
you can see all of the details
within that particular graphic.

163
00:09:02.490 --> 00:09:07.880
And we'll use both of those measurements
then to give us a balanced view within IT

164
00:09:07.880 --> 00:09:12.490
as to our service exactly how
our service is performing.

165
00:09:13.880 --> 00:09:16.240
Now this third bullet
point that we have here.

166
00:09:17.980 --> 00:09:22.580
It says here measure mistakes can be made
while adjustments are made to ensure

167
00:09:22.580 --> 00:09:26.740
the focus on the service and
not on the measurements themself.

168
00:09:26.740 --> 00:09:28.030
What on earth does that mean?

169
00:09:29.360 --> 00:09:32.557
Think about value again and
think about value perception, okay?

170
00:09:34.240 --> 00:09:39.830
Yes, we've got to measure how each
individual component is performing.

171
00:09:39.830 --> 00:09:43.040
But if I am so
focused on individual performance,

172
00:09:43.040 --> 00:09:46.130
let's say incident management,
for instance.

173
00:09:46.130 --> 00:09:50.110
If I'm focused on my individual
management performance metrics,

174
00:09:50.110 --> 00:09:55.210
then what I'm going to do is I'm gonna do
anything I possibly can to make incident

175
00:09:55.210 --> 00:09:59.807
management look good, generally to the
detrimental effect of the service, okay?

176
00:10:01.330 --> 00:10:06.030
So what I need to do is
ensure that my focus is on

177
00:10:06.030 --> 00:10:09.350
delivering value to our end users and
to our customers.

178
00:10:09.350 --> 00:10:14.040
My focus has got to be on what we call
moments of truth or customer experience.

179
00:10:14.040 --> 00:10:18.180
My focus has got to be
on value perception,

180
00:10:18.180 --> 00:10:21.870
my focus is not just on making
my statistics look good.

181
00:10:23.150 --> 00:10:26.540
Because then I'm not going to deliver
value, if that's what I'm doing.

182
00:10:27.790 --> 00:10:29.480
And what sort of things do we measure?

183
00:10:29.480 --> 00:10:35.030
Well, there's a list there of
the things that we might measure.

184
00:10:35.030 --> 00:10:37.740
Components, processes, activity.

185
00:10:37.740 --> 00:10:40.950
Please don't forget customer satisfaction
as well because this is how we

186
00:10:40.950 --> 00:10:42.829
measure whether value has been perceived.

187
00:10:43.980 --> 00:10:49.240
Now, the next slide looks at
an overall service availability.

188
00:10:49.240 --> 00:10:53.120
And that overall service availability,
right in the middle of that slide there,

189
00:10:53.120 --> 00:10:57.430
is at 91.69%, okay?

190
00:10:57.430 --> 00:11:00.520
Well, let's take a look at this for
a moment then and

191
00:11:00.520 --> 00:11:02.830
we're gonna start off
in the right-hand side.

192
00:11:02.830 --> 00:11:07.693
And in the moment in that technology
domain, we have an availability of 99.96%.

193
00:11:07.693 --> 00:11:14.992
But then the WAN, that's the wide
area network, is available 98%.

194
00:11:14.992 --> 00:11:21.800
So that's 98% of the 99.96%.

195
00:11:21.800 --> 00:11:23.520
Don't ask me to do that math, all right?

196
00:11:23.520 --> 00:11:26.180
I'm not that good at maths, okay?

197
00:11:26.180 --> 00:11:29.320
But then if we look at in the technology
domain where we've got our hubs and

198
00:11:29.320 --> 00:11:31.190
our servers and our routers or

199
00:11:31.190 --> 00:11:34.816
our routers depending on where
in the world you went to school.

200
00:11:34.816 --> 00:11:39.811
[LAUGH] Then you'll see that
that we've got a technology

201
00:11:39.811 --> 00:11:45.019
domain availability of 97.5%,
and that 97.5%

202
00:11:45.019 --> 00:11:50.448
is 97.5 of the 98% which
is 98% of the 99.96.

203
00:11:50.448 --> 00:11:54.007
And then we come down to the PCs and
the technology domain, and

204
00:11:54.007 --> 00:11:57.370
you'll see that they've got
an availability of 96%.

205
00:11:57.370 --> 00:12:00.726
Then that is 96% of the 97.5,

206
00:12:00.726 --> 00:12:06.110
which is of the 98%,
which is of the 99.96%.

207
00:12:06.110 --> 00:12:07.665
And now I'll take a breath.

208
00:12:07.665 --> 00:12:14.510
[LAUGH] What that actually means is that
for an entrance service perspective,

209
00:12:14.510 --> 00:12:19.480
that email service is available 91.69%.

210
00:12:19.480 --> 00:12:22.410
Wow, doesn't that sound confusing?

211
00:12:22.410 --> 00:12:25.760
It's not really,
it's quite simple but it really just

212
00:12:27.490 --> 00:12:31.210
asks us to understand that we have
to calculate the availability,

213
00:12:31.210 --> 00:12:34.820
and we have to calculate it
from the user perspective.

214
00:12:34.820 --> 00:12:40.014
Because you see if the availability
of the end user is 96% but

215
00:12:40.014 --> 00:12:47.564
that's only 96% of 97.5 which is
97.5 of 98, which is 98 over 99.96.

216
00:12:47.564 --> 00:12:50.807
So as far as the use of
perception is concerned,

217
00:12:50.807 --> 00:12:54.467
then service availability
is only at 91.69%.

218
00:12:54.467 --> 00:13:00.630
What this is telling us is you cannot
take your components in isolation.

219
00:13:00.630 --> 00:13:03.270
Because if you looked at your
components in isolation and

220
00:13:03.270 --> 00:13:07.750
said, hey this is my availability,
and actually it doesn't look too bad.

221
00:13:07.750 --> 00:13:13.210
But when you do the calculations, you'll
see that the user perception is not great,

222
00:13:13.210 --> 00:13:17.640
which is why it's all about the end
to end service delivery, and

223
00:13:17.640 --> 00:13:19.870
it's not about the individual components.

224
00:13:21.530 --> 00:13:26.300
We have to take the time to work out and

225
00:13:26.300 --> 00:13:30.750
then agree with the customer
how we're going to

226
00:13:30.750 --> 00:13:35.997
display our reports,
what we're going to report on,

227
00:13:35.997 --> 00:13:40.230
how often we're going to report,
who our audience is.

228
00:13:40.230 --> 00:13:44.935
So who we are going to report to and
therefore in what language we are going to

229
00:13:44.935 --> 00:13:49.584
do the reporting, and also think about
the frequency and the format too.

230
00:13:49.584 --> 00:13:54.493
And then I use the word in previous
sessions and I'll use it quite often,

231
00:13:54.493 --> 00:13:59.980
because I'm concerned about efficiency,
and I use the word consistency.

232
00:13:59.980 --> 00:14:05.400
I want to see reports in a consistent
framework and a consistent manner.

233
00:14:05.400 --> 00:14:09.980
Which means that we set expectations with
our audience, with our customers and

234
00:14:09.980 --> 00:14:14.080
with our users for the reporting itself.

235
00:14:14.080 --> 00:14:19.410
What they can expect to see,
how often they can expect to see it.

236
00:14:19.410 --> 00:14:23.030
And we want something that's
going to be customizable for

237
00:14:23.030 --> 00:14:26.040
our users view but we also want something

238
00:14:26.040 --> 00:14:30.210
that we can deliver consistently too
that means something to us as well.

239
00:14:31.520 --> 00:14:33.990
Just remember that you have
to have the right content for

240
00:14:33.990 --> 00:14:35.490
the right audience, okay?

241
00:14:35.490 --> 00:14:39.550
You're senior your management is not
interested in technical details at

242
00:14:39.550 --> 00:14:43.690
exactly what went wrong with what
particular portion of the one.

243
00:14:44.860 --> 00:14:47.390
Whereas your technical team

244
00:14:47.390 --> 00:14:51.637
are not necessarily interested in high
level budgetary predictions, okay?

245
00:14:52.910 --> 00:14:55.440
So, language of the audience.

246
00:14:55.440 --> 00:14:59.410
All communication must be in
the language of the audience, okay?

247
00:14:59.410 --> 00:15:04.130
And like I've already said, this is not
about the actual metrics themselves.

248
00:15:04.130 --> 00:15:08.200
If we are just interested
in the metrics themselves,

249
00:15:08.200 --> 00:15:13.430
then we get into that realms of compliance
with our service level targets.

250
00:15:13.430 --> 00:15:17.890
And we're not here just to prove that
we can achieve service level targets.

251
00:15:17.890 --> 00:15:22.310
I've already said in previous sessions,
and I will carry on saying, probably until

252
00:15:22.310 --> 00:15:28.380
my dying breath, that I don't want to see
green on a SLAM chart or on a RAG chart.

253
00:15:28.380 --> 00:15:33.380
It's not about compliance,
it's about our customer perception, and

254
00:15:33.380 --> 00:15:35.310
it's about delivering value.

255
00:15:36.980 --> 00:15:40.100
So, we have three different
types of metrics and

256
00:15:40.100 --> 00:15:44.830
I know that I've already mentioned this,
so this one is a reminder here.

257
00:15:44.830 --> 00:15:49.659
We have technology metrics that measure
those components, so we have process

258
00:15:49.659 --> 00:15:54.558
metrics that measure, say for instance,
how quickly we can restore service,

259
00:15:54.558 --> 00:15:59.041
and the combination of these will give
us our end to end service metrics.

260
00:15:59.041 --> 00:16:02.526
But we're not just interested in quantity.

261
00:16:02.526 --> 00:16:05.750
We're interested in quality, too.

262
00:16:05.750 --> 00:16:08.520
Now, I'm sure that somebody's gonna
make me say the big, long word.

263
00:16:08.520 --> 00:16:11.170
So I'm gonna say the big
long words at the top, okay?

264
00:16:11.170 --> 00:16:14.820
We've got qualitative examples
there that look at quality,

265
00:16:14.820 --> 00:16:18.100
which is about customer perception, okay?

266
00:16:18.100 --> 00:16:20.430
That's quality, it's about perception.

267
00:16:20.430 --> 00:16:24.590
And there's an example of a CSF and
a KPI underneath that.

268
00:16:24.590 --> 00:16:29.468
And then we've got the quantitative,
which is about being able to

269
00:16:29.468 --> 00:16:33.662
quantify exactly how our
services are being delivered.

270
00:16:33.662 --> 00:16:37.326
And yet again, we've got a CSF there for
reducing costs.

271
00:16:37.326 --> 00:16:39.923
And a KPI, which as an example,

272
00:16:39.923 --> 00:16:45.550
which will just tell us whether
we are actually reducing costs.

273
00:16:45.550 --> 00:16:49.820
And so underneath all of those KPIs and
the CSFs,

274
00:16:49.820 --> 00:16:52.920
you'll see the actual
metrics that we need to take.

275
00:16:55.140 --> 00:16:57.900
One thing that we do have to do is
make sure that we have balance in

276
00:16:57.900 --> 00:16:59.390
our metrics as well.

277
00:16:59.390 --> 00:17:02.230
And we spend a lot of time
looking at the types of metrics.

278
00:17:03.660 --> 00:17:09.780
But think about the balance between
resources, people, and money as well.

279
00:17:09.780 --> 00:17:14.612
The balance between the functionality
metrics too, and between time.

280
00:17:14.612 --> 00:17:19.535
And so we want metrics that show
our progress in terms of time along

281
00:17:19.535 --> 00:17:23.036
any project, or
even along any improvement.

282
00:17:23.036 --> 00:17:28.850
For instance, the previous slide
looked at a 10% reduction in costs.

283
00:17:28.850 --> 00:17:32.590
We also want to show a balance
between that time and

284
00:17:32.590 --> 00:17:34.750
also the functionality itself.

285
00:17:34.750 --> 00:17:40.540
So are we delivering that service, and do
we have the right number of people, okay?

286
00:17:40.540 --> 00:17:45.580
So we want to have
a balance in those metrics.

287
00:17:45.580 --> 00:17:50.990
And as it says here, with no balance,
then we might focus more on time.

288
00:17:50.990 --> 00:17:54.054
Or we might focus more on,
say, just the functionality.

289
00:17:54.054 --> 00:17:57.814
Or we might focus on just saving money,
for instance.

290
00:17:59.847 --> 00:18:03.168
When we're defining KPIs, and by the way,

291
00:18:03.168 --> 00:18:06.580
this happens in service design,
don't forget.

292
00:18:06.580 --> 00:18:09.540
It's one of the things that
we design in service design.

293
00:18:09.540 --> 00:18:13.120
We have to ask ourselves these questions,
okay?

294
00:18:13.120 --> 00:18:17.627
I've mentioned in previous
sessions in CSI about the need for

295
00:18:17.627 --> 00:18:20.321
decision-making with any metric.

296
00:18:20.321 --> 00:18:23.330
We've gotta be able to make a decision,
okay?

297
00:18:23.330 --> 00:18:27.480
You cannot just have a metric just for
the sake of having a metric.

298
00:18:27.480 --> 00:18:29.550
And because I think so

299
00:18:29.550 --> 00:18:32.520
is not a good enough measurement as
to whether we've improved or not.

300
00:18:32.520 --> 00:18:37.900
So we've gotta have metrics, but these
metrics have gotta tell us something.

301
00:18:37.900 --> 00:18:40.150
They've gotta answer a question,

302
00:18:40.150 --> 00:18:42.290
they've gotta answer the question
of what's in it for me.

303
00:18:42.290 --> 00:18:44.700
And they've gotta allow
us to make a decision.

304
00:18:44.700 --> 00:18:48.400
So take a look at the questions
that you've got in your notes.

305
00:18:48.400 --> 00:18:50.980
The questions that you've
got in front of you.

306
00:18:50.980 --> 00:18:53.240
And just ask yourselves,

307
00:18:53.240 --> 00:18:57.760
when you define any metric,
does it answer these questions.

308
00:18:57.760 --> 00:19:01.606
How easy is it to interpret,
why do we want this information?

309
00:19:01.606 --> 00:19:07.460
Is it accurate, what about changing it,
can I make a change to it?

310
00:19:07.460 --> 00:19:11.963
Can we actually measure it now, and
does it show us anything valuable?

311
00:19:11.963 --> 00:19:13.890
And by the way, who owns it?

312
00:19:13.890 --> 00:19:17.724
Because if somebody's asked for a metric,
then they probably want it for a reason.

313
00:19:17.724 --> 00:19:22.550
And therefore, do we assign them as owner,
or do we become the owner?

314
00:19:22.550 --> 00:19:26.015
Because what if somebody else
wants to use that metric, but

315
00:19:26.015 --> 00:19:29.566
just to make a slight tweak to it,
just slightly different?

316
00:19:29.566 --> 00:19:34.140
Then can we do that, or do we have to
go back to the original requester?

317
00:19:35.470 --> 00:19:37.650
All of these are questions
that have to be answered.

318
00:19:39.210 --> 00:19:43.170
Just remember the four
reasons why we measure.

319
00:19:43.170 --> 00:19:47.645
We measure to validate that we're
going in the right direction.

320
00:19:48.755 --> 00:19:52.275
We measure to justify, which is what
I call the see, I told you so metric.

321
00:19:52.275 --> 00:19:57.131
Yeah, I told you we needed more money,
I told you we needed more people.

322
00:19:57.131 --> 00:19:59.175
And we measure to direct and to intervene.

323
00:19:59.175 --> 00:20:03.681
And if we look at our SLAM charts,
that's the amber and the green, or

324
00:20:03.681 --> 00:20:07.816
the yellow and the green,
depending on where you live, okay?

325
00:20:07.816 --> 00:20:10.302
And amber or orange or
yellow, that's a direction,

326
00:20:10.302 --> 00:20:11.995
we need to do something about that.

327
00:20:11.995 --> 00:20:15.400
Whereas the red, that's an intervention,
something's gone wrong.

328
00:20:16.420 --> 00:20:20.344
So think about why you're
taking any metric, and

329
00:20:20.344 --> 00:20:22.872
what use is it going to be to you.

330
00:20:22.872 --> 00:20:26.620
And does it allow me to
make an informed decision?

331
00:20:27.630 --> 00:20:30.930
And I really like the bottom
bullet point in this slide,

332
00:20:30.930 --> 00:20:33.350
which talks about outside influences.

333
00:20:33.350 --> 00:20:35.439
And it goes back to why we're measuring.

334
00:20:37.400 --> 00:20:39.500
We want all of our
measurements to be objective,

335
00:20:39.500 --> 00:20:41.000
we don't want them to be subjective.

336
00:20:41.000 --> 00:20:45.250
The only one that should be subjective
is the customer satisfaction metric.

337
00:20:45.250 --> 00:20:48.220
And even then,
we take a qualitative metric, and

338
00:20:48.220 --> 00:20:50.240
we turn it into a quantitative metric.

339
00:20:50.240 --> 00:20:54.710
Because we'll ask our
question to our customers.

340
00:20:54.710 --> 00:20:59.485
On a scale of one to ten, how happy
are you with this particular service?

341
00:20:59.485 --> 00:21:01.942
So therefore,
we've taken the qualitative, and

342
00:21:01.942 --> 00:21:04.320
we've turned it into
something quantitative.

343
00:21:04.320 --> 00:21:07.880
Because we've asked them to mark
this on a scale of one to ten.

344
00:21:09.080 --> 00:21:15.300
Always think about taking a metric that
is going to allow you to make a decision.

345
00:21:15.300 --> 00:21:19.100
If you don't have a decision, if you
don't know what you're going to do with

346
00:21:19.100 --> 00:21:23.170
a report, then should you
really be taking that report?

347
00:21:23.170 --> 00:21:28.380
Remember, when we look for tools and
we look for our service management tools,

348
00:21:28.380 --> 00:21:33.440
we don't select a tool just because it
delivers 500 out-of-the-box reports.

349
00:21:33.440 --> 00:21:40.755
Because you might not need
499 of those reports.

350
00:21:40.755 --> 00:21:44.420
So we've looked at metrics, and
we've looked at why we take a metric.

351
00:21:44.420 --> 00:21:47.300
And we've looked at the type
of metrics that we take.

352
00:21:47.300 --> 00:21:51.186
And as we move into our next session,
we're going to start and

353
00:21:51.186 --> 00:21:54.574
take a look at other
measurement sort of techniques.

354
00:21:54.574 --> 00:21:58.430
And other measurement frameworks,
such as a balance scorecard.

355
00:21:58.430 --> 00:22:01.060
But for now, what I'd like you
to do is I want you to make

356
00:22:01.060 --> 00:22:04.360
sure that you feel comfortable
with metrics themselves.

357
00:22:04.360 --> 00:22:09.300
And with the understanding of a CSF and
a KPI, and the difference between the two.

358
00:22:09.300 --> 00:22:14.611
Maybe review back over previous sessions
over the vision to metrics tree.

359
00:22:14.611 --> 00:22:19.190
And then if you have any questions,
our forum's always available for you.

360
00:22:19.190 --> 00:22:22.300
So please feel free to let us
know if you have any questions.

361
00:22:22.300 --> 00:22:24.840
And I'll be more than happy
to answer them for you.

362
00:22:24.840 --> 00:22:28.510
>> All right, Jo, thank you again for
helping us to take a look at this idea

363
00:22:28.510 --> 00:22:32.830
of the service metrics that we've been
talking about, or the service metric.

364
00:22:32.830 --> 00:22:35.750
Realizing that the end-to-end service

365
00:22:35.750 --> 00:22:38.880
is really what a lot of times
the customer is concerned about.

366
00:22:38.880 --> 00:22:41.990
But also the focus here is
understanding that process and

367
00:22:41.990 --> 00:22:44.820
that technique that we
have available to us.

368
00:22:44.820 --> 00:22:48.190
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode.

369
00:22:48.190 --> 00:22:52.020
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

370
00:22:52.020 --> 00:22:53.290
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

371
00:22:53.290 --> 00:22:57.238
>> Stay tuned right here for

372
00:22:57.238 --> 00:23:03.828
more of the ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

373
00:23:03.828 --> 00:23:05.288
[MUSIC]

374
00:23:05.288 --> 00:23:11.760
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo describe the use of the balanced scorescard, swot analysis and ROI.  Jo explains the balanced scorecard provides metrics from all perspectives.  She also explains the use of SWOT analysis and then how ROI and VOI different and measured.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - Scorecard, SWOT and ROI
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:04.616
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:04.616 --> 00:00:11.877
You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.877 --> 00:00:15.030
>> Welcome to another episode
right here on ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.030 --> 00:00:19.110
You're watching the ITIL
intermediate CSI show.

5
00:00:19.110 --> 00:00:23.270
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
gonna take a look at what some additional

6
00:00:23.270 --> 00:00:27.640
CSI techniques to help us out here,
including the balanced scorecard.

7
00:00:27.640 --> 00:00:31.706
We're gonna also talk about the SWOT
analysis, as well as the ROI.

8
00:00:31.706 --> 00:00:36.367
And here to help us to explain
all of those different terms,

9
00:00:36.367 --> 00:00:41.790
is actually gonna be our scrabble
meister herself, yes Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:41.790 --> 00:00:43.200
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:43.200 --> 00:00:45.680
>> Thank you very much for
having me, Ronnie.

12
00:00:45.680 --> 00:00:48.820
>> All right Jo, so
when we start to take a look at this.

13
00:00:48.820 --> 00:00:53.160
You have just spilled alphabet soup
all over our lower third there.

14
00:00:53.160 --> 00:00:54.633
So you're gonna have to help us out and

15
00:00:54.633 --> 00:00:57.038
when we talk about these different
types of techniques here.

16
00:00:57.038 --> 00:01:00.840
Why is it so important that we have so
many of them Jo?

17
00:01:00.840 --> 00:01:01.680
It seems like a lot.

18
00:01:02.810 --> 00:01:07.290
>> It's really all about
understanding why we're measuring and

19
00:01:07.290 --> 00:01:11.500
I have mentioned in previous sessions and
I will carry on mentioning the fact that

20
00:01:11.500 --> 00:01:15.030
whenever we take any measurement there
has to be a reason behind it, and

21
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:17.930
we have to be able to make
an informed decision.

22
00:01:17.930 --> 00:01:23.210
So what we're going to do is we're going
to look at an analysis technique that we

23
00:01:23.210 --> 00:01:29.265
use to analyze where we are within
our organization which is SWOT,

24
00:01:29.265 --> 00:01:32.945
or otherwise known as strengths,
weaknesses, opportunities and threats.

25
00:01:32.945 --> 00:01:36.015
We're going to look at balance scorecard
which is gonna be the first thing we're

26
00:01:36.015 --> 00:01:41.005
gonna look at which really extends from a
previous session where we started looking

27
00:01:41.005 --> 00:01:45.520
at service measurements and
we looked at metrics and CSFs and KPIs.

28
00:01:45.520 --> 00:01:49.930
And we're gonna carry on by
looking at how we view those.

29
00:01:49.930 --> 00:01:52.770
And then we're also going to
look at return on investment

30
00:01:52.770 --> 00:01:55.210
versus value on investment as well.

31
00:01:55.210 --> 00:02:00.900
Because these are two different
terms that we want to achieve.

32
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:05.548
If we want to achieve a value return
when we make any improvements so

33
00:02:05.548 --> 00:02:08.868
really these are just terms
that we would use and

34
00:02:08.868 --> 00:02:12.363
the techniques that we
would utilize within CSI.

35
00:02:12.363 --> 00:02:17.228
>> All right Jo, so with all of these
different types of tools that we've been

36
00:02:17.228 --> 00:02:20.950
using, techniques,
which one do we need to begin with?

37
00:02:20.950 --> 00:02:24.380
Because I don't know if you
were to say hey just pick one,

38
00:02:24.380 --> 00:02:26.540
I don't even know which one I would pick.

39
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:29.040
>> Right,
I don't think anybody's got a favorite.

40
00:02:29.040 --> 00:02:30.165
Don't get me wrong.

41
00:02:30.165 --> 00:02:36.020
[LAUGH] Certainly not when it comes to
balancing metrics and taking reports.

42
00:02:36.020 --> 00:02:37.280
Nobody has a favorite.

>> Well, what we want to do is take

I always say that with ITIL, what we've

00:02:56.740 --> 00:03:02.050

00:03:02.050 --> 00:03:03.043
That's what we've done.

00:03:03.043 --> 00:03:08.433
And so, with a balanced scorecard,
we've taken the common

00:03:13.294 --> 00:03:19.108

Now, if you remember the fact that we have

Well, what we're just

You might think about this

Now, we've taken this and

perspective on metrics, because instead of

an innervation as we call it, because this

About return and investment, we're

So we should be showing reports

Remember we talk about quality and

00:05:21.260 --> 00:05:23.830
And then we've got

And an internal perspective really looks

So, the bottom comment there under

That's really about how us in IT,

These are our internal metrics.

00:05:42.720 --> 00:05:45.570
And then we've got

00:05:45.570 --> 00:05:49.400

It's all about growth,

99

it's about harnessing

100
00:05:55.970 --> 00:06:00.840
this is about understanding what

00:06:00.840 --> 00:06:06.505

102
00:06:06.505 --> 00:06:09.295
Now, you could argue that it's very,

00:06:09.295 --> 00:06:14.055

104
00:06:14.055 --> 00:06:18.335
Well, I'm gonna bring in the concept

105
00:06:20.132 --> 00:06:25.662
A trailing metric is a metric
of a performance in the past.

106
00:06:26.792 --> 00:06:30.572
So a trailing metric would be
something along the lines of,

107
00:06:30.572 --> 00:06:34.512
we've got a 90% incident
resolution rate within

108
00:06:35.632 --> 00:06:41.600
four hours for priority one incidents
over the last three months.

109
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:45.517
And that's the key over the last
three months or over the last year or

110
00:06:45.517 --> 00:06:49.227
over the last week,
that's what we call a trailing metric, and

111
00:06:49.227 --> 00:06:51.375
that's a metric that looks behind.

112
00:06:51.375 --> 00:06:55.880
And when you think about it in IT, and
certainly when we look at metrics that

113
00:06:55.880 --> 00:07:00.316
we've looked at in previous sections,
well acctually they've all been

114
00:07:00.316 --> 00:07:03.910
trailing metrics,
they've all looked at how we perform.

115
00:07:04.990 --> 00:07:07.110
But what about our future metrics?

116
00:07:07.110 --> 00:07:11.830
What about those metrics that look

117
00:07:11.830 --> 00:07:15.710
You might consider that to be innovation,
and our plans,

118
00:07:15.710 --> 00:07:20.260
our availability plans and our capacity
plans, they're part of our innovation.

119
00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:25.572
You could ask the question,

120
00:07:25.572 --> 00:07:30.120
Because surely previous metrics will
tell us how we have preformed, and

121
00:07:30.120 --> 00:07:32.920
therefore we can use that to the future,
can't we?

122
00:07:32.920 --> 00:07:34.170
Well yeah we can, but

123
00:07:34.170 --> 00:07:39.330
then that in itself is a leading metric
because it's predicting the future.

124
00:07:39.330 --> 00:07:44.950
So a leading metric would be something
that looks at say estimated,

125
00:07:44.950 --> 00:07:47.680
well it shouldn't be estimated
it should be planned,

126
00:07:47.680 --> 00:07:51.430
number of staff on the service
desk on a Monday morning.

127
00:07:51.430 --> 00:07:56.640
You know, a schedule for next week is
what we would call a leading metric,

128
00:07:56.640 --> 00:07:59.256
something that looks to the future.

129
00:07:59.256 --> 00:08:04.788
So we have these leading metrics, they
would appear in that innovation section

130
00:08:04.788 --> 00:08:10.157
whereas a lot of the Other sections would
potentially be trailing metrics but

131
00:08:10.157 --> 00:08:14.700
then our budget, which is
a financial perspective, is actually

132
00:08:14.700 --> 00:08:20.060
a leading metric because that's how
