133
00:08:20.060 --> 00:08:23.350
Whereas, our account and
how we have spent our money and

134
00:08:23.350 --> 00:08:28.320
where we've spent our money, well, that's
what we call a trailing metric because

135
00:08:28.320 --> 00:08:30.567
that's how much money have we spent.

136
00:08:30.567 --> 00:08:34.492
So as you see, it's not actually
impossible to look at leading metrics as

137
00:08:34.492 --> 00:08:39.010
well as trailing metrics and yet we always
think about what's happened in the past.

138
00:08:40.160 --> 00:08:42.660
But this balance scorecard
brings them together and

139
00:08:42.660 --> 00:08:45.681
this balance scorecard looks
at the different perspectives.

140
00:08:45.681 --> 00:08:51.253
And that's the different perspectives that
all of our stakeholders are interested in,

141
00:08:51.253 --> 00:08:56.375
whether that be money, whether it be our
customers that are interested in value,

142
00:08:56.375 --> 00:08:59.197
whether it be internal
IT that are interested

143
00:08:59.197 --> 00:09:03.040
in say OLA performance as
opposed to SLA performance, etc.

144
00:09:03.040 --> 00:09:05.570
So that brings us on to
our next technique then.

145
00:09:05.570 --> 00:09:09.488
And our next technique is
what we call a SWOT analysis.

146
00:09:09.488 --> 00:09:14.487
And a SWOT analysis is where we look
at strengths and weaknesses and

147
00:09:14.487 --> 00:09:16.728
opportunities and threats.

148
00:09:16.728 --> 00:09:18.145
And that's why we call it SWOT.

149
00:09:19.970 --> 00:09:25.780
And a SWOT analysis is really where, very
similar to the previous format actually.

150
00:09:25.780 --> 00:09:28.950
We're going to take a table, and
we're gonna divide it into four.

151
00:09:28.950 --> 00:09:33.275
And we're going to list our organization,
or our team's strengths,

152
00:09:33.275 --> 00:09:37.900
that their opportunities, and
their weaknesses, and their threats.

153
00:09:37.900 --> 00:09:39.230
The first thing, though,

154
00:09:39.230 --> 00:09:44.770
that we've got to do is we've got
to work out what our goal is.

155
00:09:44.770 --> 00:09:47.680
Why are we taking this SWOT analysis?

156
00:09:47.680 --> 00:09:50.919
Cuz you don't just perform
a SWOT analysis for no reason.

157
00:09:52.370 --> 00:09:57.030
If we were looking at say, say for
instance we were evaluating my

158
00:09:57.030 --> 00:10:01.040
ability to be able to consult
in an external environment.

159
00:10:01.040 --> 00:10:06.030
Or my ability to be able to appear
on TV and present something.

160
00:10:06.030 --> 00:10:09.400
Then, we would want to
look at my strengths.

161
00:10:09.400 --> 00:10:14.740
Well, some of my strengths involve
the fact that I'm very, very good at wood

162
00:10:14.740 --> 00:10:20.690
working, and that I was able to make all
of our deck furniture on our deck at home.

163
00:10:20.690 --> 00:10:23.422
That could be considered to be a strength.

164
00:10:23.422 --> 00:10:26.370
But what relevance does that
have on my ability to be

165
00:10:26.370 --> 00:10:28.370
able to talk to you right now?

166
00:10:28.370 --> 00:10:29.890
Absolutely nothing.

167
00:10:29.890 --> 00:10:31.680
Has no relevance at all.

168
00:10:31.680 --> 00:10:36.450
And so, the simple fact is that when we
conduct a SWOT analysis, like any other

169
00:10:36.450 --> 00:10:41.570
metrics, they have to be completely
relevant to the goal that we have in mind.

170
00:10:42.640 --> 00:10:49.190
The idea is that we can highlight our
strengths, we understand our weaknesses,

171
00:10:49.190 --> 00:10:53.620
but then we look externally
beyond our environment, and

172
00:10:53.620 --> 00:10:57.400
we look for opportunities, and we look for

173
00:10:57.400 --> 00:11:01.600
any elements that might
threaten those opportunities.

174
00:11:02.840 --> 00:11:07.770
So the strengths and weaknesses,
that's an internal perspective.

175
00:11:07.770 --> 00:11:09.120
That's looking at us.

176
00:11:09.120 --> 00:11:12.300
That's looking at our team,
at our department, and

177
00:11:12.300 --> 00:11:15.750
that's saying,
these are our internal strengths.

178
00:11:15.750 --> 00:11:18.690
And these are our internal weaknesses.

179
00:11:18.690 --> 00:11:20.660
And then, we look outside.

180
00:11:20.660 --> 00:11:23.540
We look externally to
our current environment.

181
00:11:23.540 --> 00:11:26.970
Depending on the scale cuz that
really is entirely dependent on

182
00:11:26.970 --> 00:11:29.590
what we're performing the analysis on.

183
00:11:29.590 --> 00:11:33.020
And externally we say, so
what are our opportunities?

184
00:11:34.270 --> 00:11:37.820
What is this for us to grow into?

185
00:11:37.820 --> 00:11:41.260
What is the new for us to expand into?

186
00:11:41.260 --> 00:11:46.330
And our threats are on what could prevent
us from doing that from an external

187
00:11:46.330 --> 00:11:47.860
perspective.

188
00:11:47.860 --> 00:11:51.900
And we can also perform SWOT
analysis on services, we can perform

189
00:11:51.900 --> 00:11:55.970
SWOT analysis on our process as well,
processes so, as well too.

190
00:11:58.160 --> 00:12:02.570
Just remember that you
have to have an end state.

191
00:12:02.570 --> 00:12:05.200
You have to know what
you're measuring against.

192
00:12:06.800 --> 00:12:12.150
You also have to be very,
very careful not to confuse opportunities,

193
00:12:12.150 --> 00:12:16.800
in other words, what we can grow into,
with what we're good at right now.

194
00:12:16.800 --> 00:12:19.485
Because what we can grow into is external,

195
00:12:19.485 --> 00:12:23.960
whereas what we're good at right
now is very much internal.

196
00:12:25.240 --> 00:12:30.690
And don't forget that an opportunity
is something that we might grow into.

197
00:12:30.690 --> 00:12:32.090
It's not a strategy.

198
00:12:32.090 --> 00:12:38.230
A strategy is a very firm
direction on where we are going.

199
00:12:38.230 --> 00:12:43.760
Whereas, an opportunity is
something that we might get into.

200
00:12:43.760 --> 00:12:47.028
So it's something that we
might take advantage of,

201
00:12:47.028 --> 00:12:49.415
something that we might expand into.

202
00:12:49.415 --> 00:12:57.170
Whereas, a strategy is a very clear
direction on what we are going to achieve.

203
00:12:57.170 --> 00:13:03.360
So a strategy might be to become
more reliant on mobile technology.

204
00:13:03.360 --> 00:13:04.260
That's a strategy.

205
00:13:04.260 --> 00:13:06.520
Something that we're going to achieve.

206
00:13:06.520 --> 00:13:11.610
But an opportunity might be to
expand into a different marketplace.

207
00:13:11.610 --> 00:13:13.298
That's an opportunity.

208
00:13:13.298 --> 00:13:18.120
The strategy is what we want to do.

209
00:13:18.120 --> 00:13:21.120
So that's the SWOT analysis,
very, very simply.

210
00:13:21.120 --> 00:13:23.210
Just remember that with a SWOT analysis,

211
00:13:23.210 --> 00:13:26.630
you have to work out what it is you're
trying to achieve first of all.

212
00:13:26.630 --> 00:13:31.240
In other words, the purpose of the SWOT,
just because I'm good at building

213
00:13:31.240 --> 00:13:35.810
deck furniture doesn't mean that it makes
me very good at talking to you right now.

214
00:13:37.150 --> 00:13:41.886
So let's talk about this other acronym
that we used because as Ronnie mentioned

215
00:13:41.886 --> 00:13:45.417
there, there was a kinda
alphabet soup going on there, but

216
00:13:45.417 --> 00:13:48.265
it's just that I like acronyms,
that's all.

217
00:13:48.265 --> 00:13:53.021
And so, we look at ROI, well,
actually, I want to bring in

218
00:13:53.021 --> 00:13:58.370
another acronym as well and
that is VOI, value on the investment.

219
00:13:59.700 --> 00:14:02.990
Before we make any improvement,
absolutely any improvement at all,

220
00:14:02.990 --> 00:14:07.260
we have to understand what
we're going to get out of it.

221
00:14:07.260 --> 00:14:11.580
And [LAUGH] as it says up there on that
slide just because it sounds like a good

222
00:14:11.580 --> 00:14:13.300
doesn't mean that it is a good idea.

223
00:14:13.300 --> 00:14:17.800
We have to make sure that we're going
to get something tangible out of it.

224
00:14:17.800 --> 00:14:19.810
So when we make any improvement,

225
00:14:19.810 --> 00:14:23.960
we're looking to identify
a return on that investment.

226
00:14:23.960 --> 00:14:27.854
But that return doesn't
necessarily have to be financial.

227
00:14:27.854 --> 00:14:31.860
It could be a value on investment.

228
00:14:31.860 --> 00:14:35.920
So for instance,
adherence to corporate policies or

229
00:14:35.920 --> 00:14:40.975
adherence to legislative requirements,
I still can't say that word by the way.

230
00:14:40.975 --> 00:14:44.390
[LAUGH] Adherence to
legislative requirements or

231
00:14:44.390 --> 00:14:47.190
adherence to regulations for instance.

232
00:14:47.190 --> 00:14:49.550
That would be considered to
be a value on investment.

233
00:14:49.550 --> 00:14:51.840
And not necessarily financial return.

234
00:14:53.410 --> 00:14:59.070
But most improvements we can articulate in
terms of financial return on investment.

235
00:14:59.070 --> 00:15:02.440
So let's take a look at the justification,
for instance,

236
00:15:02.440 --> 00:15:07.490
the cost of doing the rework, the cost of
redundant work, the cost of late delivery,

237
00:15:07.490 --> 00:15:12.580
etc., all of these form
part of a return on that

238
00:15:12.580 --> 00:15:17.810
investment because if we're saving money,
and that's what we mean by cost

239
00:15:17.810 --> 00:15:22.370
here in this instance, if we're saving
money then there's a financial return.

240
00:15:24.330 --> 00:15:31.137
Remember that all of our return
on investment statements for

241
00:15:31.137 --> 00:15:38.222
any new project, have to be
articulated in the business case.

242
00:15:38.222 --> 00:15:41.778
Now, the business case is a document,
it's a justification for

243
00:15:41.778 --> 00:15:46.112
significant IT of expenditure and we
expand further on that in service strategy

244
00:15:46.112 --> 00:15:48.958
when we look at the financial
management process and

245
00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.950
also the business relationship
management process.

246
00:15:53.000 --> 00:15:58.918
But just think about who the audience
is for your business case.

247
00:15:58.918 --> 00:16:03.894
It depends on the size of the project,
the size of the improvement project,

248
00:16:03.894 --> 00:16:07.106
just how large that business
case is going to be.

249
00:16:07.106 --> 00:16:09.372
How much money is going to be spent and

250
00:16:09.372 --> 00:16:12.452
therefore who would approve
that business case.

251
00:16:12.452 --> 00:16:16.183
So approvals for the business case
could be the business executives.

252
00:16:16.183 --> 00:16:18.280
It could be the board of directors.

253
00:16:18.280 --> 00:16:22.080
It could be the Chief Financial Officer,
or it could be the IT steering group.

254
00:16:22.080 --> 00:16:24.420
But remember who the audience is.

255
00:16:24.420 --> 00:16:27.860
Because, as I've mentioned
in quite a few sessions,

256
00:16:27.860 --> 00:16:31.240
our communication needs to be
in the language of the audience.

257
00:16:31.240 --> 00:16:35.500
It is no good telling somebody
in our board of directorship,

258
00:16:35.500 --> 00:16:37.388
our executive board.

259
00:16:37.388 --> 00:16:42.330
It's not good telling them all of the
technical nuances of our infrastructure.

260
00:16:42.330 --> 00:16:45.510
Because quite simply,
it's not their role to understand that.

261
00:16:46.540 --> 00:16:50.580
But at the same time,
if we're asking for a process manager or

262
00:16:50.580 --> 00:16:53.080
a service owner to sign something off.

263
00:16:53.080 --> 00:16:57.640
Then we don't want to necessarily tell
them all the intricacies of the ways of

264
00:16:57.640 --> 00:17:00.010
working of our executive board.

265
00:17:00.010 --> 00:17:04.450
Because, again, they don't
necessarily need to understand that.

266
00:17:04.450 --> 00:17:07.660
So ensure that we have,
when compiling a business case,

267
00:17:07.660 --> 00:17:11.030
the right target audience in mind.

268
00:17:11.030 --> 00:17:14.940
For the level of change, and for
the actual business case itself.

269
00:17:14.940 --> 00:17:18.880
And also,
we need to ensure that we are articulating

270
00:17:18.880 --> 00:17:23.160
a potential return on investment
in the right language.

271
00:17:23.160 --> 00:17:26.130
And that's the language of the audience.

272
00:17:26.130 --> 00:17:30.040
Now, we have two types
of return on investment.

273
00:17:30.040 --> 00:17:35.212
We have the pre-program ROI,
and the post-program ROI.

274
00:17:35.212 --> 00:17:38.600
The pre-program ROI is what
appears in the business case.

275
00:17:38.600 --> 00:17:43.078
That's the expected return on investment.

276
00:17:43.078 --> 00:17:46.390
The post-program ROI is what happens

277
00:17:46.390 --> 00:17:49.330
after an improvement initiative
has been implemented.

278
00:17:49.330 --> 00:17:51.790
Generally, after a set
period of time as well.

279
00:17:51.790 --> 00:17:55.130
It's not just something that you do
immediately after implementation.

280
00:17:55.130 --> 00:17:58.810
Usually you might calculate this
maybe a month afterwards, and

281
00:17:58.810 --> 00:18:01.960
then again three months, and
then again six months afterwards.

282
00:18:01.960 --> 00:18:05.570
And that's what we call post-program ROI.

283
00:18:05.570 --> 00:18:07.780
In other words, after we've implemented.

284
00:18:07.780 --> 00:18:11.114
And as it says there in the second
from last bullet point,

285
00:18:11.114 --> 00:18:14.031
that sufficient time has
got to elapse in order for

286
00:18:14.031 --> 00:18:17.801
us to be able to see whether
we've realized post-program ROI.

287
00:18:17.801 --> 00:18:22.349
So the pre-prorgram ROI is what
appears in our business case.

288
00:18:22.349 --> 00:18:26.889
And the post-program ROI is
what we calculate after we've

289
00:18:26.889 --> 00:18:29.351
implemented the improvement.

290
00:18:29.351 --> 00:18:33.808
And it's that post-program ROI
will tell us how accurate our

291
00:18:33.808 --> 00:18:36.471
pre-program ROI calculation was.

292
00:18:36.471 --> 00:18:41.183
Now, there's a really simplistic
calculation there in that last bullet

293
00:18:41.183 --> 00:18:42.310
point.

294
00:18:42.310 --> 00:18:42.990
And, for

295
00:18:42.990 --> 00:18:46.538
those of you that are not familiar
with financial management techniques.

296
00:18:46.538 --> 00:18:53.570
If you aren't looking to go to the CSI
examination and testing at the end

297
00:18:53.570 --> 00:18:58.240
of this class, then believe me, you don't
have to remember this calculation, okay.

298
00:18:58.240 --> 00:19:03.471
This is a very simple calculation that we
would use from a very, very high level.

299
00:19:03.471 --> 00:19:08.071
In truth, we're probably going to use a
much more complex calculation in the real

300
00:19:08.071 --> 00:19:12.420
world for calculating both the pre-program
ROI and the post-program ROI.

301
00:19:12.420 --> 00:19:17.239
And we're gonna get information for
calculating pre-program ROI from

302
00:19:17.239 --> 00:19:21.273
previous projects,
because that's gonna help us, okay?

303
00:19:21.273 --> 00:19:25.891
Having all of that information
within financial management,

304
00:19:25.891 --> 00:19:30.680
they should be able to highlight
where we can achieve our ROI, and

305
00:19:30.680 --> 00:19:32.785
instances where we can't.

306
00:19:32.785 --> 00:19:38.580
And as I've mentioned, this ROI,
well that appears in a business case.

307
00:19:38.580 --> 00:19:41.450
Now, a couple of things that I want
to mention about a business case.

308
00:19:41.450 --> 00:19:47.800
And a business case is a justification for
a significant item of expenditure.

309
00:19:47.800 --> 00:19:52.600
And the level of approval is completely
dependent on the scale of the project.

310
00:19:52.600 --> 00:19:56.010
A business case is a document, and
as such, has to have an owner.

311
00:19:56.010 --> 00:19:58.130
Now we'll say that it's
the responsibility for

312
00:19:58.130 --> 00:20:01.192
an actual management to
compile the business case.

313
00:20:01.192 --> 00:20:04.210
But never-the-less, there's going to
be involvement certainly from business

314
00:20:04.210 --> 00:20:07.230
relationship management,
from strategy management,

315
00:20:07.230 --> 00:20:11.440
from service portfolio management,
and from CSI as well.

316
00:20:11.440 --> 00:20:16.450
Because anything that we bring in,
any new service, or any new process, or

317
00:20:16.450 --> 00:20:22.070
any new tool is going to be an improvement
in our current infrastructure.

318
00:20:22.070 --> 00:20:24.890
So a business case will
have to be compiled.

319
00:20:24.890 --> 00:20:29.160
The level of detail contained
within the business case, well,

320
00:20:29.160 --> 00:20:32.980
that's completely dependent on the scale
of the actual improvement project.

321
00:20:34.140 --> 00:20:36.670
And the one thing that I really want
to mention about the business case,

322
00:20:36.670 --> 00:20:42.240
is the business case should contain
both methods and assumptions.

323
00:20:43.410 --> 00:20:49.320
And recommendations and
alternatives, including the risks.

324
00:20:49.320 --> 00:20:54.064
And that's the risk of not implementing
a particular recommendation, and

325
00:20:54.064 --> 00:20:57.039
the risk to the organization
of implementing.

326
00:20:57.039 --> 00:20:59.610
There's always going to be a risk.

327
00:20:59.610 --> 00:21:04.330
When we bring anything new into
an environment, there's a risk of failure.

328
00:21:04.330 --> 00:21:07.450
There's a risk of impact to
the current infrastructure.

329
00:21:07.450 --> 00:21:09.210
We can't just bury our
head in the sands and

330
00:21:09.210 --> 00:21:12.030
forget that that's not going to happen,
because it is.

331
00:21:12.030 --> 00:21:16.550
So we have to demonstrate that we
have calculated that risk, and

332
00:21:16.550 --> 00:21:19.270
that we understand the risk,
and it's okay.

333
00:21:19.270 --> 00:21:23.870
We're doing risk management on those
particular risks that we've identified.

334
00:21:26.150 --> 00:21:28.810
So Ronnie, what we've looked at
then over this last session,

335
00:21:28.810 --> 00:21:30.677
is we've looked at the balance scorecard.

336
00:21:30.677 --> 00:21:34.883
And we have looked at the strengths,
and weaknesses, and opportunities, and

337
00:21:34.883 --> 00:21:35.463
threats.

338
00:21:35.463 --> 00:21:36.640
Now you see why we used the acronym.

339
00:21:36.640 --> 00:21:37.909
>> Right.
>> Yeah, it's so much easier.

340
00:21:37.909 --> 00:21:42.360
And we've looked at ROI, and
also value on investments as well.

341
00:21:42.360 --> 00:21:44.927
And in the next section, we're going to

342
00:21:44.927 --> 00:21:49.620
look at improvement techniques that
are undertaken by other processes.

343
00:21:49.620 --> 00:21:53.880
Such as availability management,
problem management, etc.

344
00:21:53.880 --> 00:22:00.560
But for now, what we'd like you to do, is
we'd like you to go back over your notes.

345
00:22:00.560 --> 00:22:03.010
There are some exercises there for

346
00:22:03.010 --> 00:22:06.830
you that will help you understand all of
the techniques that we've looked at in

347
00:22:06.830 --> 00:22:10.960
the previous few sections to
do with metrics and reporting.

348
00:22:10.960 --> 00:22:15.690
And as always, if you have any
questions on any of those exercises,

349
00:22:15.690 --> 00:22:18.610
then please feel free to
join us in the forum where

350
00:22:18.610 --> 00:22:21.880
I'll be happy to answer any of
the questions that you have.

351
00:22:21.880 --> 00:22:23.840
All right, Jo, well thank you again for

352
00:22:23.840 --> 00:22:27.820
helping us out with taking a look at
the idea of the balance score card.

353
00:22:27.820 --> 00:22:33.330
As well as the swot analysis that we have,
and even the return on investment.

354
00:22:33.330 --> 00:22:38.030
All these are great analysis tools that
really do help us when it comes down to

355
00:22:38.030 --> 00:22:42.640
actually thinking about the idea of
the CSI techniques that we need to use.

356
00:22:42.640 --> 00:22:45.860
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

357
00:22:45.860 --> 00:22:49.710
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

358
00:22:49.710 --> 00:22:50.760
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

359
00:22:50.760 --> 00:22:54.824
>> Stay right here for
more of the ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

360
00:22:54.824 --> 00:23:02.314
[MUSIC]

361
00:23:02.314 --> 00:23:04.786
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss availability management.  Jo discusses that it begins with identifying SPoFs and evaluating them in terms of risks.  Also she describes the CFIA which helps to identify potential point of failure before they occur.  She contrasts this with FTA which is based on technology and topology that looks at the past.  Jo also describes SFA to help with end to end service availability and the Expanded incident Lifecycleâ€”Detect,Diagnose,Repair, Recover and Restoration).
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - CSI and Availability Mgmt
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:03.506
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.506 --> 00:00:06.309
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.309 --> 00:00:08.236
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.236 --> 00:00:11.868
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.868 --> 00:00:16.110
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.110 --> 00:00:19.890
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate CSI show.

7
00:00:19.890 --> 00:00:23.550
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong and
today we're actually jumping in and

8
00:00:23.550 --> 00:00:27.840
we're taking a look at CSI and
Availability Management.

9
00:00:27.840 --> 00:00:32.115
And here to help us once more is going
to be well our ITIL ninja master.

10
00:00:32.115 --> 00:00:34.065
The master herself, Miss Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:34.065 --> 00:00:35.475
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:35.475 --> 00:00:37.997
>> Thank you for having me Ronnie,
it's great to be here.

13
00:00:37.997 --> 00:00:41.635
>> All right Jo, we've been taking a look
all these different techniques and

14
00:00:41.635 --> 00:00:46.975
there is a bit more for us to actually
take a look at and to talk about as well.

15
00:00:46.975 --> 00:00:50.655
So let's talk about this idea
of Availability Management and

16
00:00:50.655 --> 00:00:54.370
its importance in this process of
continually service improvement.

17
00:00:54.370 --> 00:00:56.350
>> Okay.
Well, Availability Management is a process

18
00:00:56.350 --> 00:00:59.080
that we looked at in service design, and

19
00:00:59.080 --> 00:01:01.760
it's a process that's
split into two parts.

20
00:01:01.760 --> 00:01:04.820
It's split into both proactive and
reactive.

21
00:01:04.820 --> 00:01:09.950
And proactively, we are planning for
availability in our new services, and

22
00:01:09.950 --> 00:01:12.650
also in our existing
services going forward,

23
00:01:12.650 --> 00:01:16.290
at least once a year we
produce an availability plan.

24
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:18.690
And reactively,
we're assisting incident and

25
00:01:18.690 --> 00:01:22.860
problem management with any
availability related issues.

26
00:01:22.860 --> 00:01:28.400
You see, what Availability Management does
is look for potential points of failure.

27
00:01:29.410 --> 00:01:34.380
And Availability Management looks
at reliability of our components.

28
00:01:34.380 --> 00:01:38.130
And it looks at potential
redundancy options.

29
00:01:38.130 --> 00:01:42.420
So performance risk management for
the components within our service.

30
00:01:42.420 --> 00:01:46.900
So looking at both future services, and

31
00:01:46.900 --> 00:01:51.260
also at our existing services, and
planning for Availability Management.

32
00:01:51.260 --> 00:01:54.890
Now, Ronnie, in a previous section you
mentioned to me about alphabet soup.

33
00:01:54.890 --> 00:01:55.580
>> Right.

34
00:01:55.580 --> 00:01:58.438
>> Well I want you to take a look at what
we have in brackets, or in parenthesis,

35
00:01:58.438 --> 00:01:59.430
right in front of you now.

36
00:01:59.430 --> 00:02:00.172
>> Once more, yep.

37
00:02:00.172 --> 00:02:03.700
>> And we brought in a few more.

38
00:02:03.700 --> 00:02:05.050
Just to keep you happy really.

39
00:02:05.050 --> 00:02:06.617
>> Nice.
>> Cuz I didn't want you feeling

40
00:02:06.617 --> 00:02:07.638
left out in this section.

41
00:02:07.638 --> 00:02:09.020
>> Love it.

42
00:02:09.020 --> 00:02:11.779
>> What we're gonna be doing,
is we're gonna be looking in

43
00:02:11.779 --> 00:02:14.515
this particular section here
at all of those acronyms.

44
00:02:14.515 --> 00:02:16.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're gonna be looking at techniques

45
00:02:16.160 --> 00:02:22.540
that Availability Management uses
to identify what we call SPOFs.

46
00:02:22.540 --> 00:02:26.090
S P O F, I know, it's another acronym,
right, I'm sorry.

47
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:29.680
And SPOF is a Single Point of Failure.

48
00:02:29.680 --> 00:02:33.670
Because what we're interested in is
identifying those points of failure,

49
00:02:33.670 --> 00:02:38.750
evaluating those points of failure,
and evaluating the risk.

50
00:02:38.750 --> 00:02:39.590
In other words,

51
00:02:39.590 --> 00:02:43.940
the likelihood of whether those
particular points of failure will fail.

52
00:02:43.940 --> 00:02:48.200
Now, sometimes we look to the past and
we say, has it failed in the past.

53
00:02:48.200 --> 00:02:49.260
Then, if it has,

54
00:02:49.260 --> 00:02:53.520
then there could be an increased
likelihood of it failing in the future.

55
00:02:53.520 --> 00:02:58.590
But sometimes we just don't know,
and so we have to try and identify

56
00:02:58.590 --> 00:03:02.190
potential points of failure even in our
new services and in our existing ones.

57
00:03:02.190 --> 00:03:04.980
And just say well, you know what,
this is an exposure.

58
00:03:04.980 --> 00:03:09.630
And so, we're gonna use various
techniques in order to try and

59
00:03:09.630 --> 00:03:12.410
increase the availability of our services.

60
00:03:12.410 --> 00:03:14.612
So why aren't we looking
at this in service design?

61
00:03:14.612 --> 00:03:15.251
Well, we do.

62
00:03:15.251 --> 00:03:20.599
But as part of CSI, Continual Service
Improvement, because we acknowledge

63
00:03:20.599 --> 00:03:25.470
that everything that we do in
Availability Management is to improve.

64
00:03:26.860 --> 00:03:29.520
Now, sometimes when we're
performing risk management,

65
00:03:29.520 --> 00:03:33.040
we might decide that we
just want to accept a risk.

66
00:03:33.040 --> 00:03:34.660
But here we're looking at improvement.

67
00:03:34.660 --> 00:03:37.320
So here we're looking
at identifying risks.

68
00:03:37.320 --> 00:03:39.770
We're looking at identifying
points of failure.

69
00:03:39.770 --> 00:03:44.240
And we're looking at the options that
are available to us, to try and mitigate

70
00:03:44.240 --> 00:03:48.980
either against those risks or mitigate
against the effects of those risks.

71
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:53.820
Or maybe just helps us with
risk management itself.

72
00:03:53.820 --> 00:03:58.084
See, so that last bullet point about
helping an organization recognize where

73
00:03:58.084 --> 00:03:59.579
they can add value, okay?

74
00:04:00.650 --> 00:04:02.723
So it's all about Availability Management.

75
00:04:02.723 --> 00:04:08.350
And in following sessions, we're going
to look at links between CSI and

76
00:04:08.350 --> 00:04:12.514
other processes within
the ITIL service life cycle.

77
00:04:13.660 --> 00:04:18.030
So let's take that alphabet soup,
then, and let's start off with one.

78
00:04:18.030 --> 00:04:19.890
And I'm gonna start off with CFIA,

79
00:04:19.890 --> 00:04:22.370
or Component Failure Impact Analysis,
it is called.

80
00:04:23.550 --> 00:04:26.440
And it simply says there that
it's necessary to predict and

81
00:04:26.440 --> 00:04:31.380
value a potential impact on
availability from a component failure.

82
00:04:31.380 --> 00:04:37.899
What we're gonna do is we're going to take
a look at a network topology diagram.

83
00:04:38.930 --> 00:04:41.538
And we are going to remove a component.

84
00:04:41.538 --> 00:04:45.910
And we're gonna say, if this component
fails, I'm gonna put a big red

85
00:04:45.910 --> 00:04:50.510
X through it, if this component fails,
what's going to happen?

86
00:04:50.510 --> 00:04:55.560
What is the impact to our
organization going to be?

87
00:04:55.560 --> 00:04:58.520
That's what
Component Failure Impact Analysis does.

88
00:04:58.520 --> 00:04:59.690
And why do we do this?

89
00:04:59.690 --> 00:05:02.260
Well, we do this because
what we want to do

90
00:05:02.260 --> 00:05:04.580
is identify potential point of failures,

91
00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:09.410
we've already ascertained that, but
then what we want to do is see the impact.

92
00:05:09.410 --> 00:05:14.520
And the impact will then allow us to
make a decision as to whether we add

93
00:05:14.520 --> 00:05:18.500
in resilience options such as mirroring or
redundancy or

94
00:05:18.500 --> 00:05:21.360
whether we just want to accept that risk.

95
00:05:22.440 --> 00:05:25.700
So, let's take a look
at the next slide then.

96
00:05:25.700 --> 00:05:28.530
And the next slide actually shows us,

97
00:05:28.530 --> 00:05:33.400
in this particular network topology
diagram, a very, very basic one.

98
00:05:33.400 --> 00:05:35.800
We're looking at two
different services here.

99
00:05:35.800 --> 00:05:38.320
And these are how
the services hang together.

100
00:05:39.700 --> 00:05:43.500
Now, what you've got here in the right
hand side, in the box there,

101
00:05:43.500 --> 00:05:50.360
you've got next to each PC, you've got
either an M or an X or an A, okay?

102
00:05:50.360 --> 00:05:53.215
And then M talks about
a manual intervention.

103
00:05:53.215 --> 00:05:57.595
And a manual intervention means that,
if that component fails,

104
00:05:57.595 --> 00:06:02.515
there has to be a manual intervention
to switch over to another component.

105
00:06:02.515 --> 00:06:08.515
So, for service one, to switch from PC one
to PC two would me a manual intervention.

106
00:06:10.300 --> 00:06:13.570
Now, we also got X's and we've got A's.

107
00:06:13.570 --> 00:06:16.990
Now, the A stands for automatic,
automatic intervention.

108
00:06:16.990 --> 00:06:18.830
So if we come down in service one,

109
00:06:18.830 --> 00:06:23.640
you'll see right down near the bottom
to switch from disk 1 to disk 2 well,

110
00:06:23.640 --> 00:06:28.220
actually there is an automatic
switch between those two disks.

111
00:06:28.220 --> 00:06:30.830
So if one fails there's
an automatic switch.

112
00:06:32.160 --> 00:06:36.110
But everywhere where there is an X,
there's an exposure.

113
00:06:37.880 --> 00:06:42.990
And an exposure means that there may
not be a resilience option in place.

114
00:06:44.030 --> 00:06:46.580
There may not be any redundancy.

115
00:06:46.580 --> 00:06:52.220
And so what that means is, we have to
consider what we do in that instance.

116
00:06:52.220 --> 00:06:55.180
Whether we add in redundancy or not.

117
00:06:55.180 --> 00:06:59.240
Now, there are some blank and that blank
section really simply means that we

118
00:06:59.240 --> 00:07:02.610
don't need redundancy between
application one and two.

119
00:07:02.610 --> 00:07:06.120
We don't need redundancy because
application one is for service one and

120
00:07:06.120 --> 00:07:08.530
application two is for service two and,

121
00:07:08.530 --> 00:07:12.290
therefore, we shouldn't have fail
over between the two anyway.

122
00:07:12.290 --> 00:07:15.890
Obviously, because they're different
services, and in different applications.

123
00:07:17.076 --> 00:07:21.670
So the X is where we've got potential
exposures, and the Xs actually allow us

124
00:07:21.670 --> 00:07:25.810
to not only identify those exposures,

125
00:07:25.810 --> 00:07:30.930
but now we can make decisions as to what
we want to do about those exposures.

126
00:07:30.930 --> 00:07:37.410
So between switch one and switch two,
well, switch two's not even on there.

127
00:07:37.410 --> 00:07:39.160
So, is there

128
00:07:41.070 --> 00:07:45.290
any type of intervention required
between switch one and switch two?

129
00:07:45.290 --> 00:07:48.564
I'm guessing not because I don't see
switch one and switch two there.

130
00:07:48.564 --> 00:07:52.456
So maybe we can't actually move
from switch one to switch two.

131
00:07:52.456 --> 00:07:57.071
So maybe we need to add in some resilience
in switch one because If switch one,

132
00:07:57.071 --> 00:08:01.650
there's nothing or there's no
redundancy there against switch one.

133
00:08:01.650 --> 00:08:03.750
Then that means that those two PCs,

134
00:08:03.750 --> 00:08:07.540
if that switch fails, those two
PCs cannot access either service.

135
00:08:09.990 --> 00:08:14.460
So it allows us to make decisions it
doesn't make the decisions for us.

136
00:08:14.460 --> 00:08:17.620
And none of these techniques
are gonna make decisions for us.

137
00:08:17.620 --> 00:08:21.010
But it allows us to highlight
potential points of failure.

138
00:08:22.330 --> 00:08:24.780
Now the same could be said for
Fault Tree Analysis.

139
00:08:24.780 --> 00:08:28.460
And Fault Tree Analysis looks
at what's already happened.

140
00:08:29.460 --> 00:08:32.190
So what has caused a disruption and

141
00:08:32.190 --> 00:08:37.700
says okay then, what events were
they that caused this disruption?

142
00:08:37.700 --> 00:08:42.007
And we look at different types of
events here such as basic events, or

143
00:08:42.007 --> 00:08:46.466
resulting events or a conditional
event that only occurs under certain

144
00:08:46.466 --> 00:08:51.390
conditions through a trigger event,
something that triggers other events.

145
00:08:51.390 --> 00:08:56.558
Okay let's take a look then at
this particular diagram here.

146
00:08:56.558 --> 00:09:00.143
So I'm gonna start off
with the top here and

147
00:09:00.143 --> 00:09:05.628
the service was down okay, so
what caused the service to be down?

148
00:09:05.628 --> 00:09:09.964
Well, by the way, just as an aside there,
it was outside of service hours, so

149
00:09:09.964 --> 00:09:11.805
is that really important?

150
00:09:11.805 --> 00:09:14.175
Well, the service is down, so yes, it is.

151
00:09:14.175 --> 00:09:16.997
So, okay, the service was down,
because the system was down.

152
00:09:16.997 --> 00:09:19.117
So why was the system down?

153
00:09:19.117 --> 00:09:22.647
Well it either could've been because
the server was down or the application,

154
00:09:22.647 --> 00:09:25.127
the software was not available.

155
00:09:25.127 --> 00:09:27.097
Or it was because the network was done.

156
00:09:27.097 --> 00:09:29.067
So then we'll carry on and we'll say okay,

157
00:09:29.067 --> 00:09:31.313
well, it was the network
that was actually down.

158
00:09:31.313 --> 00:09:34.268
Okay, why was the network down?

159
00:09:34.268 --> 00:09:36.378
Well, was it either a primary line, or

160
00:09:36.378 --> 00:09:40.268
was it our backup or
our fail over line that was down?

161
00:09:40.268 --> 00:09:44.478
And so what we're doing is
we're going down a fault, and

162
00:09:44.478 --> 00:09:47.008
we're saying, okay what caused that?

163
00:09:47.008 --> 00:09:48.408
And then what caused that?

164
00:09:48.408 --> 00:09:52.307
And we're just going down
each particular event and

165
00:09:52.307 --> 00:09:55.859
looking at the cause of
each particular event.

166
00:09:55.859 --> 00:09:58.930
Now this is based on the technology.

167
00:09:58.930 --> 00:10:02.163
So this is Fault Tree Analysis and
it's based on the technology.

168
00:10:02.163 --> 00:10:05.123
It's based again on our network topology,

169
00:10:05.123 --> 00:10:09.560
very similar to the component
failure impact analysis.

170
00:10:09.560 --> 00:10:14.516
But component failure impact
analysis was planning for

171
00:10:14.516 --> 00:10:19.902
the future this is looking at
the past to plan for the future.

172
00:10:19.902 --> 00:10:22.317
And then we have service
failure analysis or SFA.

173
00:10:22.317 --> 00:10:25.719
And service failure analysis is very,

174
00:10:25.719 --> 00:10:30.875
very similar to faltery analysis
where we're just looking

175
00:10:30.875 --> 00:10:36.380
at end-to-end availability
of an entire service.

176
00:10:36.380 --> 00:10:41.670
So where fault tree analysis looks to
identify a particular component that has

177
00:10:41.670 --> 00:10:44.730
caused a failure, service failure analysis

178
00:10:44.730 --> 00:10:49.100
actually looks at the end-to-end
service in its entirety.

179
00:10:49.100 --> 00:10:52.630
Looks at the end-to-end service and
says okay,

180
00:10:52.630 --> 00:10:57.270
what could cause a problem
in that end-to-end service?

181
00:10:58.400 --> 00:11:03.010
And you'll see here, and
I mentioned what could cause a service.

182
00:11:03.010 --> 00:11:07.306
So you'll see here that I have
underneath this particular diagram here,

183
00:11:07.306 --> 00:11:08.910
selected an opportunity.

184
00:11:08.910 --> 00:11:12.360
In other words, I've found where there's
been a failure in end-to-end service.

185
00:11:12.360 --> 00:11:16.790
And what I'm going to do,
is I'm going to scope my analysis,

186
00:11:16.790 --> 00:11:20.965
then I plan it and I build hypothesis,
which is all about,

187
00:11:20.965 --> 00:11:24.826
well was it caused by this,
and was it caused by this?

188
00:11:24.826 --> 00:11:30.192
Was the failure itself,
caused by something very large on,

189
00:11:30.192 --> 00:11:36.860
sorry, was the failure itself caused
by some form of technical issue.

190
00:11:36.860 --> 00:11:40.720
But it was compounded by the fact
that the incident then wasn't

191
00:11:40.720 --> 00:11:43.070
resolved quickly enough okay?

192
00:11:43.070 --> 00:11:45.390
So that's when I build my hypothesis.

193
00:11:45.390 --> 00:11:49.523
And my hypothesis will not just be
based in the technical components,

194
00:11:49.523 --> 00:11:51.988
it will be based on the processes as well.

195
00:11:51.988 --> 00:11:55.380
So my end-to-end service metrics.

196
00:11:55.380 --> 00:11:56.870
And then I analyze the data.

197
00:11:56.870 --> 00:12:01.507
And I might need to interview people,
I might need to go back to people and

198
00:12:01.507 --> 00:12:03.600
ask them for their opinion.

199
00:12:03.600 --> 00:12:06.670
Why wasn't the incident closed quickly?

200
00:12:06.670 --> 00:12:09.130
Why wasn't it resolved quick enough?

201
00:12:09.130 --> 00:12:12.930
And then I draw my conclusions
based upon my findings.

202
00:12:12.930 --> 00:12:15.388
And then I make recommendations.

203
00:12:15.388 --> 00:12:19.898
And those recommendations,
they will be by way of a nice,

204
00:12:19.898 --> 00:12:26.100
pretty picture of a graph and remember
we only do that to produce a decision.

205
00:12:26.100 --> 00:12:30.440
And that decision that will
validate that actually we made

206
00:12:30.440 --> 00:12:35.315
the right amount of investigation and
we undertook the right path

207
00:12:35.315 --> 00:12:40.210
on that investigation in order to
be able to make an improvement.

208
00:12:40.210 --> 00:12:45.399
So the service failure analysis
looks at the entire service,

209
00:12:45.399 --> 00:12:47.808
the end-to-end service.

210
00:12:47.808 --> 00:12:51.887
From a previous section we
covered the fact that service,

211
00:12:51.887 --> 00:12:56.634
end-to-end service metrics are made
up of technology metrics and

212
00:12:56.634 --> 00:13:02.297
processed metrics, combined, to measure
the entire end-to-end service and

213
00:13:02.297 --> 00:13:06.580
that is exactly what the service
failure analysis does.

214
00:13:06.580 --> 00:13:12.060
Is that it takes a look at a failure but
doesn't just look at the faulty analysis.

215
00:13:12.060 --> 00:13:14.308
It doesn't just look at the technology.

216
00:13:14.308 --> 00:13:19.080
It also looks at the processes that
impacted on that failure as well.

217
00:13:20.450 --> 00:13:26.100
So now we've got other techniques that we
use within availability management, too.

218
00:13:26.100 --> 00:13:32.310
And the first is what we call, we call
this a TOP, a technical observation post.

219
00:13:32.310 --> 00:13:36.305
So Ronnie if I mention the word TOP
to you, technical observation post,

220
00:13:36.305 --> 00:13:37.754
what do you think that is?

221
00:13:37.754 --> 00:13:42.248
>> [LAUGH]
I would assume as somebody that

222
00:13:42.248 --> 00:13:46.720
takes a look at the technology that's
implemented and sees if it fits.

223
00:13:47.920 --> 00:13:49.140
>> It's not, it's really basic.

224
00:13:49.140 --> 00:13:51.931
It's really, really basic and in fact,

225
00:13:51.931 --> 00:13:56.500
a technical observation post is
where we sit and watch and wait.

226
00:13:56.500 --> 00:13:59.885
>> Nice
>> That's a technical observation post.

227
00:13:59.885 --> 00:14:04.695
And it really just involves a lot
of technical people sitting,

228
00:14:04.695 --> 00:14:08.610
and watching, and waiting for
something to fail.

229
00:14:08.610 --> 00:14:11.170
It's about monitoring events in realtor.

230
00:14:11.170 --> 00:14:12.673
Sometimes we have failures and

231
00:14:12.673 --> 00:14:15.692
we don't actually understand
why something keeps failing.

232
00:14:15.692 --> 00:14:20.560
And sometimes we just have to wait and
watch for it to fail.

233
00:14:20.560 --> 00:14:24.025
This is utilized quite
often when we've had, and

234
00:14:24.025 --> 00:14:28.078
I've seen this used in the past,
many many years ago now.

235
00:14:28.078 --> 00:14:30.918
But I've seen it used
very effectively where in

236
00:14:30.918 --> 00:14:36.130
one organization a server kept failing,
and they couldn't understand why.

237
00:14:36.130 --> 00:14:39.584
On a Monday morning,
they'd come into the office and

238
00:14:39.584 --> 00:14:41.980
the server was always unavailable.

239
00:14:41.980 --> 00:14:44.880
It was always down and
they really couldn't understand why.

240
00:14:44.880 --> 00:14:47.910
So what they did was they set up
a technical observation post and

241
00:14:47.910 --> 00:14:52.040
they actually had somebody working over
the weekend, a group of people on shift

242
00:14:52.040 --> 00:14:55.560
work and over the weekend,
just watching to see what would happen.

243
00:14:55.560 --> 00:15:01.692
And at one point in time,
on the Sunday morning, the server died.

244
00:15:01.692 --> 00:15:05.206
Went offline, completely offline and
so somebody went and

245
00:15:05.206 --> 00:15:06.830
went into the server room.

246
00:15:06.830 --> 00:15:09.555
This was a technical observation post,
they were sitting waiting for

247
00:15:09.555 --> 00:15:10.116
it to happen.

248
00:15:10.116 --> 00:15:14.907
They went in to the server room that
the cleaner had unplugged the server to

249
00:15:14.907 --> 00:15:16.230
plug in her vacuum.

250
00:15:16.230 --> 00:15:18.502
>> There you go.

251
00:15:18.502 --> 00:15:22.862
>> That would never have been discovered
by anybody else other than watching

252
00:15:22.862 --> 00:15:25.884
a video camera,
a video recording of the event, or

253
00:15:25.884 --> 00:15:28.923
by somebody watching and
waiting for the failure.

254
00:15:28.923 --> 00:15:32.560
And that is a technical observation,
simple as that..

255
00:15:32.560 --> 00:15:34.850
Technical people observing.

256
00:15:34.850 --> 00:15:39.658
Okay, so then that brings me onto the last
technique that we're going to look at in

257
00:15:39.658 --> 00:15:43.073
availability management now,
and that is the expanded or

258
00:15:43.073 --> 00:15:44.968
extended incident life cycle.

259
00:15:44.968 --> 00:15:46.583
And we can call it both.

260
00:15:46.583 --> 00:15:50.223
I've seen it called both in the ITIL
publications and quite happy for

261
00:15:50.223 --> 00:15:51.112
you to use both.

262
00:15:51.112 --> 00:15:55.446
And really, what we do is,
it's a technique for

263
00:15:55.446 --> 00:16:01.371
analyzing incidents,
incidents that have happened in the past,

264
00:16:01.371 --> 00:16:06.446
and then working out what we
can do in the future to prevent

265
00:16:06.446 --> 00:16:13.470
the incident from being outstanding
as long, or for being open as long.

266
00:16:13.470 --> 00:16:16.120
So let's take a look at the next slide.

267
00:16:16.120 --> 00:16:21.520
And I want you to focus your eyes here,
on this particular section here.

268
00:16:22.570 --> 00:16:27.000
What we do, this is our downtime,
this is when the incident starts.

269
00:16:27.000 --> 00:16:29.680
And this is when the incident or

270
00:16:29.680 --> 00:16:33.230
the service was restored right here,
this particular line here.

271
00:16:34.550 --> 00:16:37.030
So what we're going to do is we're
going to take that incident.

272
00:16:37.030 --> 00:16:39.080
And we're going to split it into five.

273
00:16:40.130 --> 00:16:47.420
Detection, diagnosis, repair, recovery
of data, and restoration of service.

274
00:16:49.400 --> 00:16:53.360
Now, what we want to do, is we want to
take each one of those sections, and

275
00:16:53.360 --> 00:16:57.230
we want to reduce the amount of time

276
00:16:57.230 --> 00:17:01.570
that each section took in order
to advance on to the next.

277
00:17:02.710 --> 00:17:08.014
Thereby if we reduce each individual
section, detection, diagnosis,

278
00:17:08.014 --> 00:17:12.804
repair, recovery of data and
restoration of service to the user,

279
00:17:12.804 --> 00:17:17.764
if we reduce each section,
then the next time the incident happens,

280
00:17:17.764 --> 00:17:20.757
you'll see here in our downtime, well,

281
00:17:20.757 --> 00:17:24.635
it was actually down for
a lot shorter period of time.

282
00:17:24.635 --> 00:17:29.510
So here, in availability management then,
we analyze each section and we say, okay

283
00:17:29.510 --> 00:17:34.630
then, what can we do to reduce the amount
of time taken to detect an incident?

284
00:17:34.630 --> 00:17:38.140
Well, we can use event management to
automatically detect an incident.

285
00:17:39.530 --> 00:17:43.450
What about the amount of time taken
to diagnose an incident then?

286
00:17:43.450 --> 00:17:47.460
Well, we could use things like script,
for instance.

287
00:17:47.460 --> 00:17:50.480
What about the amount of
time taken to repair?

288
00:17:50.480 --> 00:17:54.710
Well, sometimes, you can't reduce
that time, but sometimes we can.

289
00:17:54.710 --> 00:17:56.500
Maybe we can automate.

290
00:17:56.500 --> 00:17:58.210
What about recovery of data?

291
00:17:58.210 --> 00:18:01.049
Well, if we could get quicker
access to backups, for instance,

292
00:18:01.049 --> 00:18:02.710
maybe we could recover data quicker.

293
00:18:02.710 --> 00:18:05.990
And what about restoration
of service to the user?

294
00:18:05.990 --> 00:18:08.840
Don't forget in incident management,
we have to confirm with

295
00:18:08.840 --> 00:18:11.920
the user that they're happy
that service has been restored.

296
00:18:11.920 --> 00:18:14.740
So maybe in the service level agreement,

297
00:18:14.740 --> 00:18:17.100
we incorporate the three strikes and
out rule.

298
00:18:17.100 --> 00:18:19.270
We don't want to keep pass them in you and

299
00:18:19.270 --> 00:18:23.560
keep ringing you every 30 minutes to
see whether service has been restored.

300
00:18:23.560 --> 00:18:27.640
So what we're going to do is we're going
to say, well, we tried to call you twice.

301
00:18:27.640 --> 00:18:30.910
And then, we sent you an email, and so
now we're gonna close the incident.

302
00:18:30.910 --> 00:18:35.240
And if you have any more problems,
then just give us a call again.

303
00:18:35.240 --> 00:18:40.650
So we want to reduce each
particular one of those sections.

304
00:18:40.650 --> 00:18:45.440
Then, by the next time the incident
happens, then we reduce the downtime.

305
00:18:46.540 --> 00:18:50.340
So that's what we call the extended or
expanded incident life cycle.

306
00:18:51.670 --> 00:18:56.659
So what we've looked at then over this
particular section are the techniques that

307
00:18:56.659 --> 00:19:01.793
availability management uses to identify
potential points of failure and to try and

308
00:19:01.793 --> 00:19:06.782
minimize either the impact caused by those
points of failure or actually to try and

309
00:19:06.782 --> 00:19:12.090
remove the failure themselves by adding in
maybe resilience and redundancy options.

310
00:19:12.090 --> 00:19:15.857
And, of course,
every time we do something like that,

311
00:19:15.857 --> 00:19:20.104
we do it because we want to improve
our service availability and

312
00:19:20.104 --> 00:19:25.415
our delivery of that service to our
organization by delivering value to them.

313
00:19:26.800 --> 00:19:31.220
In our next section, we're actually going
to be looking at the interaction of

314
00:19:31.220 --> 00:19:35.310
other processes within
the service life cycle and CSI.

315
00:19:35.310 --> 00:19:38.300
And what techniques they
undertake as part of CSI.

316
00:19:39.580 --> 00:19:40.190
>> Alright, Jo.

317
00:19:40.190 --> 00:19:44.190
Well, thank you again for introducing us
to some of those different techniques.

318
00:19:44.190 --> 00:19:48.618
That the idea of the incremental changes
and those small little things that really

319
00:19:48.618 --> 00:19:52.910
add up to shortening things really is
an improvement that can help us all.

320
00:19:52.910 --> 00:19:55.790
So this is a great thing for
us to actually think about and

321
00:19:55.790 --> 00:19:57.780
make sure you review those concepts,
as well.

322
00:19:57.780 --> 00:20:00.160
This is a great place for
us also end this episode.

323
00:20:00.160 --> 00:20:03.220
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

324
00:20:03.220 --> 00:20:04.300
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

325
00:20:04.300 --> 00:20:07.937
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

326
00:20:07.937 --> 00:20:14.788
[MUSIC]

327
00:20:14.788 --> 00:20:17.170
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

Alao described by Jo would be demand management and knowledge management.
episodes.title: CSI Techniques - CSI and Lifecycle Processes

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the idea of accountability and responsibility is the key to organizing for CSI.  Jo states that itâ€™s import for an organization to define the process owner and manager.  She also emphasizes the need for these roles to be filled with skilled people who can do analysis, reporting and knows additional frameworks to get things done.  The example Jo provides is using a RACI chart as an example.
episodes.title: Organizing for CSI
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:00.585
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:00.585 --> 00:00:06.050
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.050 --> 00:00:08.152
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.152 --> 00:00:12.980
>> You're watching ITProTV
>> Welcome to

5
00:00:12.980 --> 00:00:15.440
another great episode
right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.440 --> 00:00:19.650
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate CSI show.

7
00:00:19.650 --> 00:00:24.450
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong and today
we're taking a look at organizing for

8
00:00:24.450 --> 00:00:26.160
continual service improvement.

9
00:00:26.160 --> 00:00:29.192
And here to help us,
of course, is gonna be well,

10
00:00:29.192 --> 00:00:32.390
our grandmaster of ITIL herself,
Miss Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:32.390 --> 00:00:33.710
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:33.710 --> 00:00:34.840
>> Thank you for having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:34.840 --> 00:00:35.740
How are you?

14
00:00:35.740 --> 00:00:37.570
>> I am doing great, Jo.

15
00:00:37.570 --> 00:00:42.030
As we start to take a look at this idea,
organizing for

16
00:00:42.030 --> 00:00:46.180
continual service improvement,
shouldn't just something be native?

17
00:00:46.180 --> 00:00:50.065
How much organization do we really
need to have to get this rolling?

18
00:00:50.065 --> 00:00:53.830
>> Well,
CSI should be a part of everybody's role.

19
00:00:53.830 --> 00:00:57.490
And everybody has a responsibility for
identifying improvement opportunities.

20
00:00:58.700 --> 00:01:01.520
But as I mentioned in one
of our previous sections,

21
00:01:01.520 --> 00:01:03.320
just because we have a responsibility for

22
00:01:03.320 --> 00:01:06.040
identifying improvement opportunities
doesn't mean that we do.

23
00:01:06.040 --> 00:01:09.990
And it certainly doesn't mean
that we carry that on and

24
00:01:09.990 --> 00:01:13.600
that we actually do something with
that improvement opportunity.

25
00:01:13.600 --> 00:01:17.890
So we need to have somebody that's
going to take ownership for CSI and

26
00:01:17.890 --> 00:01:22.640
we need to have dedicated roles and
responsibilities

27
00:01:22.640 --> 00:01:27.700
within all of our roles but say this is
what we should be doing in terms of CSI.

28
00:01:27.700 --> 00:01:32.050
You might think it's intuitive and it
sounds like it's intuitive and it's kinda

29
00:01:32.050 --> 00:01:35.870
the thing that you think, well, we always
wanna be getting better and sure we do.

30
00:01:36.940 --> 00:01:40.340
But we talked in previous
sessions about consistency and

31
00:01:40.340 --> 00:01:44.220
we talked about the need to have
a formal process and a formal method

32

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo talk about some of the technology considerations to help with CSI.  Jo lets us know that a single tool may be the way to go but we may find out the cost may outweigh the technology we already have.  She tells us the key is to ensure that those technologies should be inter-related to provide what the user needs.  The technologies to help with CSI should help us to identify, track and validate the improvements we need to make, the progress of the improvement and the result of that improvement.
