the relationships in place,

326
00:20:00.574 --> 00:20:05.219
working with knowledge management, to
ensure that those relationships will give

327
00:20:05.219 --> 00:20:09.820
us the information that we need in order
to identify improvement opportunities.

328
00:20:09.820 --> 00:20:14.692
And also to be able to track
improvement opportunities throughout

329
00:20:14.692 --> 00:20:17.047
their implementation as well.

330
00:20:17.047 --> 00:20:20.340
So as I said,
it's not about the latest shiny gadget,

331
00:20:20.340 --> 00:20:22.930
as much as I would love it to be,
it's not.

332
00:20:22.930 --> 00:20:25.197
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's really about having those

333
00:20:25.197 --> 00:20:29.240
relationships in place that
will help us make decisions.

334
00:20:29.240 --> 00:20:32.270
And one more thing that I
really want to add about tools.

335
00:20:32.270 --> 00:20:36.908
It was something that was mentioned in the
first slide in this particular session,

336
00:20:36.908 --> 00:20:38.178
is about automation.

337
00:20:38.178 --> 00:20:44.850
Automation is efficient when
it's configured correctly.

338
00:20:44.850 --> 00:20:47.180
So we automate where appropriate.

339
00:20:47.180 --> 00:20:50.899
So we don't wanna look for
tool that's going to do everything for us.

340
00:20:50.899 --> 00:20:56.960
You see, we'll only automate something
once we defined a particular process.

341
00:20:56.960 --> 00:20:59.950
But if the process has been
defined in an inefficient way,

342
00:20:59.950 --> 00:21:04.890
then all automation is going to do is just
gonna get us to that bad result quicker.

343
00:21:06.586 --> 00:21:11.206
So, we're gonna have to ensure that before
we automate anything we configure it in

344
00:21:11.206 --> 00:21:15.364
an efficient way because if we don't
configure it efficiently and as I said

345
00:21:15.364 --> 00:21:19.856
it's just gonna get us to the wrong result
just a little bit quicker that's all.

346
00:21:19.856 --> 00:21:23.490
So be careful,
automation is not always the answer,

347
00:21:23.490 --> 00:21:25.930
automation is where appropriate.

348
00:21:25.930 --> 00:21:29.003
>> All right Jo, thank you again for
helping us take a look and

349
00:21:29.003 --> 00:21:33.300
thinking about the idea of technology
consideration that are before us.

350
00:21:33.300 --> 00:21:37.160
It's always neat to think that maybe what
we need as an organization of course is

351
00:21:37.160 --> 00:21:38.270
one tool.

352
00:21:38.270 --> 00:21:42.840
But we might found out that that tool may
be of more of a detriment to us than just

353
00:21:42.840 --> 00:21:45.700
making sure that the relationship
between the tools we already have

354
00:21:45.700 --> 00:21:48.060
are actually going to be for us.

355
00:21:48.060 --> 00:21:52.360
So keeping that in mind, remember to
take a look at your technology and

356
00:21:52.360 --> 00:21:55.810
to consider whether or not they actually
help you to track, identify and

357
00:21:55.810 --> 00:21:58.350
validate the improvements
that you want to make.

358
00:21:58.350 --> 00:22:01.470
Well that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

359
00:22:01.470 --> 00:22:05.240
Signing off from ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

360
00:22:05.240 --> 00:22:06.240
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

361
00:22:06.240 --> 00:22:11.004
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the ITIL Intermediate CSI shows.

362
00:22:11.004 --> 00:22:16.639
[MUSIC]

363
00:22:16.639 --> 00:22:20.199
>> Thank you for watching, ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: aIn this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin with discussing the implementation and communication.  Jo emphasizes the formalization of the communication plan and helps us to know where to begin implementing CSI.  She tells us to pick a pain point to start.  She also mentions the use of CoBIT and ITIL together to know what needs to be achieved to improve and ITIL shows us how.
episodes.title: Implementation and Communication
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:01.250
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.250 --> 00:00:02.364
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.364 --> 00:00:04.982
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.982 --> 00:00:08.258
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.258 --> 00:00:12.157
You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.157 --> 00:00:15.100
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.100 --> 00:00:19.210
You're watching
the ITIL Intermediate CSI show.

8
00:00:19.210 --> 00:00:21.060
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

9
00:00:21.060 --> 00:00:26.660
today we are gonna be taking a look at
implementation and communication for CSI.

10
00:00:26.660 --> 00:00:30.694
And here to help us, of course,
is gonna be well our IT diva herself Ms.

11
00:00:30.694 --> 00:00:31.450
Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:31.450 --> 00:00:33.190
Jo, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:33.190 --> 00:00:33.700
>> Thank you.

14
00:00:33.700 --> 00:00:38.010
I guess if I'm a dealer, what I really,
really need is plenty of drinks and

15
00:00:38.010 --> 00:00:40.698
I need, yeah-
>> Yeah, we've got you a nice beverage.

16
00:00:40.698 --> 00:00:43.098
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:43.098 --> 00:00:44.170
>> I just need a green room,

18
00:00:44.170 --> 00:00:45.220
okay, just for me.

19
00:00:45.220 --> 00:00:47.020
>> Well, we've got one, too.

20
00:00:47.020 --> 00:00:49.390
So Jo, here it is, so here we are.

21
00:00:49.390 --> 00:00:53.580
We're taking a look at the idea of
implementation and communication.

22
00:00:53.580 --> 00:00:57.810
These two concepts, right, of course,
implementation sounds natural enough.

23
00:00:57.810 --> 00:01:01.630
We know that, well, continual service
improvement, somebody has to actually

24
00:01:01.630 --> 00:01:05.420
implement it, but the communication part,
Joe, isn't that obvious?

25
00:01:05.420 --> 00:01:08.530
>> You would like to think that
communication was obvious and

26
00:01:08.530 --> 00:01:12.170
that communication is something that we
address actually in all of our life cycle

27
00:01:12.170 --> 00:01:18.280
phases and predominantly in service
operation and also in CSI as well.

28
00:01:18.280 --> 00:01:21.070
Because we need to look at who
are we communicating with and

29
00:01:21.070 --> 00:01:23.320
what we are communicating to them.

30
00:01:23.320 --> 00:01:25.210
People are only interested
in what's in it for me.

31
00:01:25.210 --> 00:01:28.570
And if you get the communication wrong,

32
00:01:28.570 --> 00:01:31.900
then you're not really
communicating at all.

33
00:01:31.900 --> 00:01:35.760
And you can send out 150 emails per day,
but

34
00:01:35.760 --> 00:01:38.030
if none of them are read then you
might as well not send out any.

35
00:01:39.160 --> 00:01:41.530
So it's really important that
we get communication right.

36
00:01:41.530 --> 00:01:44.530
So what we're gonna touch on in this
session is just where to start,

37
00:01:44.530 --> 00:01:46.960
when we want to implement CSI.

38
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:52.380
Because I've already mentioned in
previous episodes the fact that,

39
00:01:52.380 --> 00:01:55.510
CSI, yeah it should come naturally,
of course it should.

40
00:01:55.510 --> 00:01:59.840
But it's kind of often the thing
that we forget about the most, okay?

41
00:01:59.840 --> 00:02:04.560
So CSI tends to come to light when
we've got a challenge ahead of us,

42
00:02:04.560 --> 00:02:07.600
when we've got an issue that
we've really got to tackle.

43
00:02:07.600 --> 00:02:11.160
And so we're gonna look at where to start,
and then we're also going to look

44
00:02:11.160 --> 00:02:14.350
just really a communication principles,
very, very briefly.

45
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:16.874
Just understanding sort of
what we're communicating and

46
00:02:16.874 --> 00:02:18.510
who we're communicating to.

47
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:22.650
Because in order for CSI to be successful,
you couldn't tell people about it, right?

48
00:02:22.650 --> 00:02:26.320
You can't just assume that this
going to happen in the background.

49
00:02:26.320 --> 00:02:28.260
Especially when it comes
to adoption of CSI.

50
00:02:28.260 --> 00:02:33.470
In order for CSI to be adopted
it's got to be accepted as

51
00:02:33.470 --> 00:02:36.960
a recognized practice
within the organization.

52
00:02:36.960 --> 00:02:39.740
Well, it's never gonna be accepted
as a recognized practice within

53
00:02:39.740 --> 00:02:43.830
the organization if we don't actually
communicate that we're doing it.

54
00:02:45.720 --> 00:02:50.440
Quite often CSI, if it's done in the
background, people don't know about it.

55
00:02:50.440 --> 00:02:53.470
And therefore when we say yes
well that's our CSI manager.

56
00:02:53.470 --> 00:02:55.670
The first question is,
well why do we need one of those?

57
00:02:55.670 --> 00:02:57.230
Because we're doing this so
well on our own.

58
00:02:57.230 --> 00:03:01.120
Well you're doing this so well because
you've got a CSI manager in place.

59
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:06.846
And this is where the problems lie and
then trying to justify why we're making

60
00:03:06.846 --> 00:03:11.333
improvements or justify why we have
certain positions because of course they

61
00:03:11.333 --> 00:03:15.425
don't see the visibility of those
positions or those improvements.

62
00:03:15.425 --> 00:03:19.810
>> All right, so Jo now that we
understand that they do have to exist.

63
00:03:19.810 --> 00:03:21.851
Right, we have to have a plan for
implementation.

64
00:03:21.851 --> 00:03:24.593
We have to also know about
the idea of communicating.

65
00:03:24.593 --> 00:03:29.068
We've also in episode previous to this,
we've talked about the importance of

66
00:03:29.068 --> 00:03:33.277
the ownership and the responsible
person for this, we've got everything

67
00:03:33.277 --> 00:03:37.720
in placed Joe, so where are we going to
begin in terms of implementation here?

68
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:40.753
>> Well the first thing that we need
to do is to find somewhere to start.

69
00:03:40.753 --> 00:03:42.755
And pick a pain point, and

70
00:03:42.755 --> 00:03:47.760
that's really the obvious answer
to this is to pick a pain point.

71
00:03:47.760 --> 00:03:49.800
Whether it's a pain point
within a service, or

72
00:03:49.800 --> 00:03:53.910
whether it's a pain point within,
we call it a lifecycle approach.

73
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:56.460
But if it's a pain point within a process,
or

74
00:03:56.460 --> 00:03:59.200
whether it's a pain point
within a team itself.

75
00:04:00.220 --> 00:04:05.970
We've got to improve, and we have to
ensure that our improvements are targeted.

76
00:04:05.970 --> 00:04:12.020
So, we can start with a service, and quite
often we'll see a service that's failing.

77
00:04:12.020 --> 00:04:15.070
Now service level management is going to
tell us whether a service is failing or

78
00:04:15.070 --> 00:04:18.120
not, because service level management
sees those slam charts and

79
00:04:18.120 --> 00:04:22.110
those red charts that we've
referred to in previous episodes.

80
00:04:22.110 --> 00:04:26.650
So, we can start with a service or
we can start with a process,

81
00:04:26.650 --> 00:04:27.860
the lifecycle approach.

82
00:04:27.860 --> 00:04:33.140
In other words, maybe we've got
a problem with that handover from

83
00:04:33.140 --> 00:04:34.890
service design to service transition.

84
00:04:34.890 --> 00:04:38.640
In other words, the service design
package may be of poor quality,

85
00:04:38.640 --> 00:04:41.300
or maybe service transition
aren't signing off.

86
00:04:41.300 --> 00:04:45.260
Or maybe we've got a problem with getting
business cases approved and therefore

87
00:04:45.260 --> 00:04:50.060
the hand over from strategy to service
design is not going particularly smoothly.

88
00:04:50.060 --> 00:04:54.510
So we pick a pin point within
the actual service lifecycle itself.

89
00:04:54.510 --> 00:04:58.660
Somewhere where we're not transitioning
from one process to another, or

90
00:04:58.660 --> 00:05:02.470
where we're not transitioning from
one lifecycle phase to another.

91
00:05:02.470 --> 00:05:07.310
You might see that as a communication
issue, but there are genuine

92
00:05:07.310 --> 00:05:12.251
failures that are caused by that
lack of integration should we say.

93
00:05:12.251 --> 00:05:16.430
And then of course there's the functional
group, in other words the team.

94
00:05:18.230 --> 00:05:22.060
The example that we've got up there is
that, if server failure is an issue,

95
00:05:22.060 --> 00:05:24.570
it might not necessarily
be a hardware problem.

96
00:05:24.570 --> 00:05:28.640
It might actually be that the team are
just not functioning in the way that they

97
00:05:28.640 --> 00:05:32.210
need to function in order to keep
the service up in the morning or

98
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:35.970
maybe to actually fix the service
when something goes wrong.

99
00:05:35.970 --> 00:05:39.320
So we need to be able to identify and

100
00:05:39.320 --> 00:05:42.360
recognize when there is
a problem with a team.

101
00:05:42.360 --> 00:05:45.080
Now it could be lack of coordination,

102
00:05:45.080 --> 00:05:49.250
it could be a lack of experience or
lack of skills, or

103
00:05:49.250 --> 00:05:53.800
it could quite simply be an interpersonal
problem that we have to deal with.

104
00:05:53.800 --> 00:05:56.770
Nevertheless, we have to accept
that these things happen and so,

105
00:05:56.770 --> 00:06:00.540
we can't just bury our head in the sand.

106
00:06:00.540 --> 00:06:02.660
We do that Sometimes in IT.

107
00:06:02.660 --> 00:06:06.270
We don't want to address
the elephant in the room.

108
00:06:06.270 --> 00:06:09.110
We don't want to address the fact
that we've got an issue here and

109
00:06:09.110 --> 00:06:14.740
there's something wrong with the team
work, and it's not really coming together.

110
00:06:14.740 --> 00:06:17.710
We're not working as a cohesive team and

111
00:06:17.710 --> 00:06:20.200
our services are suffering
because of that.

112
00:06:20.200 --> 00:06:23.700
So pick a pain point,
this is what I will tell you to do.

113
00:06:23.700 --> 00:06:25.750
Start either with a particular service,

114
00:06:25.750 --> 00:06:28.625
a service that's just not
functioning in the way it should be.

115
00:06:28.625 --> 00:06:32.410
And, Service level management's
going to help us with that.

116
00:06:32.410 --> 00:06:34.020
The service desk itself,

117
00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:37.300
they're going to tell us what
services cause the most issues, too.

118
00:06:37.300 --> 00:06:39.790
They've got all of that information
in their call logging system.

119
00:06:39.790 --> 00:06:41.420
Look at the number of incidents and

120
00:06:41.420 --> 00:06:44.350
the number of problems we
have with any service.

121
00:06:44.350 --> 00:06:46.450
Start with a lifecycle approach.

122
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:50.130
Now that one's going to be
more difficult to identify but

123
00:06:50.130 --> 00:06:54.220
just think about transitions,
transitions from one process to another or

124
00:06:54.220 --> 00:06:57.380
transitions from one
lifecycle phase to another.

125
00:06:57.380 --> 00:07:00.260
If there is a failure in a relationship,

126
00:07:00.260 --> 00:07:04.690
then that's what we call a life cycle
approach, and we've got to address that.

127
00:07:04.690 --> 00:07:07.980
And that's not a case of addressing
it with an individual process.

128
00:07:07.980 --> 00:07:12.160
It's a case of addressing it with
the relationship between two processes or

129
00:07:12.160 --> 00:07:14.285
two lifecycle phases.

130
00:07:14.285 --> 00:07:17.125
And then of course we've got
the team issue as well, so

131
00:07:17.125 --> 00:07:19.933
we may choose to start with the team.

132
00:07:19.933 --> 00:07:22.815
Whatever your pain point is,
that's where you implement CSI,

133
00:07:22.815 --> 00:07:25.065
that's here you need to
make the improvement.

134
00:07:26.215 --> 00:07:28.105
Now, don't forget governance.

135
00:07:28.105 --> 00:07:30.285
Governance is really important to us.

136
00:07:30.285 --> 00:07:33.445
And this is identified
from service strategy.

137
00:07:33.445 --> 00:07:38.040
Service strategy sets
outs governance ethics.

138
00:07:38.040 --> 00:07:42.340
How we're going to work, what our
policies are, the way that we work.

139
00:07:42.340 --> 00:07:45.866
Things like in supplier
management how long do we

140
00:07:45.866 --> 00:07:48.534
negotiate a supplier contract for?

141
00:07:48.534 --> 00:07:53.672
Do we negotiate a contract on an ad-hoc
basis until it expires naturally?

142
00:07:53.672 --> 00:07:56.772
Or do we negotiate a contract
every three years?

143
00:07:56.772 --> 00:07:59.278
Or do we negotiate a ten year contract?

144
00:07:59.278 --> 00:08:02.714
And then when it comes to contract
renewal, do we have to go out and

145
00:08:02.714 --> 00:08:05.600
follow a tender process, or
can we just simply renew?

146
00:08:05.600 --> 00:08:09.730
Well, that's completely dependent on the
organization at some of those instances.

147
00:08:09.730 --> 00:08:12.940
If you're working in a government
organization, for instance,

148
00:08:12.940 --> 00:08:15.850
you have to go out to
tender with every contract.

149
00:08:15.850 --> 00:08:23.194
You have to go out and offer that service
to suppliers every time you renew.

150
00:08:23.194 --> 00:08:25.741
The tendency with government
contracts is that, well,

151
00:08:25.741 --> 00:08:29.347
you're gonna negotiate a contract for
maybe 10 years because you don't wanna

152
00:08:29.347 --> 00:08:32.865
go through the tender process again,
cuz that can be quite a lengthy process.

153
00:08:32.865 --> 00:08:36.900
It can take a year in itself just
to go through the tender process.

154
00:08:37.990 --> 00:08:44.798
Your organization is gonna tell you how
they expect us in IT to be governed, okay?

155
00:08:44.798 --> 00:08:48.621
They will settle a lot of the policies,
but nevertheless,

156
00:08:48.621 --> 00:08:53.211
it's up to strategy management within
service strategy to then define

157
00:08:53.211 --> 00:08:58.040
our own individual governance ethics and
policies within IT.

158
00:08:58.040 --> 00:09:00.670
Think about things like recycling.

159
00:09:00.670 --> 00:09:03.960
Now, for some of us,
recycling is a legal requirement, and

160
00:09:03.960 --> 00:09:06.880
we cannot just dispose of hardware.

161
00:09:06.880 --> 00:09:10.222
For others around the world,
recycling is not a legal requirement.

162
00:09:10.222 --> 00:09:14.405
And so what will tend to happen is
organizations that exist in many

163
00:09:14.405 --> 00:09:18.362
countries, international
organizations will want to adopt

164
00:09:18.362 --> 00:09:22.850
the same ethical policy right away
around the globe because it makes it

165
00:09:22.850 --> 00:09:26.602
easier from a governance from
a management perspective.

166
00:09:26.602 --> 00:09:31.479
So they may impose recycling
on those areas of the world

167
00:09:31.479 --> 00:09:35.304
where recycling is not important to them.

168
00:09:35.304 --> 00:09:39.710
So there has to be a comprehensive and an
integrated approach to governance, okay?

169
00:09:39.710 --> 00:09:41.520
Governance has to apply across the board.

170
00:09:41.520 --> 00:09:44.720
Governance is not just something
that we use in service strategy and

171
00:09:44.720 --> 00:09:46.010
then we forget about.

172
00:09:46.010 --> 00:09:50.650
Governance applies to the way
that we work throughout IT.

173
00:09:50.650 --> 00:09:55.030
Ultimately, don't forget, we've got to be
aligned to the needs of the organization.

174
00:09:55.030 --> 00:09:59.390
And therefore, those governance policies
that the organization set, well,

175
00:09:59.390 --> 00:10:01.320
we've got to be aligned to those.

176
00:10:01.320 --> 00:10:05.300
So in all of our policies,
we've got to be aligned to their needs.

177
00:10:05.300 --> 00:10:08.602
Now, I want to bring in something
called COBIT, Control Objectives for

178
00:10:08.602 --> 00:10:10.397
Information and related Technology.

179
00:10:10.397 --> 00:10:15.705
And I can honestly say that in
recent months, I've had a lot of

180
00:10:15.705 --> 00:10:21.946
interest from various organizations
relating specifically to COBIT.

181
00:10:21.946 --> 00:10:26.192
Now, it came from the finance industry,
and

182
00:10:26.192 --> 00:10:31.781
COBIT came along as a framework for
financial industries,

183
00:10:31.781 --> 00:10:35.694
financial organizations, to define and

184
00:10:35.694 --> 00:10:42.660
integrate strategies within IT,
with organizational strategies.

185
00:10:42.660 --> 00:10:47.130
So it is all about, it says there, it
covers governance of strategic alignment.

186
00:10:47.130 --> 00:10:50.360
It really focuses on value delivery.

187
00:10:50.360 --> 00:10:56.670
It focuses on being at a strategic level,
being aligned to the organization.

188
00:10:56.670 --> 00:11:02.390
It does not focus on
operational performance at all.

189
00:11:02.390 --> 00:11:06.880
It doesn't have any focus on
the business as usual side of IT.

190
00:11:06.880 --> 00:11:11.334
This is all about ensuring
that from a strategic level,

191
00:11:11.334 --> 00:11:14.475
we deliver value to the organization.

192
00:11:14.475 --> 00:11:18.813
So think about it as COBIT focusses
under what we've got to achieve and

193
00:11:18.813 --> 00:11:22.793
the alignment with the organization
that we've got to attain.

194
00:11:22.793 --> 00:11:26.999
Whereas ITIL focuses under
how we're going to do it, and

195
00:11:26.999 --> 00:11:32.100
we have the processes in place
to facilitate that achievement.

196
00:11:32.100 --> 00:11:33.770
And a lot of organizations,

197
00:11:33.770 --> 00:11:38.450
especially financial organizations,
will want to work towards a COBIT audit.

198
00:11:38.450 --> 00:11:43.447
And that's great, but ITIL will actually
help you achieve that COBIT audit.

199
00:11:43.447 --> 00:11:48.033
Without ITIL, without the processes in
place to run the business as usual,

200
00:11:48.033 --> 00:11:52.978
it doesn't matter how well-aligned your
strategy is, you're never going to be

201
00:11:52.978 --> 00:11:56.793
able to realize that strategy
without being able to manage IT.

202
00:11:56.793 --> 00:12:02.236
So COBIT does have a very important
part to play in some organizations,

203
00:12:02.236 --> 00:12:05.510
specifically financial organizations.

204
00:12:06.660 --> 00:12:11.160
But that doesn't mean that ITIL
doesn't have a part to play in those

205
00:12:11.160 --> 00:12:12.160
organizations.

206
00:12:12.160 --> 00:12:18.060
And as it said, ITIL will tell you
how we can achieve your COBIT audit,

207
00:12:18.060 --> 00:12:20.020
and will help you achieve
your COBIT audit.

208
00:12:21.740 --> 00:12:23.850
So let's talk about communications then,

209
00:12:23.850 --> 00:12:27.210
because I know that we mentioned
communication a little while ago.

210
00:12:27.210 --> 00:12:31.160
And I said, well, we have to have a clear
plan for communication, and we have to

211
00:12:31.160 --> 00:12:34.990
understand who we're communicating to and
why we're communicating.

212
00:12:36.740 --> 00:12:38.870
We want to have a formal
communication plan.

213
00:12:38.870 --> 00:12:43.250
And I know that the tendency is to say,
well look,

214
00:12:43.250 --> 00:12:46.680
we're communicating all the time, so
why do we need to formalize this?

215
00:12:46.680 --> 00:12:49.110
Why can't we just send an email?

216
00:12:49.110 --> 00:12:51.770
Well, people expect communications.

217
00:12:51.770 --> 00:12:56.160
If you send an email every
Monday morning at nine o'clock,

218
00:12:56.160 --> 00:12:58.649
people notice when they
don't receive that email.

219
00:13:00.030 --> 00:13:03.760
I've got a few emails that I get from
a few companies that I receive over night,

220
00:13:03.760 --> 00:13:05.740
every night, and I get every morning.

221
00:13:05.740 --> 00:13:07.969
When I open up my laptop,
I get this email.

222
00:13:07.969 --> 00:13:11.290
Now, when I don't receive that email,
I don't necessarily read that email,

223
00:13:11.290 --> 00:13:12.191
don't get me wrong.

224
00:13:12.191 --> 00:13:15.998
But when I don't receive that email,
my first question is,

225
00:13:15.998 --> 00:13:18.472
I wonder why I haven't got that today.

226
00:13:18.472 --> 00:13:22.280
You expect it, you expect certain things.

227
00:13:22.280 --> 00:13:25.510
So this is why we should have
a formal communication plan.

228
00:13:25.510 --> 00:13:30.861
The other thing is that if I don't receive
that email for a specific period of time,

229
00:13:30.861 --> 00:13:34.924
let's say maybe three of four days,
then I stop expecting it.

230
00:13:34.924 --> 00:13:40.648
And when I get it again, then I might
not see the importance of it anymore.

231
00:13:40.648 --> 00:13:44.255
Because if it wasn't important enough
to send it for the last three days,

232
00:13:44.255 --> 00:13:45.732
then why should I read it now?

233
00:13:45.732 --> 00:13:51.450
Communication is really important, and
there are various ways of communication.

234
00:13:51.450 --> 00:13:56.440
And I've just talked about emails, but one
of our communication principles within CSI

235
00:13:56.440 --> 00:14:00.597
is the fact that communication
is a two-way process.

236
00:14:02.050 --> 00:14:07.730
Communication is both to an audience and
also from an audience.

237
00:14:07.730 --> 00:14:10.870
And feedback is incredibly important.

238
00:14:10.870 --> 00:14:13.090
We should always give opportunity for
feedback.

239
00:14:13.090 --> 00:14:17.860
I've said numerous times, communication
should be in the language of the audience,

240
00:14:17.860 --> 00:14:20.830
and it should also answer the question,
what's in it for me?

241
00:14:22.190 --> 00:14:23.680
Think about how you're communicating.

242
00:14:23.680 --> 00:14:27.650
We can improve communication,
and that's why it's in CSI.

243
00:14:27.650 --> 00:14:31.190
Cuz we can improve it,
we can get better at it.

244
00:14:31.190 --> 00:14:33.930
I will always improve my communication and

245
00:14:33.930 --> 00:14:36.580
the way I talk based on
my feedback from you.

246
00:14:36.580 --> 00:14:38.530
If you don't like the way
I've done something, or

247
00:14:38.530 --> 00:14:42.500
you don't like what I've said, and I'm
gonna take that forward, and next time,

248
00:14:42.500 --> 00:14:47.330
maybe I won't actually say that, or maybe
I will do something slightly different.

249
00:14:47.330 --> 00:14:50.132
If I made an organization
during consultancy,

250
00:14:50.132 --> 00:14:54.335
or maybe I am doing a presentation and
then a particular organization,

251
00:14:54.335 --> 00:14:59.320
if I see somebody asleep, then that tells
me that I'm not communicating very well.

252
00:14:59.320 --> 00:15:02.288
If I hear somebody snore, and
then that tells me I've really,

253
00:15:02.288 --> 00:15:04.032
really got to work on things, okay?

254
00:15:04.032 --> 00:15:06.540
So communications is very important.

255
00:15:06.540 --> 00:15:09.773
And the first thing that we've got to
do is we've gotta work at who we're

256
00:15:09.773 --> 00:15:10.750
communicating to.

257
00:15:10.750 --> 00:15:12.960
So that's our target audience.

258
00:15:12.960 --> 00:15:18.044
And what is it we need to tell them,
and how are we going to tell them?

259
00:15:18.044 --> 00:15:20.425
The method of communication
is really important.

260
00:15:20.425 --> 00:15:21.823
Think about email.

261
00:15:21.823 --> 00:15:26.240
We all know the general
guidance on the email.

262
00:15:26.240 --> 00:15:29.780
Don't put a joke in email cuz the person
who's reading it might not be in a great

263
00:15:29.780 --> 00:15:33.061
mood that day, and they might
misconstrue something that you've said.

264
00:15:33.061 --> 00:15:37.180
We all know that, but what about
the other principles of email, too?

265
00:15:37.180 --> 00:15:41.629
And the principles of email in that any
email that you send could end up anywhere.

266
00:15:41.629 --> 00:15:45.007
So don't forget, it's been written down,
and it could be passed on.

267
00:15:45.007 --> 00:15:45.599
So really,

268
00:15:45.599 --> 00:15:49.700
you don't need to be saying anything in
your email that you shouldn't be saying.

269
00:15:49.700 --> 00:15:54.351
But also,
think about how long is your email?

270
00:15:54.351 --> 00:15:58.131
I mean, I don't know about you personally
but there's a general principle that says

271
00:15:58.131 --> 00:16:02.540
if it's longer than one page then people
aren't going to scroll down and read it.

272
00:16:02.540 --> 00:16:06.683
I was in a position quite some
time ago now where I went to

273
00:16:06.683 --> 00:16:10.659
conduct an executive
overview to an organization.

274
00:16:10.659 --> 00:16:15.158
And this particular organization,
we had 50 people that had turned up for

275
00:16:15.158 --> 00:16:18.967
this executive overview and
I thought to myself, 50 people?

276
00:16:18.967 --> 00:16:23.700
Surely there's not 50 board of directors
for this particular organization.

277
00:16:23.700 --> 00:16:27.999
And sure enough, they hadn't read
down in the email to see who

278
00:16:27.999 --> 00:16:32.228
the target audience was for
that particular presentation.

279
00:16:32.228 --> 00:16:35.468
And so if you don't put it
there right in front of them,

280
00:16:35.468 --> 00:16:38.920
then people aren't going to scroll down.

281
00:16:38.920 --> 00:16:41.730
And then think about other
medium of communication,

282
00:16:41.730 --> 00:16:46.100
things like town hall meetings or
video communication.

283
00:16:46.100 --> 00:16:49.220
Well that's great, but then how
are you gonna obtain the feedback?

284
00:16:49.220 --> 00:16:53.130
And I'll be the one that says to you,
hey we've got a forum, we've got a chat,

285
00:16:53.130 --> 00:16:59.182
then please tell us how you feel, ask me
any questions and I will answer you back.

286
00:16:59.182 --> 00:17:00.880
Now obviously this has been recorded so

287
00:17:00.880 --> 00:17:03.810
I'm not going to answer
you back in real-time.

288
00:17:03.810 --> 00:17:07.523
I can't answer your question right
now while I'm talking to you,

289
00:17:07.523 --> 00:17:08.924
although I wish I could.

290
00:17:08.924 --> 00:17:12.432
[LAUGH] But
I am going to come back to you.

291
00:17:12.432 --> 00:17:15.360
But I don't know when you're going
to be watching this recording.

292
00:17:16.450 --> 00:17:18.810
And what about other
types of communication.

293
00:17:18.810 --> 00:17:23.260
If we're launching a new project then some
people could be very wary about the state

294
00:17:23.260 --> 00:17:29.530
of their roles of the state of their
current position within the organization.

295
00:17:29.530 --> 00:17:32.038
Well you're certainly
not going to just tell

296
00:17:32.038 --> 00:17:35.281
them something like that via a text or
via an email are you?

297
00:17:35.281 --> 00:17:39.237
Surely you're going to sit down with them
and explain this is what's happening and

298
00:17:39.237 --> 00:17:40.830
this is how it's affecting you.

299
00:17:42.430 --> 00:17:44.420
We should communicate on a regular basis.

300
00:17:44.420 --> 00:17:47.159
And communication shouldn't
be a one-off thing.

301
00:17:47.159 --> 00:17:51.641
We should have senior management buy
in for all of our communication, so

302
00:17:51.641 --> 00:17:55.095
that everybody understands
that no matter what you're

303
00:17:55.095 --> 00:18:00.500
communicating at whatever level,
you have the support of senior management.

304
00:18:00.500 --> 00:18:02.530
But communication should be regular.

305
00:18:02.530 --> 00:18:06.280
Don't just tell somebody we're launching
a new project and then walk away and leave

306
00:18:06.280 --> 00:18:11.090
them, because that's when speculation
starts, that's when rumours start, and

307
00:18:11.090 --> 00:18:15.810
that's how projects and improvement
initiatives end up being undermined.

308
00:18:15.810 --> 00:18:19.500
Because rumors start, speculation happens.

309
00:18:19.500 --> 00:18:22.340
And if we don't tell somebody something,
believe me,

310
00:18:22.340 --> 00:18:24.460
somebody's gonna make it up, okay?

311
00:18:24.460 --> 00:18:27.870
So we have to think about
how we communicate.

312
00:18:27.870 --> 00:18:30.490
So before we prepare any communication,

313
00:18:30.490 --> 00:18:33.090
let's think about who we're
communicating to, and

314
00:18:33.090 --> 00:18:37.560
how often we should communicate to them,
and what messages we wanna communicate.

315
00:18:37.560 --> 00:18:41.320
If I see an email every single day
then I'm not really interested in

316
00:18:41.320 --> 00:18:42.520
reading that email.

317
00:18:42.520 --> 00:18:48.230
But if I see one once a week then I'm
definitely going to be interested.

318
00:18:48.230 --> 00:18:52.015
I am really interested in that.

319
00:18:52.015 --> 00:18:55.626
Sorry, excuse me,
I lost my train of thought there.

320
00:18:55.626 --> 00:19:00.109
So the portion there that says,
need to be aware of losing the focus.

321
00:19:01.420 --> 00:19:05.060
Take a look at that flashlight,
that torch that's on the right hand side.

322
00:19:06.410 --> 00:19:11.380
What I want you to get away from, or
take away from this, is the fact that,

323
00:19:12.680 --> 00:19:18.320
the further away from the vision that
you are the less it means to you,

324
00:19:18.320 --> 00:19:22.300
the more diluted that message becomes.

325
00:19:24.250 --> 00:19:28.410
So at a strategic level,
right up there at that strategic level,

326
00:19:28.410 --> 00:19:32.280
the communication at that
level needs to be strategic.

327
00:19:33.778 --> 00:19:38.650
The communication at that level
doesn't need to get into the nuances

328
00:19:38.650 --> 00:19:42.300
of the actual technologies that
we're going to be updating.

329
00:19:42.300 --> 00:19:46.380
It doesn't need to get into the nitty
gritty, it doesn't need to answer

330
00:19:46.380 --> 00:19:51.110
questions like, does that mean I still
come in at 9 AM on Monday morning?

331
00:19:51.110 --> 00:19:53.690
That's not what needs to be
communicated at that level,

332
00:19:53.690 --> 00:19:56.420
at that level we're
communicating the vision.

333
00:19:56.420 --> 00:20:00.760
But the further down we move towards
tactical and operational level,

334
00:20:00.760 --> 00:20:06.480
then the more relevant that communication
needs to be to that individual level.

335
00:20:06.480 --> 00:20:10.320
So from an operational level we're
thinking about communicating, okay,

336
00:20:10.320 --> 00:20:13.230
do I need to be in at nine
o'clock on Monday morning?

337
00:20:13.230 --> 00:20:18.371
Exactly what is this going to mean to me,
how is this process going to change?

338
00:20:18.371 --> 00:20:22.268
So think about who you're
communicating what to.

339
00:20:22.268 --> 00:20:26.120
And the demand, as it says,
is driven by that level above it.

340
00:20:26.120 --> 00:20:30.380
So if I've communicated at the top level
that there's going to be a change,

341
00:20:30.380 --> 00:20:35.270
then at the tactical level then I'm
hungry to know about that change.

342
00:20:35.270 --> 00:20:38.400
And at the operational level I'm asking
that question what's in it for me?

343
00:20:40.020 --> 00:20:44.065
And don't forget those
arrows are bi-directional.

344
00:20:44.065 --> 00:20:50.055
Communication is a two-way process, so
we have to be prepared to accept feedback.

345
00:20:50.055 --> 00:20:52.855
And it doesn't matter what
level we're communicating at,

346
00:20:53.985 --> 00:20:57.925
we have to give a vehicle for feedback.

347
00:20:57.925 --> 00:21:01.895
We have to provide some form of
opportunity to feed it back.

348
00:21:01.895 --> 00:21:06.281
Then in exactly the same way I will
say to you look, we've got a forum.

349
00:21:06.281 --> 00:21:09.420
And if you have any questions please
come back to us on the forum and

350
00:21:09.420 --> 00:21:12.440
I'll be happy to answer any
of those questions for you.

351
00:21:12.440 --> 00:21:18.501
Well, we have to do that at every single
level and with any form of communication.

352
00:21:18.501 --> 00:21:24.463
So now, over the last few sessions
we've looked at implementing CSI.

353
00:21:24.463 --> 00:21:27.696
We've looked at where we start
when we're implementing CSI,

354
00:21:27.696 --> 00:21:31.661
we've looked at communication,
we've also in a previous episode looked at

355
00:21:31.661 --> 00:21:34.680
technology considerations
as well with CSI.

356
00:21:34.680 --> 00:21:39.382
And now within the course material that
you've downloaded you have some exercises,

357
00:21:39.382 --> 00:21:43.427
and those exercises are going to take
you around about an hour to an hour and

358
00:21:43.427 --> 00:21:44.554
a half to complete.

359
00:21:44.554 --> 00:21:47.801
So I would like you to go away and
take a look at the exercises,

360
00:21:47.801 --> 00:21:52.620
they're to do with technology and
also implementation and communication.

361
00:21:52.620 --> 00:21:55.990
And by all means,
please come back to us on the forum.

362
00:21:55.990 --> 00:22:00.670
Let us know how you feel about
the exercises, let us know how you get on.

363
00:22:00.670 --> 00:22:04.290
And if you have any questions,
then I'll be happy to answer them for you.

364
00:22:04.290 --> 00:22:04.810
>> All right Jo.

365
00:22:04.810 --> 00:22:09.040
Well thank you again for helping us out
here in understanding the importance

366
00:22:09.040 --> 00:22:11.800
of the implementation as
well as the communication

367
00:22:11.800 --> 00:22:14.930
to help us to get started in our
continual service improvement.

368
00:22:14.930 --> 00:22:17.620
As well, make sure you also
take Jo's advice there and

369
00:22:17.620 --> 00:22:19.430
do the homework that's required.

370
00:22:19.430 --> 00:22:23.421
Before you move on, make sure these
concepts are solidified in your mind.

371
00:22:23.421 --> 00:22:26.610
Well that's a great place for
us to sign off for this episode then.

372
00:22:26.610 --> 00:22:29.770
For ITPRO.TV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

373
00:22:29.770 --> 00:22:30.810
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

374
00:22:30.810 --> 00:22:36.551
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the ITIL Intermediate CSI Shows.

375
00:22:36.551 --> 00:22:42.534
[MUSIC]

376
00:22:42.534 --> 00:22:45.632
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo look at the challenges to implementing CSI, the CSFs that show what needs to be accomplished and then the risks that can stop of CSI in its progress.  Jo reviews the most common factors in each of these areas to help us gain a better understanding of the CSI lifecycle.
episodes.title: Challenges, CSFs and Risks

we're gonna be diving into challenges,

[LAUGH] All right, Jo, now,

00:00:52.615 --> 00:00:56.660
tongue-twisting for me to actually have to

21
00:00:56.660 --> 00:01:01.680
So Jo, when it comes down to the idea of
challenges and critical success factors,

22
00:01:01.680 --> 00:01:06.900
those don't seem to go together, but nor
do risks seem to actually go together with

23
00:01:06.900 --> 00:01:09.960
the critical success factors and
well, risk either.

24
00:01:09.960 --> 00:01:13.530
So Jo, these seem a little bit disparate
here in what we're talking about.

25
00:01:13.530 --> 00:01:16.810
So what are some of the challenges
that we actually have to think about?

26
00:01:16.810 --> 00:01:20.010
And how are we gonna combine all of those
together to help us out in what we're

27
00:01:20.010 --> 00:01:21.295
taking a look at?

28
00:01:21.295 --> 00:01:23.572
>> Well, what we're gonna take a look
at really in this section, and

29
00:01:23.572 --> 00:01:24.761
this is just a very small section.

30
00:01:24.761 --> 00:01:30.620
Just where we cover the challenges that we
face when we're trying to implement CSI.

31
00:01:30.620 --> 00:01:34.040
Now, we have covered some of
these in previous sections.

32
00:01:34.040 --> 00:01:38.480
But we're going to just take a brief

about addressing the issues mentioned
either in the question or the scenario.

145
00:08:59.570 --> 00:09:05.404
If your answer does not address the issues
I relevance, if it's not relevant,

146
00:09:05.404 --> 00:09:10.191
then again, you're not going to be
on to that five point answer so

147
00:09:10.191 --> 00:09:14.390
read the full question,
be very, very careful, okay?

148
00:09:15.570 --> 00:09:19.650
It says that as you read the scenario,
highlight, underline, or write down

149
00:09:19.650 --> 00:09:24.520
the specific issues, but you can only do
that if you've got a paper exam in front

150
00:09:24.520 --> 00:09:29.320
of you, you can not do that when you
are online and doing a virtual test.

151
00:09:29.320 --> 00:09:35.430
You will be allowed, in your virtual test,
to have a piece of blank paper with you.

152
00:09:36.900 --> 00:09:41.210
What I would recommend, and I was just
thinking if how I had one here, and

153
00:09:41.210 --> 00:09:42.930
I don't, unfortunately.

154
00:09:42.930 --> 00:09:48.020
What I would recommend for you is to
actually take one piece of blank paper,

155
00:09:48.020 --> 00:09:50.770
and fold it into quarters.

156
00:09:50.770 --> 00:09:54.610
By doing that, you've divided up
the front page into four sections and

157
00:09:54.610 --> 00:09:57.687
you've divided up the back
page into four sections too.

158
00:09:57.687 --> 00:10:01.329
You'll be allowed to have that piece
of paper and a pencil with you.

159
00:10:02.380 --> 00:10:08.540
In every single quarter I would write down
the notes for each particular question.

160
00:10:09.610 --> 00:10:12.690
What that allows you to do is actually
keep your questions separate,

161
00:10:12.690 --> 00:10:14.500
which is a huge start.

162
00:10:14.500 --> 00:10:18.572
If you just start writing down random
words on a piece of paper you won't really

163
00:10:18.572 --> 00:10:20.311
know what question it refers to.

164
00:10:20.311 --> 00:10:24.730
And if you have to go back to a question
then you really be in trouble, okay?

165
00:10:24.730 --> 00:10:29.100
So, take that piece of people and
literally just fol it into four and

166
00:10:29.100 --> 00:10:33.110
as you all fold it you've now got
to divide it four on each side and

167
00:10:33.110 --> 00:10:35.530
use one quarter for each question and

168
00:10:35.530 --> 00:10:39.190
then right down the specific words
you want to highlight, okay.

169
00:10:40.330 --> 00:10:43.280
So, the third bullet point up there
talks about sticking to facts,

170
00:10:43.280 --> 00:10:48.440
and what I will say to you is,
don't assume, please don't assume.

171
00:10:48.440 --> 00:10:52.040
Stick to what's in front of you,
read the full question, and

172
00:10:52.040 --> 00:10:56.050
don't read in between the lines,
there is nothing written there.

173
00:10:56.050 --> 00:11:00.020
So don't read in between the lines,
don't assume anything,

174
00:11:00.020 --> 00:11:04.570
if it's not down in black and white,
then it simply, doesn't exist.

175
00:11:05.930 --> 00:11:11.060
Now you've completed your class, now's
the time when you follow this link, and

176
00:11:11.060 --> 00:11:13.690
you download your exam voucher.

177
00:11:15.100 --> 00:11:18.578
What will happen,
is you'll be given this voucher, and

178
00:11:18.578 --> 00:11:23.507
you will be also given an instruction
booklet or an instruction email, rather,

179
00:11:23.507 --> 00:11:27.492
and you will be asked to go to
the website at peoplecert.org, and

180
00:11:27.492 --> 00:11:31.790
you will be asked to register as
a kind if you haven't already done so.

181
00:11:31.790 --> 00:11:35.973
You may already have a candidate login,
and

182
00:11:35.973 --> 00:11:43.000
then you select the option to register for
an exam, using a exam voucher.

183
00:11:43.000 --> 00:11:44.930
Let me repeat that again, okay?

184
00:11:44.930 --> 00:11:51.735
You'll be asked to register for an exam
using an examination voucher, okay?

185
00:11:51.735 --> 00:11:56.578
And then the voucher number that you've
been given in your email from Passion IT

186
00:11:56.578 --> 00:12:00.020
is the voucher number that you will use.

187
00:12:00.020 --> 00:12:03.290
Once you've input that, it's going to
ask you for an appropriate date and

188
00:12:03.290 --> 00:12:05.480
time to set your test.

189
00:12:05.480 --> 00:12:08.060
You can do whatever time you like, so

190
00:12:08.060 --> 00:12:11.540
pick something that's appropriate for
you, okay?

191
00:12:11.540 --> 00:12:14.000
Something that you can work with.

192
00:12:14.000 --> 00:12:18.530
There are a few things that I want to
tell you about this online exam as well.

193
00:12:18.530 --> 00:12:22.780
And the first thing is,
please make sure you can't be interrupted.

194
00:12:22.780 --> 00:12:26.570
You need to be in a room
where it's only you and

195
00:12:26.570 --> 00:12:28.680
preferably where the door is closed.

196
00:12:30.140 --> 00:12:35.790
You will need to be using a laptop or
a tablet with a camera.

197
00:12:35.790 --> 00:12:37.450
If your laptop or your tablet or

198
00:12:37.450 --> 00:12:42.400
your desktop does not have a camera then
you won't be able to sit your test because

199
00:12:42.400 --> 00:12:47.210
you will be watched by a proctor
throughout your entire test.

200
00:12:47.210 --> 00:12:48.820
You can't use more than one screen.

201
00:12:48.820 --> 00:12:51.260
You can only use one screen.

202
00:12:51.260 --> 00:12:56.297
And you cannot at any point in time have
any other devices on your desk either,

203
00:12:56.297 --> 00:12:59.722
so nothing that can connect
to the Internet, okay.

204
00:13:01.265 --> 00:13:04.938
You will be asked when you
register of your test for

205
00:13:04.938 --> 00:13:11.430
about an hour before your test is due to
download some exam guard software, okay?

206
00:13:11.430 --> 00:13:15.100
And what that does is that allows
the proctor to remotely watch what

207
00:13:15.100 --> 00:13:18.600
you are doing on your laptop or
on your PC or on your device and

208
00:13:18.600 --> 00:13:21.319
then make sure that you're not on
the internet Googling the answer.

209
00:13:23.510 --> 00:13:27.320
So, we started our exam,
we've downloaded all the software.

210
00:13:27.320 --> 00:13:31.250
And by the way, when I mentioned that,
if you're using a work PC you better make

211
00:13:31.250 --> 00:13:34.770
sure you have the permissions in order
to be able to download that software.

212
00:13:34.770 --> 00:13:38.123
If the software's not on your PC,
then you won't be able to sit the test.

213
00:13:38.123 --> 00:13:44.010
Okay, so then the proctor will come online
and they will ask you if you're all ready.

214
00:13:44.010 --> 00:13:47.020
And they'll tell you that you can
have a piece of paper and a pen.

215
00:13:47.020 --> 00:13:49.960
And then they will ask
to see around your room.

216
00:13:49.960 --> 00:13:55.419
So you must be in a position where you
can physically pick up your laptop and

217
00:13:55.419 --> 00:13:59.309
turn it around so
that the proctor can view the room.

218
00:13:59.309 --> 00:14:02.980
That's to make sure that you don't
have any ITIL books with you.

219
00:14:02.980 --> 00:14:05.870
That you don't have anybody,
like me, hiding in the corner or

220
00:14:05.870 --> 00:14:08.230
hiding under your desk helping you out.

221
00:14:08.230 --> 00:14:12.393
And it's also to make sure that
you are completely alone and

222
00:14:12.393 --> 00:14:16.150
can't be interrupted during
that particular test.

223
00:14:16.150 --> 00:14:22.160
At that point in time, the examiner
will ask you to start your test.

224
00:14:22.160 --> 00:14:23.940
You'll get 90 minutes.

225
00:14:23.940 --> 00:14:27.470
And to be perfectly honest 90 minutes or
an hour and a half is pretty comfortable.

226
00:14:28.800 --> 00:14:32.890
At the end of your test,
one thing I will tell you,

227
00:14:32.890 --> 00:14:34.160
please don't change your answers.

228
00:14:34.160 --> 00:14:36.780
Go with your gut instinct
it's generally right.

229
00:14:36.780 --> 00:14:40.160
And to be perfectly honest,
in about 75% of cases,

230
00:14:40.160 --> 00:14:42.900
the person who changes their answer
changes it to the wrong one.

231
00:14:43.930 --> 00:14:46.390
You wanna weigh in for
about ten minutes per question

232
00:14:46.390 --> 00:14:49.670
the average is 11 minutes per question,
but I aim for ten.

233
00:14:49.670 --> 00:14:53.160
And then you'll feel completely
comfortable with the time and

234
00:14:53.160 --> 00:14:57.460
at the end of your test,
you will be asked to submit.

235
00:14:57.460 --> 00:15:00.890
And when you've finished
then you click submit.

236
00:15:00.890 --> 00:15:04.790
At that point in time,
your screen will disappear.

237
00:15:05.810 --> 00:15:10.650
You will be given an intermediate,
I don't like to use that word, actually,

238
00:15:10.650 --> 00:15:12.510
when we're talking about
item intermediates.

239
00:15:12.510 --> 00:15:14.940
You'll be getting an interim result,
there and then.

240
00:15:14.940 --> 00:15:18.910
And that interim result will tell you very
simply whether you've passed or failed.

241
00:15:18.910 --> 00:15:22.780
You're not gonna be able to get anything
more than that out of it, okay?

242
00:15:22.780 --> 00:15:26.260
It's just a pass or
fail because it has to be independently

243
00:15:26.260 --> 00:15:29.420
audited before they can release
the result to you, okay?

244
00:15:29.420 --> 00:15:32.600
So you'll get your interim
result immediately, and

245
00:15:32.600 --> 00:15:37.300
then you'll get your result with
your score within a week, okay?

246
00:15:38.480 --> 00:15:41.450
I want to just draw attention to
that bottom bullet point there

247
00:15:41.450 --> 00:15:42.620
just before we move on.

248
00:15:42.620 --> 00:15:46.360
If you're struggling with the question
move on come back to it and

249
00:15:46.360 --> 00:15:49.410
just remember that if you
don't answer a question

250
00:15:49.410 --> 00:15:52.110
because you think it's too difficult
then you gonna get zero points.

251
00:15:53.330 --> 00:15:56.440
You've got a 25% chance of
getting a 5 pointer and

252
00:15:56.440 --> 00:15:59.971
you've got a 50 percent chance
of either getting 5 or 3.

253
00:15:59.971 --> 00:16:01.960
So please answer it, okay.

254
00:16:01.960 --> 00:16:04.860
Don't just leave it blank,
always answer a question.

255
00:16:06.190 --> 00:16:11.370
Right, I think I've probably given
you enough exam tips for now.

256
00:16:11.370 --> 00:16:16.040
Now it's your turn, what I want you
to do now is I want you to go and

257
00:16:16.040 --> 00:16:19.320
I want you to download sample paper one.

258
00:16:19.320 --> 00:16:24.080
And then I want you to do sample paper
one, including the scenario booklet and

259
00:16:24.080 --> 00:16:25.620
the question booklet.

260
00:16:25.620 --> 00:16:29.515
I want you to do that now and
then we're gonna come back and

261
00:16:29.515 --> 00:16:32.852
we're gonna go through
that question booklet.

262
00:16:32.852 --> 00:16:35.417
Now you'll notice that with
this particular booklet,

263
00:16:35.417 --> 00:16:38.650
with sample paper one you've got
answers and you've got rationale.

264
00:16:38.650 --> 00:16:42.250
In other words, that's the reason why,
that's the five pointer,

265
00:16:42.250 --> 00:16:48.020
the reason why this one is the three
pointer but for the moment

266
00:16:48.020 --> 00:16:52.660
what I want us to do is to come is I want
us to come back when you finish that exam.

267
00:16:52.660 --> 00:16:57.660
I want us to come back and
I want us to go through that test, okay?

268
00:16:57.660 --> 00:17:00.790
And then you see how you did.

269
00:17:00.790 --> 00:17:03.560
And don't forget we've got
a forum available to us and

270
00:17:03.560 --> 00:17:07.180
now more than anything else when you
really wanna be using that forum.

271
00:17:07.180 --> 00:17:10.998
Just to answer questions,
etcetera as we've gone through that test.

272
00:17:10.998 --> 00:17:15.958
So, good luck,
have fun with your sample paper.

273
00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:20.299
Remember, read the full question,
read the full scenario,

274
00:17:20.299 --> 00:17:23.553
every word counts,
check for relevance, and

275
00:17:23.553 --> 00:17:28.574
don't make assumptions, and
I'll see you when you finish your test.

276
00:17:28.574 --> 00:17:29.480
>> All right Jo.

277
00:17:29.480 --> 00:17:33.680
Well thank you again for helping us
out and those different exam tips.

278
00:17:33.680 --> 00:17:35.150
But remember that now is the time for

279
00:17:35.150 --> 00:17:39.670
of course for you to download that
exam paper and do exactly as Jo says.

280
00:17:39.670 --> 00:17:42.590
And when you get back, there will be,
of course Jo waiting for

281
00:17:42.590 --> 00:17:44.770
you to review that paper as well.

282
00:17:44.770 --> 00:17:47.000
Well great place for
us to end this episode then.

283
00:17:47.000 --> 00:17:50.080
For ITPRO.TV I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

284
00:17:50.080 --> 00:17:51.170
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

285
00:17:51.170 --> 00:17:55.550
>> Come right back for
your exam review with Jo.

286
00:17:55.550 --> 00:18:01.472
[MUSIC]

287
00:18:01.472 --> 00:18:04.872
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.925
[SOUND] Hi, so
by now you have finished your

2
00:00:04.925 --> 00:00:09.412
sample paper, the sample paper one.

3
00:00:09.412 --> 00:00:13.796
And now we are going to spend the next
couple of sessions just going over

4
00:00:13.796 --> 00:00:16.220
the questions from sample paper one.

5
00:00:16.220 --> 00:00:21.130
And going over any problems that
you might have experienced,

6
00:00:21.130 --> 00:00:26.390
just looking for some pointers here,
just to help you in your real test, okay?

7
00:00:26.390 --> 00:00:30.820
So, let's launch straight away
then into question number 1.

8
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:35.210
Okay, and question number one
relates to a SWOT analysis.

9
00:00:35.210 --> 00:00:38.380
And the question that it asks you is,
which of the following statements about

10
00:00:38.380 --> 00:00:42.690
this SWOT analysis, that's your strengths,
weaknesses, opportunities and threats.

11
00:00:42.690 --> 00:00:44.050
Which one of these answers,

12
00:00:44.050 --> 00:00:50.020
best reveals it's usefulness in
identifying the current gaps, okay?

13
00:00:50.020 --> 00:00:54.520
So what we gotta identify here then in
our scenario, is the business strategy.

14
00:00:54.520 --> 00:00:58.190
We're looking for
any specific deficiencies here, and

15
00:00:58.190 --> 00:01:01.430
we're also looking for
our current capabilities.

16
00:01:01.430 --> 00:01:05.270
Now, things that I want to pull out of
this scenario here then, right now.

17
00:01:05.270 --> 00:01:09.340
Here's the fact that we've got
a medium sized company here,

18
00:01:09.340 --> 00:01:13.730
that got one manufacturing plant
they employed 200 people, okay?

19
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:18.686
And they've experienced difficulty,
in keeping production in line with demand.

20
00:01:18.686 --> 00:01:21.010
Okay, so
we've got some demand issues here.

21
00:01:21.010 --> 00:01:25.810
We've got problems with demand management,
perhaps business relationship management.

22
00:01:25.810 --> 00:01:28.640
We've got issues there
within the strategy itself.

23
00:01:28.640 --> 00:01:33.300
So they want to expand both locally and
abroad.

24
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:35.800
And the business,
bearing in mind we're in CSI,

25
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:38.930
we have to align ourselves
with the business strategy.

26
00:01:38.930 --> 00:01:41.020
They want to streamline
business operations.

27
00:01:41.020 --> 00:01:43.340
They want to concentrate
on increasing market share,

28
00:01:43.340 --> 00:01:47.960
and they want to improve
production capacity and

29
00:01:47.960 --> 00:01:51.790
capabilities, by moving to the new
sites in different territories.

30
00:01:53.220 --> 00:01:57.550
The CIO is now considering
the department's strategic response.

31
00:01:58.650 --> 00:02:01.960
And they want to increase awareness
in that acceptance of CSI.

32
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:08.510
You've recently taken
over as the CSI manager.

33
00:02:08.510 --> 00:02:09.640
There's a bit of a clue there.

34
00:02:09.640 --> 00:02:10.970
I'll put emphasis on that.

35
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:14.690
You've taken over as the CSI manager.

36
00:02:14.690 --> 00:02:19.210
So whilst I'll say things like, don't make
any assumptions, if you've taken over,

37
00:02:19.210 --> 00:02:24.990
there was either a previous CSI manager
there, or CSI was already in place.

38
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:29.070
There is an implication there that,
there's been some form of CSI, okay?

39
00:02:30.440 --> 00:02:34.160
You've recently taken over, but then
you've been given the results of a SWOT

40
00:02:34.160 --> 00:02:38.520
analysis, that was conducted by IT staff,
doesn't say whether it was anything to do

41
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:43.930
with CSI, a few months before
the strategies were agreed and published.

42
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:45.730
Therefore before your appointment.

43
00:02:45.730 --> 00:02:50.230
The fact that it was before your
appointment, is quite an important note

44
00:02:50.230 --> 00:02:54.890
to make, but certainly the fact that it
was before the strategies were decided and

45
00:02:54.890 --> 00:02:57.770
published, well that's
incredibly important.

46
00:02:57.770 --> 00:03:02.460
Because if you remember, we go back to the
session where we looked at SWOT analysis,

47
00:03:02.460 --> 00:03:04.320
and one of the things that I said is,

48
00:03:04.320 --> 00:03:07.660
that we have to have a clear direction for
a SWOT.

49
00:03:07.660 --> 00:03:12.020
In other words it's no good if we're
doing a SWOT analysis on whether

50
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:16.980
I am able to deliver a training class.

51
00:03:16.980 --> 00:03:22.130
Well, the fact that I have a strength in
being able to make my own furniture for

52
00:03:22.130 --> 00:03:27.852
my deck at home, has absolutely no bearing
on my ability to deliver a training class.

53
00:03:27.852 --> 00:03:32.388
So therefore our strengths and weaknesses,
and our opportunities and our threats,

54
00:03:32.388 --> 00:03:34.280
these are external factors.

55
00:03:34.280 --> 00:03:39.870
Well they have to have a bearing on
what it is we're trying to achieve.

56
00:03:39.870 --> 00:03:41.480
And what we're trying to achieve,

57
00:03:41.480 --> 00:03:44.520
is alignment to the strategies
in the organization.

58
00:03:44.520 --> 00:03:46.800
Well if the strategies have
only just been announced,

59
00:03:46.800 --> 00:03:50.720
then obviously the SWOT is not going
to be aligned to those strategies.

60
00:03:50.720 --> 00:03:52.740
Kinda makes sense really doesn't it?

61
00:03:52.740 --> 00:03:54.150
So let's take a look at the SWOT.

62
00:03:55.982 --> 00:03:59.850
So, our strengths are that we demonstrate
commitment to CSI manager and

63
00:03:59.850 --> 00:04:02.000
that we've got the right attitude.

64
00:04:02.000 --> 00:04:06.712
And that we've got processes
based at maturity level 3,

65
00:04:06.712 --> 00:04:08.836
level 3 as in CMMI scale.

66
00:04:08.836 --> 00:04:12.240
Okay, that's great,
what about weaknesses then?

67
00:04:12.240 --> 00:04:14.030
We're reactive.

68
00:04:14.030 --> 00:04:19.110
We've got stagnant processes, we've got
a lack of monitoring and reporting tools.

69
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:21.210
Monitoring and reporting about what?

70
00:04:21.210 --> 00:04:23.180
That's my question, okay?

71
00:04:24.450 --> 00:04:27.720
And then we've got processes
that are poorly integrated, but

72
00:04:27.720 --> 00:04:29.839
what is the aim of those processes?

73
00:04:31.260 --> 00:04:35.160
Now opportunities, don't forget,
opportunities are external.

74
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:38.990
So external to
the IT Service Provider Organization.

75
00:04:38.990 --> 00:04:43.050
So investing in an integrated service
management tool to remove bottlenecks,

76
00:04:43.050 --> 00:04:45.560
is that a an opportunity?

77
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:49.245
Is that external to the service
provider organization?

78
00:04:49.245 --> 00:04:52.740
Implementing a new reporting mechanism and
tools for knowledge management.

79
00:04:52.740 --> 00:04:55.470
Again, is that external
to the organization?

80
